              <b:includable id='post' var='post'>
  <div class='post hentry uncustomized-post-template' itemprop='blogPost' itemscope='itemscope' itemtype='http://schema.org/BlogPosting'>
    <b:if cond='data:post.firstImageUrl'>
      <meta expr:content='data:post.firstImageUrl' itemprop='image_url'/>
    </b:if>
    <meta expr:content='data:blog.blogId' itemprop='blogId'/>
    <meta expr:content='data:post.id' itemprop='postId'/>

    <a expr:name='data:post.id'/>
    <b:if cond='data:post.title'>
      <h3 class='post-title entry-title' itemprop='name'>
      <b:if cond='data:post.link or (data:post.url and data:blog.url != data:post.url)'>
        <a expr:href='data:post.link ? data:post.link : data:post.url'><data:post.title/></a>
      <b:else/>
        <data:post.title/>
      </b:if>
      </h3>
    </b:if>

    <div class='post-header'>
    <div class='post-header-line-1'/>
    </div>

    <!-- Then use the post body as the schema.org description, for good G+/FB snippeting. -->
    <div class='post-body entry-content' expr:id='"post-body-" + data:post.id' expr:itemprop='(data:blog.metaDescription ? "" : "description ") + "articleBody"'>
      <data:post.body/>
      <div style='clear: both;'/> <!-- clear for photos floats -->
    </div>

    <b:if cond='data:post.hasJumpLink'>
      <div class='jump-link'>
        <a expr:href='data:post.url + "#more"' expr:title='data:post.title'><data:post.jumpText/></a>
      </div>
    </b:if>

    <div class='post-footer'>
    <div class='post-footer-line post-footer-line-1'>
      <span class='post-author vcard'>
        <b:if cond='data:top.showAuthor'>
          <data:top.authorLabel/>
            <b:if cond='data:post.authorProfileUrl'>
              <span class='fn' itemprop='author' itemscope='itemscope' itemtype='http://schema.org/Person'>
                <meta expr:content='data:post.authorProfileUrl' itemprop='url'/>
                <a class='g-profile' expr:href='data:post.authorProfileUrl' rel='author' title='author profile'>
                  <span itemprop='name'><data:post.author/></span>
                </a>
              </span>
            <b:else/>
              <span class='fn' itemprop='author' itemscope='itemscope' itemtype='http://schema.org/Person'>
                <span itemprop='name'><data:post.author/></span>
              </span>
            </b:if>
        </b:if>
      </span>

      <span class='post-timestamp'>
        <b:if cond='data:top.showTimestamp'>
          <data:top.timestampLabel/>
          <b:if cond='data:post.url'>
            <meta expr:content='data:post.url.canonical' itemprop='url'/>
            <a class='timestamp-link' expr:href='data:post.url' rel='bookmark' title='permanent link'><abbr class='published' expr:title='data:post.timestampISO8601' itemprop='datePublished'><data:post.timestamp/></abbr></a>
          </b:if>
        </b:if>
      </span>

      <span class='reaction-buttons'>
        <b:if cond='data:top.showReactions'>
          <table border='0' cellpadding='0' cellspacing='0' width='100%'><tr>
            <td class='reactions-label-cell' nowrap='nowrap' valign='top' width='1%'>
              <span class='reactions-label'>
              <data:top.reactionsLabel/></span> </td>
            <td><iframe allowtransparency='true' class='reactions-iframe' expr:src='data:post.reactionsUrl' frameborder='0' name='reactions' scrolling='no'/></td>
           </tr></table>
        </b:if>
      </span>

      <span class='post-comment-link'>
        <b:include cond='data:blog.pageType not in {"item","static_page"}                          and data:post.allowComments' data='post' name='comment_count_picker'/>
      </span>

       <!-- backlinks -->
       <span class='post-backlinks post-comment-link'>
         <b:if cond='data:blog.pageType not in {"item","static_page"}                      and data:post.showBacklinks'>
           <a class='comment-link' expr:href='data:post.url + "#links"'><data:top.backlinkLabel/></a>
         </b:if>
       </span>

      <span class='post-icons'>
        <!-- email post links -->
        <b:if cond='data:post.emailPostUrl'>
          <span class='item-action'>
          <a expr:href='data:post.emailPostUrl' expr:title='data:top.emailPostMsg'>
            <img alt='' class='icon-action' height='13' src='https://resources.blogblog.com/img/icon18_email.gif' width='18'/>
          </a>
          </span>
        </b:if>

        <!-- quickedit pencil -->
        <b:include data='post' name='postQuickEdit'/>
      </span>

      <!-- share buttons -->
      <div class='post-share-buttons goog-inline-block'>
        <b:include cond='data:post.sharePostUrl' data='post' name='shareButtons'/>
      </div>

      </div>

      <div class='post-footer-line post-footer-line-2'>
      <span class='post-labels'>
        <b:if cond='data:top.showPostLabels and data:post.labels'>
          <data:postLabelsLabel/>
          <b:loop values='data:post.labels' var='label'>
            <a expr:href='data:label.url' rel='tag'><data:label.name/></a><b:if cond='not data:label.isLast'>,</b:if>
          </b:loop>
        </b:if>
      </span>
      </div>

      <div class='post-footer-line post-footer-line-3'>
      <span class='post-location'>
        <b:if cond='data:top.showLocation and data:post.location'>
          <data:postLocationLabel/>
          <a expr:href='data:post.location.mapsUrl' target='_blank'><data:post.location.name/></a>
        </b:if>
      </span>
      </div>
      <b:if cond='data:post.authorAboutMe'>
        <div class='author-profile' itemprop='author' itemscope='itemscope' itemtype='http://schema.org/Person'>
          <b:if cond='data:post.authorPhoto.url'>
            <img expr:src='data:post.authorPhoto.url' itemprop='image' width='50px'/>
          </b:if>
          <div>
            <a class='g-profile' expr:href='data:post.authorProfileUrl' itemprop='url' rel='author' title='author profile'>
              <span itemprop='name'><data:post.author/></span>
            </a>
          </div>
          <span itemprop='description'><data:post.authorAboutMe/></span>
        </div>
      </b:if>
    </div>
  </div>
</b:includable>
              <b:includable id='postQuickEdit' var='post'>
  <b:if cond='data:post.editUrl'>
    <span expr:class='"item-control " + data:post.adminClass'>
      <a expr:href='data:post.editUrl' expr:title='data:top.editPostMsg'>
        <img alt='' class='icon-action' height='18' src='https://resources.blogblog.com/img/icon18_edit_allbkg.gif' width='18'/>
      </a>
    </span>
  </b:if>
</b:includable>
              <b:includable id='shareButtons' var='post'>
  <b:if cond='data:top.showEmailButton'><a class='goog-inline-block share-button sb-email' expr:href='data:post.sharePostUrl + "&target=email"' expr:title='data:top.emailThisMsg' target='_blank'><span class='share-button-link-text'><data:top.emailThisMsg/></span></a></b:if><b:if cond='data:top.showBlogThisButton'><a class='goog-inline-block share-button sb-blog' expr:href='data:post.sharePostUrl + "&target=blog"' expr:onclick='"window.open(this.href, \"_blank\", \"height=270,width=475\"); return false;"' expr:title='data:top.blogThisMsg' target='_blank'><span class='share-button-link-text'><data:top.blogThisMsg/></span></a></b:if><b:if cond='data:top.showTwitterButton'><a class='goog-inline-block share-button sb-twitter' expr:href='data:post.sharePostUrl + "&target=twitter"' expr:title='data:top.shareToTwitterMsg' target='_blank'><span class='share-button-link-text'><data:top.shareToTwitterMsg/></span></a></b:if><b:if cond='data:top.showFacebookButton'><a class='goog-inline-block share-button sb-facebook' expr:href='data:post.sharePostUrl + "&target=facebook"' expr:onclick='"window.open(this.href, \"_blank\", \"height=430,width=640\"); return false;"' expr:title='data:top.shareToFacebookMsg' target='_blank'><span class='share-button-link-text'><data:top.shareToFacebookMsg/></span></a></b:if><b:if cond='data:top.showPinterestButton'><a class='goog-inline-block share-button sb-pinterest' expr:href='data:post.sharePostUrl + "&target=pinterest"' expr:title='data:top.shareToPinterestMsg' target='_blank'><span class='share-button-link-text'><data:top.shareToPinterestMsg/></span></a></b:if><b:if cond='data:top.showPlusOne'><div class='goog-inline-block google-plus-share-container'><data:post.googlePlusShareTag/></div></b:if>
</b:includable>
              <b:includable id='status-message'>
  <b:if cond='data:navMessage'>
  <div class='status-msg-wrap'>
    <div class='status-msg-body'>
      <data:navMessage/>
    </div>
    <div class='status-msg-border'>
      <div class='status-msg-bg'>
        <div class='status-msg-hidden'><data:navMessage/></div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
  <div style='clear: both;'/>
  </b:if>
</b:includable>
              <b:includable id='threaded-comment-form' var='post'>
  <div class='comment-form'>
    <a name='comment-form'/>
    <b:if cond='data:mobile'>
      <p><data:blogCommentMessage/></p>
      <data:blogTeamBlogMessage/>
      <a expr:href='data:post.commentFormIframeSrc' id='comment-editor-src'/>
      <iframe allowtransparency='true' class='blogger-iframe-colorize blogger-comment-from-post' expr:height='data:cmtIframeInitialHeight' frameborder='0' id='comment-editor' name='comment-editor' src='' style='display: none' width='100%'/>
    <b:else/>
      <p><data:blogCommentMessage/></p>
      <data:blogTeamBlogMessage/>
      <a expr:href='data:post.commentFormIframeSrc' id='comment-editor-src'/>
      <iframe allowtransparency='true' class='blogger-iframe-colorize blogger-comment-from-post' expr:height='data:cmtIframeInitialHeight' frameborder='0' id='comment-editor' name='comment-editor' src='' width='100%'/>
    </b:if>
    <data:post.cmtfpIframe/>
    <script type='text/javascript'>
      BLOG_CMT_createIframe('<data:post.appRpcRelayPath/>');
    </script>
  </div>
</b:includable>
              <b:includable id='threaded_comment_js' var='post'>
  <script async='async' expr:src='data:post.commentSrc' type='text/javascript'/>

  <script type='text/javascript'>
    (function() {
      var items = <data:post.commentJso/>;
      var msgs = <data:post.commentMsgs/>;
      var config = <data:post.commentConfig/>;

// <![CDATA[
      var cursor = null;
      if (items && items.length > 0) {
        cursor = parseInt(items[items.length - 1].timestamp) + 1;
      }

      var bodyFromEntry = function(entry) {
        var text = (entry &&
                    ((entry.content && entry.content.$t) ||
                     (entry.summary && entry.summary.$t))) ||
            '';
        if (entry && entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
          for (var k in entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
            if (entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].name == 'blogger.contentRemoved') {
              return '<span class="deleted-comment">' + text + '</span>';
            }
          }
        }
        return text;
      }

      var parse = function(data) {
        cursor = null;
        var comments = [];
        if (data && data.feed && data.feed.entry) {
          for (var i = 0, entry; entry = data.feed.entry[i]; i++) {
            var comment = {};
            // comment ID, parsed out of the original id format
            var id = /blog-(\d+).post-(\d+)/.exec(entry.id.$t);
            comment.id = id ? id[2] : null;
            comment.body = bodyFromEntry(entry);
            comment.timestamp = Date.parse(entry.published.$t) + '';
            if (entry.author && entry.author.constructor === Array) {
              var auth = entry.author[0];
              if (auth) {
                comment.author = {
                  name: (auth.name ? auth.name.$t : undefined),
                  profileUrl: (auth.uri ? auth.uri.$t : undefined),
                  avatarUrl: (auth.gd$image ? auth.gd$image.src : undefined)
                };
              }
            }
            if (entry.link) {
              if (entry.link[2]) {
                comment.link = comment.permalink = entry.link[2].href;
              }
              if (entry.link[3]) {
                var pid = /.*comments\/default\/(\d+)\?.*/.exec(entry.link[3].href);
                if (pid && pid[1]) {
                  comment.parentId = pid[1];
                }
              }
            }
            comment.deleteclass = 'item-control blog-admin';
            if (entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
              for (var k in entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
                if (entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].name == 'blogger.itemClass') {
                  comment.deleteclass += ' ' + entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].value;
                } else if (entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].name == 'blogger.displayTime') {
                  comment.displayTime = entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].value;
                }
              }
            }
            comments.push(comment);
          }
        }
        return comments;
      };

      var paginator = function(callback) {
        if (hasMore()) {
          var url = config.feed + '?alt=json&v=2&orderby=published&reverse=false&max-results=50';
          if (cursor) {
            url += '&published-min=' + new Date(cursor).toISOString();
          }
          window.bloggercomments = function(data) {
            var parsed = parse(data);
            cursor = parsed.length < 50 ? null
                : parseInt(parsed[parsed.length - 1].timestamp) + 1
            callback(parsed);
            window.bloggercomments = null;
          }
          url += '&callback=bloggercomments';
          var script = document.createElement('script');
          script.type = 'text/javascript';
          script.src = url;
          document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0].appendChild(script);
        }
      };
      var hasMore = function() {
        return !!cursor;
      };
      var getMeta = function(key, comment) {
        if ('iswriter' == key) {
          var matches = !!comment.author
              && comment.author.name == config.authorName
              && comment.author.profileUrl == config.authorUrl;
          return matches ? 'true' : '';
        } else if ('deletelink' == key) {
          return config.baseUri + '/delete-comment.g?blogID='
               + config.blogId + '&postID=' + comment.id;
        } else if ('deleteclass' == key) {
          return comment.deleteclass;
        }
        return '';
      };

      var replybox = null;
      var replyUrlParts = null;
      var replyParent = undefined;

      var onReply = function(commentId, domId) {
        if (replybox == null) {
          // lazily cache replybox, and adjust to suit this style:
          replybox = document.getElementById('comment-editor');
          if (replybox != null) {
            replybox.height = '250px';
            replybox.style.display = 'block';
            replyUrlParts = replybox.src.split('#');
          }
        }
        if (replybox && (commentId !== replyParent)) {
          replybox.src = '';
          document.getElementById(domId).insertBefore(replybox, null);
          replybox.src = replyUrlParts[0]
              + (commentId ? '&parentID=' + commentId : '')
              + '#' + replyUrlParts[1];
          replyParent = commentId;
        }
      };

      var hash = (window.location.hash || '#').substring(1);
      var startThread, targetComment;
      if (/^comment-form_/.test(hash)) {
        startThread = hash.substring('comment-form_'.length);
      } else if (/^c[0-9]+$/.test(hash)) {
        targetComment = hash.substring(1);
      }

      // Configure commenting API:
      var configJso = {
        'maxDepth': config.maxThreadDepth
      };
      var provider = {
        'id': config.postId,
        'data': items,
        'loadNext': paginator,
        'hasMore': hasMore,
        'getMeta': getMeta,
        'onReply': onReply,
        'rendered': true,
        'initComment': targetComment,
        'initReplyThread': startThread,
        'config': configJso,
        'messages': msgs
      };

      var render = function() {
        if (window.goog && window.goog.comments) {
          var holder = document.getElementById('comment-holder');
          window.goog.comments.render(holder, provider);
        }
      };

      // render now, or queue to render when library loads:
      if (window.goog && window.goog.comments) {
        render();
      } else {
        window.goog = window.goog || {};
        window.goog.comments = window.goog.comments || {};
        window.goog.comments.loadQueue = window.goog.comments.loadQueue || [];
        window.goog.comments.loadQueue.push(render);
      }
    })();
// ]]>
  </script>
</b:includable>
              <b:includable id='threaded_comments' var='post'>
  <div class='comments' id='comments'>
    <a name='comments'/>
    <h4><data:post.commentLabelFull/>:</h4>

    <div class='comments-content'>
      <b:include cond='data:post.embedCommentForm' data='post' name='threaded_comment_js'/>
      <div id='comment-holder'>
         <data:post.commentHtml/>
      </div>
    </div>

    <p class='comment-footer'>
      <b:if cond='data:post.allowNewComments'>
        <b:include data='post' name='threaded-comment-form'/>
      <b:else/>
        <data:post.noNewCommentsText/>
      </b:if>
    </p>

    <b:if cond='data:showCmtPopup'>
      <div id='comment-popup'>
        <iframe allowtransparency='true' frameborder='0' id='comment-actions' name='comment-actions' scrolling='no'>
        </iframe>
      </div>
    </b:if>

    <div id='backlinks-container'>
    <div expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_backlinks-container"'>
      <b:include cond='data:post.showBacklinks' data='post' name='backlinks'/>
    </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</b:includable>
            </b:widget>
          </b:section>
        </div>
        </div>

        <div class='column-left-outer'>
        <div class='column-left-inner'>
          <aside>
          <macro:include id='main-column-left-sections' name='sections'>
            <macro:param default='0' name='num'/>
            <macro:param default='sidebar-left' name='idPrefix'/>
            <macro:param default='sidebar' name='class'/>
            <macro:param default='true' name='includeBottom'/>
          </macro:include>
          </aside>
        </div>
        </div>

        <div class='column-right-outer'>
        <div class='column-right-inner'>
          <aside>
          <macro:include id='main-column-right-sections' name='sections'>
            <macro:param default='2' name='num'/>
            <macro:param default='sidebar-right' name='idPrefix'/>
            <macro:param default='sidebar' name='class'/>
            <macro:param default='true' name='includeBottom'/>
          </macro:include>
          </aside>
        </div>
        </div>

        </div>

        <div style='clear: both'/>
      <!-- columns -->
      </div>

    <!-- main -->
    </div>
    </div>
    <div class='main-cap-bottom cap-bottom'>
      <div class='cap-left'/>
      <div class='cap-right'/>
    </div>
    </div>

    <footer>
    <div class='footer-outer'>
    <div class='footer-cap-top cap-top'>
      <div class='cap-left'/>
      <div class='cap-right'/>
    </div>
    <div class='fauxborder-left footer-fauxborder-left'>
    <div class='fauxborder-right footer-fauxborder-right'/>
    <div class='region-inner footer-inner'>
      <macro:include id='footer-sections' name='sections'>
        <macro:param default='2' name='num'/>
        <macro:param default='footer' name='idPrefix'/>
        <macro:param default='foot' name='class'/>
        <macro:param default='false' name='includeBottom'/>
      </macro:include>
      <!-- outside of the include in order to lock Attribution widget -->
      <b:section class='foot' id='footer-3' name='Footer' showaddelement='no'>
        <b:widget id='Attribution1' locked='true' title='' type='Attribution'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='copyright'>© Cathal Murphy, 2009-2011</b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
    <div class='widget-content' style='text-align: center;'>
      <b:if cond='data:attribution != ""'>
       <data:attribution/>
      </b:if>
    </div>

    <b:include name='quickedit'/>
  </b:includable>
        </b:widget>
      </b:section>
    </div>
    </div>
    <div class='footer-cap-bottom cap-bottom'>
      <div class='cap-left'/>
      <div class='cap-right'/>
    </div>
    </div>
    </footer>

  <!-- content -->
  </div>
  </div>
  <div class='content-cap-bottom cap-bottom'>
    <div class='cap-left'/>
    <div class='cap-right'/>
  </div>
  </div>
  </div>

  <script type='text/javascript'>
    window.setTimeout(function() {
        document.body.className = document.body.className.replace('loading', '');
      }, 10);
  </script>
</body>

<macro:includable id='sections' var='col'>
  <macro:if cond='data:col.num == 0'>
  <macro:else/>
    <b:section mexpr:class='data:col.class' mexpr:id='data:col.idPrefix + "-1"' preferred='yes' showaddelement='yes'/>

    <macro:if cond='data:col.num >= 2'>
      <table border='0' cellpadding='0' cellspacing='0' mexpr:class='"section-columns columns-" + data:col.num'>
      <tbody>
      <tr>
        <td class='first columns-cell'>
          <b:section mexpr:class='data:col.class' mexpr:id='data:col.idPrefix + "-2-1"'/>
        </td>

        <td class='columns-cell'>
          <b:section mexpr:class='data:col.class' mexpr:id='data:col.idPrefix + "-2-2"'/>
        </td>

        <macro:if cond='data:col.num >= 3'>
          <td class='columns-cell'>
            <b:section mexpr:class='data:col.class' mexpr:id='data:col.idPrefix + "-2-3"'/>
          </td>
        </macro:if>

        <macro:if cond='data:col.num >= 4'>
          <td class='columns-cell'>
            <b:section mexpr:class='data:col.class' mexpr:id='data:col.idPrefix + "-2-4"'/>
          </td>
        </macro:if>
      </tr>
      </tbody>
      </table>

      <macro:if cond='data:col.includeBottom'>
        <b:section mexpr:class='data:col.class' mexpr:id='data:col.idPrefix + "-3"' showaddelement='no'/>
      </macro:if>
    </macro:if>
  </macro:if>
</macro:includable>

<b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-1'>
  <b:widget id='Profile1' locked='false' title='Me' type='Profile'>
    <b:widget-settings>
      <b:widget-setting name='showaboutme'>true</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showlocation'>true</b:widget-setting>
    </b:widget-settings>
    <b:includable id='main'>
    <b:if cond='data:title != ""'>
      <h2><data:title/></h2>
    </b:if>
    <div class='widget-content'>
    <b:if cond='data:team'> <!-- team blog profile -->
      <ul>
        <b:loop values='data:authors' var='i'>
          <li><a class='profile-name-link g-profile' expr:href='data:i.userUrl' expr:style='"background-image: url(" + data:i.profileLogo + ");"'><data:i.display-name/></a></li>
        </b:loop>
      </ul>

    <b:else/> <!-- normal blog profile -->

      <b:if cond='data:photo.url != ""'>
        <a expr:href='data:userUrl'><img class='profile-img' expr:alt='data:messages.myPhoto' expr:height='data:photo.height' expr:src='data:photo.url' expr:width='data:photo.width'/></a>
      </b:if>

      <dl class='profile-datablock'>
        <dt class='profile-data'>
          <a class='profile-name-link g-profile' expr:href='data:userUrl' expr:style='"background-image: url(" + data:profileLogo + ");"' rel='author'>
            <data:displayname/>
          </a>
          <b:if cond='data:hasgoogleprofile'>
            <br/>
            <div class='g-follow' data-annotation='bubble' data-height='20' expr:data-href='data:userUrl'/>
          </b:if>
        </dt>

        <b:if cond='data:showlocation'>
          <dd class='profile-data'><data:location/></dd>
        </b:if>

        <b:if cond='data:aboutme != ""'><dd class='profile-textblock'><data:aboutme/></dd></b:if>
      </dl>
      <a class='profile-link' expr:href='data:userUrl' rel='author'><data:viewProfileMsg/></a>
    </b:if>

     <b:include name='quickedit'/>
    </div>
  </b:includable>
  </b:widget>
</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-2-1'>
  <b:widget id='BlogList1' locked='false' title='Blogroll' type='BlogList'>
    <b:widget-settings>
      <b:widget-setting name='showItemThumbnail'>false</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='sortType'>ALPHABETICAL</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='numItemsToShow'>0</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showTimePeriodSinceLastUpdate'>false</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showIcon'>false</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showItemTitle'>false</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showItemSnippet'>false</b:widget-setting>
    </b:widget-settings>
    <b:includable id='main'>
    <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->
    <b:if cond='data:title != ""'>
      <h2 class='title'><data:title/></h2>
    </b:if>

    <div class='widget-content'>
      <div class='blog-list-container' expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_container"'>
        <ul expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_blogs"'>
          <b:loop values='data:items' var='item'>
            <li expr:style='data:item.displayStyle'>
              <div class='blog-icon'>
                <b:if cond='data:showIcon'>
                  <img expr:data-lateloadsrc='data:item.blogIconUrl' height='16' width='16'/>
                </b:if>
              </div>
              <div class='blog-content'>
                <div class='blog-title'>
                  <a expr:href='data:item.blogUrl' target='_blank'>
                    <data:item.blogTitle/></a>
                </div>
                <div class='item-content'>
                  <b:if cond='data:showItemThumbnail and data:item.itemThumbnail'>
                    <div class='item-thumbnail'>
                      <a expr:href='data:item.blogUrl' target='_blank'>
                        <img alt='' border='0' expr:height='data:item.itemThumbnail.height' expr:src='data:item.itemThumbnail.url' expr:width='data:item.itemThumbnail.width'/>
                      </a>
                    </div>
                  </b:if>
                  <b:if cond='data:showItemTitle'>
                    <span class='item-title'>
                      <b:tag cond='data:item.itemUrl != ""' expr:href='data:item.itemUrl' name='a' target='_blank'>
                        <data:item.itemTitle/>
                      </b:tag>
                    </span>
                  </b:if>
                  <b:if cond='data:showItemSnippet'>
                    <b:if cond='data:showItemTitle'>
                      -
                    </b:if>
                    <span class='item-snippet'>
                      <data:item.itemSnippet/>
                    </span>
                  </b:if>
                  <b:if cond='data:showTimePeriodSinceLastUpdate'>
                    <div class='item-time'>
                      <data:item.timePeriodSinceLastUpdate/>
                    </div>
                  </b:if>
                </div>
              </div>
              <div style='clear: both;'/>
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>

        <b:if cond='data:numItemsToShow != 0 and data:totalItems > data:numItemsToShow'>
          <div class='show-option'>
            <span expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_show-n"' style='display: none;'>
              <a href='javascript:void(0)' onclick='return false;'>
                <data:showNText/>
              </a>
            </span>
            <span expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_show-all"' style='margin-left: 5px;'>
              <a href='javascript:void(0)' onclick='return false;'>
                <data:showAllText/>
              </a>
            </span>
          </div>
        </b:if>

        <b:include name='quickedit'/>
      </div>
    </div>
  </b:includable>
  </b:widget>
</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-2-2'>
  <b:widget id='BlogArchive1' locked='false' title='The Archives' type='BlogArchive'>
    <b:widget-settings>
      <b:widget-setting name='showStyle'>HIERARCHY</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='yearPattern'>yyyy</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showWeekEnd'>true</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='monthPattern'>MMMM</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='dayPattern'>MMM dd</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='weekPattern'>MM/dd</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='chronological'>false</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showPosts'>true</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='frequency'>MONTHLY</b:widget-setting>
    </b:widget-settings>
    <b:includable id='main'>
  <b:if cond='data:title != ""'>
    <h2><data:title/></h2>
  </b:if>
  <div class='widget-content'>
  <div id='ArchiveList'>
  <div expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveList"'>
    <b:include cond='data:style == "HIERARCHY"' data='data' name='interval'/>
    <b:include cond='data:style == "FLAT"' data='data' name='flat'/>
    <b:include cond='data:style == "MENU"' data='data' name='menu'/>
  </div>
  </div>
  <b:include name='quickedit'/>
  </div>
</b:includable>
    <b:includable id='flat' var='data'>
  <ul class='flat'>
    <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
      <li class='archivedate'>
        <a expr:href='data:i.url'><data:i.name/></a> (<data:i.post-count/>)
      </li>
    </b:loop>
  </ul>
</b:includable>
    <b:includable id='interval' var='intervalData'>
  <b:loop values='data:intervalData' var='interval'>
    <ul class='hierarchy'>
      <li expr:class='"archivedate " + data:interval.expclass'>
        <b:include cond='data:interval.toggleId' data='interval' name='toggle'/>
        <a class='post-count-link' expr:href='data:interval.url'>
          <data:interval.name/>
        </a>
        <span class='post-count' dir='ltr'>(<data:interval.post-count/>)</span>
        <b:include cond='data:interval.data' data='interval.data' name='interval'/>
        <b:include cond='data:interval.posts' data='interval.posts' name='posts'/>
      </li>
    </ul>
  </b:loop>
</b:includable>
    <b:includable id='menu' var='data'>
  <select expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveMenu"'>
    <option value=''><data:title/></option>
    <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
      <option expr:value='data:i.url'><data:i.name/> (<data:i.post-count/>)</option>
    </b:loop>
  </select>
</b:includable>
    <b:includable id='posts' var='posts'>
  <ul class='posts'>
    <b:loop values='data:posts' var='post'>
      <li><a expr:href='data:post.url'><data:post.title/></a></li>
    </b:loop>
  </ul>
</b:includable>
    <b:includable id='toggle' var='interval'>
  <a class='toggle' href='javascript:void(0)'>
    <span expr:class='"zippy" + (data:interval.expclass == "expanded" ? " toggle-open" : "")'>
      <b:if cond='data:interval.expclass == "expanded"'>
        ▼ 
      <b:elseif cond='data:blog.languageDirection == "rtl"'/>
        ◄ 
      <b:else/>
        ► 
      </b:if>
    </span>
  </a>
</b:includable>
  </b:widget>
</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-3'>
  <b:widget id='Label1' locked='false' title='Tags' type='Label'>
    <b:widget-settings>
      <b:widget-setting name='sorting'>FREQUENCY</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='display'>CLOUD</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='selectedLabelsList'/>
      <b:widget-setting name='showType'>ALL</b:widget-setting>
      <b:widget-setting name='showFreqNumbers'>true</b:widget-setting>
    </b:widget-settings>
    <b:includable id='main'>
  <b:if cond='data:title != ""'>
    <h2><data:title/></h2>
  </b:if>
  <div expr:class='"widget-content " + data:display + "-label-widget-content"'>
    <b:if cond='data:display == "list"'>
      <ul>
        <b:loop values='data:labels' var='label'>
          <li>
            <b:if cond='data:blog.url == data:label.url'>
              <span expr:dir='data:blog.languageDirection'><data:label.name/></span>
            <b:else/>
              <a expr:dir='data:blog.languageDirection' expr:href='data:label.url'><data:label.name/></a>
            </b:if>
            <b:if cond='data:showFreqNumbers'>
              <span dir='ltr'>(<data:label.count/>)</span>
            </b:if>
          </li>
        </b:loop>
      </ul>
    <b:else/>
      <b:loop values='data:labels' var='label'>
        <span expr:class='"label-size label-size-" + data:label.cssSize'>
          <b:if cond='data:blog.url == data:label.url'>
            <span expr:dir='data:blog.languageDirection'><data:label.name/></span>
          <b:else/>
            <a expr:dir='data:blog.languageDirection' expr:href='data:label.url'><data:label.name/></a>
          </b:if>
          <b:if cond='data:showFreqNumbers'>
            <span class='label-count' dir='ltr'>(<data:label.count/>)</span>
          </b:if>
        </span>
      </b:loop>
    </b:if>
    <b:include name='quickedit'/>
  </div>
</b:includable>
  </b:widget>
</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='footer-1'/><b:section-contents id='footer-2-1'/><b:section-contents id='footer-2-2'/></html>

entry.title: Jordan, Shut Up and Jam
entry.content:
As some of you might know, for a while Frank has been developing (with help from Fitzy) the idea of a rock opera based around Space Jam, which I'm pretty sure everyone who reads this has seen. But if you haven't it's basically a film where Michael Jordan teams up with the Looney Tunes and then makes his comeback to the NBA. I watched the film last night, and before I get into the body of the post I have a few observations to make:

a) Marvin Martian is a really shitty referee, I mean he just flat out lets extreme physical aggression slide, I mean I've just finished re-watching it with Larney, and literally anything goes, which goes well for the whole physical comedy and The Monsters are Dicks part of the film, but I mean it's just flat out shitty refereeing. I'm also pretty sure the Looney Tunes have more than 5 players on the court at one point.

b) Shawn Bradley and Muggsy Bogues should have done a buddy comedy, but the golden opportunity has been missed.

c) This film seems completely okay with having Michael gambling and wagering up in.

d) Larry Bird and Bill Murray also should have done a buddy comedy.

e) This film would be better off it used some pre-established Looney Tunes characters as the villains, rather than Danny DeVito and those annoying small dudes, like say Marvin Martian and some bros of his. They have the added bonus of having those bad-ass hats, and being well-known, so it becomes more iconic.

f) One more thing, at the start of the film Jordan's son gets out of the car, and seems depressed. Jordan asks "you ok?" and the son shakes his head. THIS IS NEVER MENTIONED AGAIN. This could have made for some grimdark subplot about fatherhood or depression in children, but hey what everyone really wants is the Monstars.

But to the rock opera, so I watched through the film, and realised that Space Jam has great potential for a truly brilliant musical. It has room for some great themes, like ambition, the greater good, the nature of talent, and gambling addiction. So basically in this post I'm just write up the really preliminary tracklist and for a couple of tracks a short plot note. I'm going to be watching through most of the Looney Tunes shorts up to the 60s over the next few months, so some things will probably be changing as I learn more.

  1. Ladies & Gentlemen, Michael Jordan: This track (which plays as if being performed by a busker, relating a legend or forgotten folk tale) introduces the character of Michael Jordan, World's Greatest Basketball Player. Starting from his sophomore year of high school, where is rejected for the varsity team due to being 5'11", this song tracks his meteoric rise to global icon, and ends with the death of his father and his retirement from basketball to pursue a career in baseball.
  2. We Need Something Looney: This track introduces the villains of the piece (right now the Martians, which will mean some War of the Worlds references being thrown in, but for this post they'll resemble the Nerdlucks more than the Martians). The Mars theme park, which represents the backbone of their economy, and main source of employment, is struggling. The boss, Marvin, decides what they need is new attractions, and while thinking out loud, accidentally sits on TV remote, and his underlings see, on several screens, some old Merrie Melodies cartoons. This song then describes their reaction to seeing the classic cartoons, and after Marvin witnesses it, he agrees that they need something looney.
  3. How to Capture a Cartoon Character: The Martians arrive in Looney Tune Land, and declare that the Looney Tunes are their prisoners. At first the Looney Tunes find this hilarious, but when the Martians brandish their high-tech weapons, only Bugs Bunny's quick thinking allows them a chance to defend themselves. After talking about the Martians, the Looney Tunes decide that basketball is the perfect way out.
  4. You Can't Teach That (Don't Swing): The story shifts back to Michael Jordan, now at the Double-A Birmingham Barons. Even though his batting average is just above the Mendoza Line, everyone still treats him like a star, which makes him uneasy. After striking out for the 3rd time in a game against the Hunstville Stars, Michael has a solo, where he debates the reasons he retired and entered baseball with himself, and wonders if he has truly made the right decision. He considers returning to the NBA, but opts against it, reasoning that quitting because it got too tough is not becoming of the Greatest of All Time, and would set a bad example for his oldest son, who is making a name for himself in local Little League.
  5. The Best Players in the World: While trying to improve their wack game, the Martians discover the NBA through an instructional film. They set off to find the "Best Players in the World" to even the playing field. They, one at a time, briefly describe the things they will do with the talent they plan to steal.
  6. You Heard of the Dream Team?: The Martians successfully steal the talent of Muggsy Bogues, Larry Johnson, Patrick Ewing, Charles Barkley, and Shawn Bradley. They don't realise they have 2 centers and no shooting guard. They show off their talent after the Looney Tunes mock their height. The Looney Tunes panic, and decide they desperately need help to avoid slavery. Michael hears about what has happened to the players on the news, and decides that he was right to retire.
  7. I'm a Baseball Player Now: The Looney Tunes decide they need to pull out the big guns. After being turned down by LeBron James in an hour long press conference, they decide they need one of the retired greats. They kidnap Michael Jordan on a golf course, and tell him what they face if he does not help them. He laments that although he would love nothing more than to shoot hoops again, he has left that life behind. But after being confronted and mocked by the transformed Martians, he decides to play.
  8. Fly Like an Eagle: Michael kits up, and at first is worried that his game will have deteriorated in his time away. However, once he picks up the ball and starts playing, it is clear that is not the case. He sings of the pure unadulterated joy he feels when he jumps toward a hoop, ball in hand, and contrasts it to his struggles in baseball. He curses himself for squandering such a gift during some of the prime years of his life, and decides that once he returns to the real world he will re-sign with the Bulls.
  9. You're Not Charles Barkley: Michael's rediscovery of his talent is contrasted with the fates of the players who have had their talent stolen. It opens with Charles Barkley being called a wannabe by a group of young girls after they outplay him. This song describes the treatment of the 5 players both in hospital and in the world at large. They ruminate on how they are no longer seen as themselves, but as imitators of who they once were. They begin to adjust to life, but feel frustrated in their new jobs when customers "mistake" them for famous basketball players. They all feel they should have retired in their prime, before they became shadows of the greats they once were.
  10. You'll Always Lose: (Duet) Having heard word that the Looney Tunes have a secret weapon, Marvin waits outside their training facility to confront Michael. After seeing for himself that the rumours are true, Marvin decides he must be stopped, for if they do not have the Looney Tunes, their theme park, and by extension, the entire Martian economy, will fail. Michael meets Marvin after staying late, and Marvin tries to provoke him, calling him washed-up, and referring to him as The Baseball Player, but Michael is unfazed. Marvin then describes what he has planned for the Looney Tunes, and asks Michael why is he going back on his own word to help them, and hints that Michael is really just looking for an excuse to quit on baseball, and go back to basketball, a safe environment. He tells Michael that he is bound to lose, because his team has stolen the talent of the NBA players. Michael replies that he will always look out for his friends, and offers to raise the wager. If the Looney Tunes win, Marvin will return the NBA talent, but if they lose, Marvin will have Michael as his new attraction. He tells Michael that he will have him play one-on-one all day, and that it will be rigged so he'll always lose. Although secretly this horrifies Michael, he presses ahead and finalises the new wager.
  11. No More Basketball: After players all across the country refuse to play because of what happened to the 5, David Stern announces the current basketball season is cancelled. Watching it on the news, the 5 curse themselves for destroying professional basketball.
  12. Let's Have Some Fun: Michael has not told the Looney Tunes about the talent-stealing, since he knows it will demoralise them. He sings about they have formed a bond, and he could not live with himself if he lets them down. He gives them a pep talk, and assures them this is a game they can win. He tells them to just go out and have fun, which he says is something he never did in his last few years in the NBA.
  13. The Ultimate Game (Part I of II): This song describes the first half of the "Ultimate" game between the Martians and the Looney Tunes. At first they are resoudingly beaten, and the ref (on Martian payroll) routinely ignores blatant fouls. Even Michael struggles, as he is routinely triple-teamed by the Martians, who seem too fast and skilled to stop. Despondent, and trailing 66-18, the Looney Tunes head for the locker room at half-time.
  14. I Know We're Down (We Can Still Win): In the locker room, Michael tries and fails to rouse the Looney Tunes, and accidentally lets slip that the Martians stole NBA talent. Angered that Michael did not tell them this important bit of information, and feeling that they have no hope of coming back from a 48-point deficit against 5 all-stars, they suggest they forfeit. Michael snaps, and sings at the top of his voice that he was not dragged here just to have them quit on him, and tells them that he has put his own life on the line to return their freedom and the talent of his friends. He explains that someone should never quit, even if the odds seem insurmountable. After a pause, he tells them the problem has been they've been playing average basketball, which the Martians are doing better. To win, he says, they'll need to play more "Looney" basketball.
  15. The Ultimate Game (Part II of II): The Looney Tunes play "looney" basketball, and it seems to be working. They frustrate the Martians at every turn, and narrow the score to 109-108 when, with 23 seconds to go, Marvin calls a timeout.
  16. No Sweat (This is Looney Tune Land): Michael is anxious, and worries that putting himself on the line may have been a futile, pointless gesture. Marvin comes over and offers him one last chance to pull out, all he has to do is forfeit the game. Although the Looney Tunes tell him it is the right thing to do, he refuses, and reiterates that he does not quit on his friends. Michael then discusses a strategy with Bugs and Daffy, but they explain how, in Looney Tune Land, anything is possible. Outraged, Marvin returns to his team, and tells them to "crush 'em".
  17. Fly Like an Eagle (Part II): The first play after resuming goes badly for the Looney Tunes, and 2 of their players are injured. However, thanks to a lucky touch, Michael gets the ball, and decides to take it to the hole. However, with 7 seconds left he is only at half-court, and deciding that he has nothing to lose, goes to dunk. Accompanied by soaring strings, the song describes how Michael jumps from half-court, and when the Martians try to drag him down, he stretches his hand to an incredible length to dunk the ball just before the buzzer. The Looney Tunes have won, and there is much rejoicing. The Martians then return the talent.
  18. I Caught It (Raw Talent): Michael returns to the real world, and finds the 5 all-stars in a gym, trying and failing to shoot from the field. They notice Michael, and he jokes about their horrible game. They tell him how hard it has been for them without talent, and he offers to return it to them. After some hesitation, they agree to touch the talent-ball, and when he throws the now empty ball to Muggsy, he catches it, and joyously dribbles. The players then challenge Michael to a 3-on-3, and he says he's done with that. They suggest that he refuses the challenge because he's lost his touch, and he says that there's only one way to find out.
  19. That's All Folks: The first part of the song describes Michael's triumphant return to the NBA, where, in a charity 3-on-3 exhibition, he goes shot for shot with the best players in the NBA. They, in chorus, tell of how the court is their home, and how they find the purest joy in playing basketball. The story ends with Michael going to the hole, and there is then a rollcall, which has a melody borrowed from the classic Merrie Melodies tune.

That's about it, I mean it's a first draft, so I'll be changing a lot of stuff, but it's a good idea, and hopefully with some work and writing we can get it to where it needs to be. Also if you have any titles tell Frank, because I don't think Space Jam: The Rock Opera can be used.

Shut up and jam,
Cathal

entry.title: Recovery
entry.content:
Recovery is officially out now, so I'm gonna talk about it without fear of legal repercussions (on that note, I should probably delete my short-lived mp3 blog) and Anderson asked me about it today so here's my Impressions of Recovery.

I just don't give a fuck.

It's really hard to give a fuck about Recovery, everyone I know except Darver, Corey, and Mully has knotted over it, but I think I've listen to it maybe one and a half times since I downloaded it; Relapse got 3 times as much play at least. The marketing campaign was a lot less embarrassing this time, there wasn't any Teabagging with Bruno, just the usual routine of freestyles and talk show appearances and interviews. Em obviously realised Relapse is what nobody wanted, even though on paper an Eminem album produced entirely by Dre wasn't a bad idea, jokes about drug addiction and rape aren't gonna play in an era where Drake is taken seriously by heads. I thought it was like a 4/10, but there were 2 songs on it, Deja Vu, and Beautiful, which were mind-blowing, both flow- and rhymes-wise, and they hinted that Eminem had in him an incredible concept album about addiction and rehab and all the attendant concepts of AA. Turns out, he didn't.

Originally there was gonna be a Relapse 2, there was even a Refill EP released to stoke interest (it was pretty good, 7.5/10), the rapping was great, and it had Forever, where Eminem shows up Drake, and Kanye, and Lil Wayne, who are all somehow GOAT candidates, and a great song with Dre, Hell Breaks Loose, which rivals Old Times Sake, my 3rd favourite song on Relapse. Hell, even the comical lead single was tight, unlike We Made You, which was embarrassing.

But then about Relapse 2, Em announces that he's been working with Just Blaze, who was on the way back up thanks to his work with Jay Elec, and I was getting excited again, and also Alchemist was gonna have beats on an Em album at long last. He promised PARENTAL ADVISORY: EXTREMELY HONEST CONTENT, and it actually sounded like a good idea, but then around mid-Spring, after a while in the dark, new shit came to light. It kinda went like this...

"Boi-1da's gonna produce shit for this", "Jim Jonsin will produce the lead single", "(feat. Lil Wayne)", and I realised what had happened. Although he talks about how he doesn't want MMLP levels of fame, and is just in it for the rapping, this was gonna be album with crazy commercial considerations, even though he still had enough cred that he could do 808s & Heartbreak numbers with an album produced by Oktopus. It was depressing to see Eminem working with the likes of Boi-1da and Jim Jonsin, when ten years ago he was working with Da Beatminerz and Thirstin Howl III.

Anyway, the actual album. I knew I wouldn't feel it from the moment I heard "Not Afraid", which is some terrible motivational speaker bullshit. The whole album is a mix of that and club jams, and some terrible love songs thrown in (Eminem doesn't do these very well), and also a mid-tier H.E.R. song (25 to Life) which has a great chorus, and isn't too bad, but pales in comparison to the inspiration. Of the other songs, only Going Through Changes has any significant replay value, and the whole thing is just completely forgettable. I mean there isn't that much to be wrote about how the producers phone in their signature styles, or how the guest spots are poorly chosen, or how Eminem has lost a few steps from even a few months ago. There are 2 good things I'll say about it:

a) Eminem's finally abandoned The Template LP, there's no I Still Don't Give a Fuck, no The Real Slim Shady, no Dr. Dre guest spot, maybe when he adjusts better to making a full record away from this template, it'll improve, but I'm not mad optimistic.

b) No skits, no Berman, no Ken Kaniff, no Paul Rosenberg. I'mokwiththis.

Eminem's stuff between 98-02 is some of the best rapping ever done, it had everything, he had no limits. Eminem's stuff since his comeback has been tired, forced, and unfunny, where previously even his SRS stuff had a touch of black comedy about them.

It was still better than Rakim's comeback,
Cathal

entry.title: a short story whoa check it out
entry.content:
The night, as it happens, goes far better than you expected or maybe even hoped from the part of your brain that deals in unrealistic fantasies. And the time you spend together, at that table, gives new meanings to actions and glances that have taken place over the last five months. You can’t remember being happier or ever feeling more like you belong than at that table with her.

At breakfast, she kisses your cheek in a way that just about drives you wild, and straight afterward you share what could be called a “holy moment”, just looking at each other. On the bus home, she falls near-asleep, and you have to hold her to stop her unwillingly falling off the seat, you feel, when the bus makes a particularly sharp or sudden turn. When you both disembark, she feels strongly enough to use the public restroom across the street. It falls upon Shauna to take her over and check for any like bad things, while you sit beside a statue of a Revolutionary you’ve never heard of. Anyway, she returns and she complains about her shoes, which you say - Yeah I can imagine - and there’s a like very comfortable silence, then you tune into the conversations of people across the road, and then that’s broken by some very friendly banter between you and her and the other 6 people there. You don’t feel tired, it’s probably worth noting.

So after everyone else has finalised their plans for return home, she asks you if you’d mind bumming around town for a while are the exact words she uses. You say sure you haven’t really made any other plans for that morning and perhaps a more substantial breakfast could be gotten somewhere. Anyway so you walk off with her, arms around her, the way you’ve seen men put their arm around Their Woman in so many of the movies you’ve seen, in the direction of every place that you could conceivably get breakfast from. Conveniently, all these places go along one stretch of road, but as it turns out, as you pass each, none open ‘til half eight at the earliest, and the time on your watch currently reading seven-thirty, and thus waiting outside anywhere is really implausible, because she needs to sit down and get to not be conscious of her feet for just a second.

Anyway, you end up stopping outside of the press office, and you just stand there for a while. She takes off her shoes, and the appearance of her feet is serene, not in keeping with the pain she’s been describing. They aren’t visibly scarred or blistered or dry, they appear exactly like you imagine feet should. Anyway she does appear visibly discomforted, the way she keeps shifting weight from one foot to the other. She’s standing directly beside a grille, and she’s resting against the glass store-front, which is filled with recent clippings and advertisements for the paper, with the distinctive red typeface and headline fonts, which in your mind will always signify Wednesday. Her dress is purple and knee-length, and quite simply stunning. This was actually the first thing you said to her yesterday, when she arrived at your door, and you stood there, assuming a pose of calm you had rehearsed beforehand. She had, over the course of the night, asked you several times - Do I look alright - and every time you had replied with a riff on the line - You look stunning - although you aren’t sure if she believed you. She’s good people, my mother told me the first time my mother met her, - She’s good people, you can tell.

Anyway, you keep goin’ on to the McDonalds which you’ve both agreed is likely to be serving breakfast at this time, seven-forty-five by your watch. Your arm’s been around her this whole time, and you have to walk a lot slower than you normally would, and you’re holding her shoes in your left hand. You see familiar faces, and you exchange pleasantries with them without stopping.

Directly before you first kiss, a friend takes you aside, expresses disappointment but also and this is the thing that sticks, says - If you want something, you just have to go for it - and the way this seems just so damn relevant to what’s going on, you don’t normally go in for the fate thing, but this is probably the thing that starts it. But the big thing, the thing that surprises you about kissing her, is the complete subsiding of your normal unbearable self-consciousness for that moment.
But back to the morning. You’re actually really impressed with the grace she has while crossing the gravelled road in bare feet, something that you’ve never been able to do, even as a child with a lower-than-average awareness of pain, and you position yourself on a wall that has a brick lying beside it. Anyway, she starts hiccupping at this point, and this hiccupping on her account has been going on and off for a week, so it is, for her, extremely frustrating, she in fact expressed a concern that her hiccups had ruined the night, and you had to re-assure her that just wasn’t true, and as you ring your father to go home and also give her a way home, she leans against you and cries quietly, due to frustration at her inability to control this thing. This isn’t the first time she’s cried in front of you, and you secretly feel validated, as she’s told you she’s never cried in front of anyone else, in fact going out of her way to isolate herself from her family whenever she did cry, but the other time is the first time you felt connected to anyone, when you stayed up with her until three a.m., just listening to her cry, being there with her, after her uncle died.

And so you both sit on the wall, your head against her shoulder, you holding her, motorists seeing you both and inventing a back story as to how you both ended up in that position.

She’s wearing your jacket too, has been for some time, and you’re aware that this another cliché, but that it doesn’t bother you, and ditto that you’re cold. Anyway, you’re father takes you both to her house, and she gives you back your jacket, and you both get out and walk up to her front door, and you hold her, briefly, not knowing this is the last time you’ll ever speak to her.

entry.title: water footprint
entry.content:
Abstract
Background: As global population continues to increase and developing countries develop, increased importance is placed on the division of water for various important uses. By comparing the water footprint and net virtual water import/export of a developed country with an arid climate with that of a developing nation with a similar climate, it is hoped insight can be gained into water resource management, what a water footprint reveals about a nation’s situation, and how increasing globalization impacts upon developing nations and their water usage and supply. The history, development, methods, and implications of the Virtual Water and Water Footprint concepts are also explored and discussed, so as to give a background for the analysis and comparison.
Result: Spain and Morocco are found to have much in common in terms of climate, but it is found that, through examination of available data, that they differ in key areas, which indicate differences in economic standing. Attention is focused primarily on agricultural water use, due to a lack of available detailed information about the Moroccan industrial sector, and also because there are interesting contrasts in Spanish and Moroccan agricultural sectors, particularly in currency value/water usage ratios, and through-trade.
Conclusion: Although they are at different stages of economic development, Spain and Morocco face similar problems with regards to water scarcity. An analysis of their agricultural sectors reveals that by changing their primary crops to less water-intensive crops, and importing things such as cereals, with high virtual-water content, might allow them to alleviate this problem.

Distilled down to its most basic and primitive form, the concept of the Water Footprint is a means of measuring and expressing both the direct and indirect water use of a country, a consumer, or a producer. This essay will mainly strive to explain the differences in the water footprints of developed and developing nations, and will touch on other areas related to this, including: a brief history and explanation of the Water Footprint concept, along with both its basic function and the concept of “virtual water”; also, outside of outlining the differences in the water footprints of nations, I will also examine the usefulness of these figures as economic and environmental indicators, before finishing with an examination of the criticism and limitations of the water footprint concept.
Introduced by Arjen Hoekstra in the early 2000s (Hoekstra and Hung, 2002), the Water Footprint concept was inspired by the similar Footprint concepts introduced around the same time, mainly the ecological footprint (Rees, 1992, p. 121-130). The water footprint is an alternative indicator of water use, and an application of the concept of Virtual Water (coined by John Anthony Allan in 1993), which is the water used in the manufacture and transport of a good or service (e.g., a one litre bottle of water has a virtual water content of nine litres, the amount consumed in its making). After its initial introduction, it was further refined by Hoekstra, and his colleagues at the UNESCO-IHE, with a 2004 UNESCO report, Water Footprint of Nations, outlining the most elaborate means of accounting water footprint. One of the main components of this is the concept of different categories of water: White, meaning potable; Grey, meaning water that been degraded; and finally black, meaning sewage or effluent, water completely unfit for human consumption, and potentially lethal. There are also two categories of water usage: blue, representing water for drinking; and green, meaning water intended for irrigation.
With the increased demand for water, these concepts are now incredibly useful for water resource management. Although there is, in theory, 26 times more water per person on this planet (the average runoff (i.e., rainfall that doesn’t evaporate) is 53 cubic metres per day per person, but the average amount used is 2 cubic metres per day per person.), water is still a huge international problem. Countries with less than 500 cubic metres/year/person are judged to have a scarcity of water (Drew, 2010). Even in developed countries like China or the United States of America, there can be huge discrepancies in runoff and water supply between regions, in spite of the use of modern, cutting-edge irrigation (Saeger, 2009). These regional discrepancies in United States and other countries, have always existed, and accompanying disputes over water, e.g., the Hetch-Hetchy dispute of the 1900s (Righter, 2005) have been a constant part of the political landscape, but in recent years, and gradually over the 20th century, population in the water-scarce areas has increased both in real terms and as a proportion of the general population (US Census Bureau, various). When taken in concert with the increasing globalization of water (Jordan, for example, a relatively affluent middle-eastern state, imports 7 times more water than it uses from domestic sources (Yorke, 2009)), this could have major ramifications for the world, and in the coming years water resource management will become increasingly important for society, and it has been agreed by experts that most water crises and conflicts result not from actual, physical scarcity but from poor management of resources (Aldaya et al., 2008).
Historically, water shortages were viewed as a local problem, their scope extending no further than the applicable river basin, and, historically, this may have been the case. However, with the advent of globalization it is no longer the case, with it being possible for people in one country to affect the water system in another far-off nation, through a variety of ways. A perfect example is the Chernobyl disaster in Ukraine in the mid-1980s. It had a devastating impact on the surrounding area (Smith, 2005) , but this nuclear accident in Eastern Europe also had far-reaching effects globally, and a study published in Nature (Smith, et al, 2000) demonstrated it had affected water and fish as far away as Scandinavia and the United Kingdom.
The main goal of this essay is to take two countries, one developed, one developing, and analyse and compare their water footprints. For this, I have chosen two neighbouring countries, separated by only thirteen kilometres of the Mediterranean Sea: Spain, and Morocco.
When examining the water usage of a country, there are three categories that have traditionally been used: Domestic, Agricultural, and Industrial. Although adding these together can give a general impression of a country’s water usage and demand, but as explained earlier with the concept of Virtual Water, in the era of globalization, not only is much of the water consumed used to make products and services that will be exported, but many of the goods used by consumers will originate from foreign countries (Hoekstra and Champaign, 2008). Thus examining the water footprint of a given country involves not only measuring consumption of water for domestic and agricultural use, but also taking into account the virtual water value of goods that are both imported and exported.
Spain makes, in the words of Alberto Garrido and his colleagues, an “ideal case study for an in-depth analysis of virtual water and water footprint”, and was the first to utilize water footprint analysis as a key component of government policy. A developed nation, Spain is also by far the most arid in the European Union, and water resource management is crucial for its continued prosperity. It has one of the largest water footprints in the world, and its arid climate presents a major challenge in water resource management, and analysis of the Spanish situation and resulting response can afford insight into the formation and application of water policy, especially for similarly arid nations, and much can be learned about facilitating efficient use of water. Despite the arid climate, Spain has a far smaller water import dependency than neighbouring E.U. countries, although it is twice as high as Morocco’s (Spain’s figure stands at 36%, Morocco’s at 15%, while Italy, Germany, and Portugal all have a water import dependency above 50% (Water Footprint Network, 1997-2001).
However, in agriculture, Spain is a net importer of virtual water, and its agriculture consists primarily of crops with high, intensive blue-water demand and relatively low yield, but with livestock, it is a net water exporter. For Spain, the recent trend is for the majority of water consumption to be “blue”, rather than “green”, and the proportion of blue usage has grown over time. In 1997, 51% of water consumption was for “blue” purposes, but by 2005, that percentage had grown to 75% (Garrido, et. al, 2008). In the same study just referenced, Garrido and company propose that water productivity is dependent on two main factors: the ratio of blue/green water usage, and water scarcity. Generally, Spain’s water footprint has risen and fallen consistently with levels of agricultural water use, as industrial and urban water footprints have remained remarkably steady.
On the surface, the situations and water footprints of Morocco and Spain appear to have much in common. Both are arid countries on the periphery of their continents, and both are, agriculturally at least, net water importers, with Morocco importing, over the timeframe 1997-2001, 6.3 billion cubic meters of water a year (mostly in the form of food and agricultural commodities), compared to a water export of 1.6 billion cubic meters a year. Nearly half of this figure resulted from cereal imports, which account for 3.0 billion cubic meters of that figure, with an additional 1.7 billion cubic meters resulting from the import of oil crops (Hoekstra and Champaign, 2008). In Morocco, water is a scarce commodity, and given that, it makes sense that the export figure would be so low, as most water would go towards feeding people within Morocco, with only about 4% of total agricultural water use in Morocco going towards products for export. By contrast, Spain, although it’s agricultural water imports greatly exceed its exports, uses just over a quarter of its agricultural water for export crops (Garrido, et al, 2008); from an economic standpoint, it might be interesting to find out how high the yield per unit of water used is for these exported crops. I was able to find currency/unit water values for crops in Spain (Garrido, et al, 2008), but was unable to find out what proportion of each crop was exported, and whether the exports had a significantly different value than had they been sold within Spain. Industrial crops had a very low value (less than €.5/cubic meter), while the value for vineyards were 8 times higher, with olives staying consistent around €1/cubic meter.
From The Globalization of Water (Hoekstra and Champaign, 2008), we can see that Morocco’s main crop exports are oil crops and fruit, which, by the Spanish values, have a relatively high currency/unit value. A large proportion of their exports are in the form of cereal exports to Libya. Cereals are water-intensive crops, so one might question the wisdom of such farming, especially given Morocco’s scarce water supply. In Spain, however, the Andalusian region in the south is the main contributor of exports. Andalusia’s main crops are cereals and olives (Junta de Andalucía, 2008), and recently there has been large growth in organic farming. Given the reputation of Spanish olive oil, as well as the premium placed upon organically farmed products, one can assume that Andalusian exports have a high currency/unit value.
Also, unlike Morocco, Spain has a much larger through-trade, meaning imported products which are in turn exported again. This means a large proportion (the virtual water value for export of imported products is about 66% of that for export of domestic crops) of Spain’s virtual water export actually originates from outside the country, whereas for Morocco, this number is negligible. This difference is evident of the great economic divide between a developed and a developing nation. While both nations have large per capita water footprints (Morocco’s is 1,477 cubic meters/year, while Spain’s is 2,000) and indeed Morocco’s per capita water footprint is twice as large as that of the Netherlands, examining the nature of their net import/export of virtual water, and their agricultural footprint, speaks volumes about their differences. Despite their similar climates and crop portfolios, it is clear that they are on completely different economic terms. The most telling figure, of these, is the proportion of virtual water export that originates from foreign nations. While Spain’s figure is quite high, especially considering their booming industry in low water-intensity, high-value crops such as citrus fruits and grapes, Morocco’s is tiny, and practically non-existent, due to the evaporative demand of the arid climate, and also Morocco’s low agricultural yield: Moroccan crops have massive water demands: while European maize can have a virtual water content as low as 400 cubic meters/ton, Moroccan maize has a virtual water content of 12,600 cubic meters/ton, while Spanish virtual water content is more in line with global averages (Novo, et al, 2008).
Although they are both at different stages of economic development, however, Spain and Morocco are both faced with water scarcity, and in the coming years, they will tackle similar water problems, and they will both need to find a more efficient way to allocate water resources, and come up with real water savings; in Spain’s case, to maintain their position as an economic power; in Morocco’s case, to continue their economic development. Morocco would benefit from re-focusing its agricultural sector on crops with low water-demands, and then importing the high virtual-water content crops, like maize, from temperate countries where the virtual water content of these crops is lower. Spain, too, can benefit from a similar policy, focusing more of its agricultural water on low-demand, high-yield crops, and importing high-demand, low-yield crops, which currently account for 60% of all blue water use in Spain, while only accounting for 5% of agricultural Gross Value Added (Hoekstra and Champaign, 2008). These allocations of water are grossly inefficient, and especially troubling for arid countries with water scarcity such as Morocco and Spain. However, through increased international trade, and a better, more efficient apportionment of water for agricultural use, they can easily face these problems.

Cathal Murphy, 2011
References
Hoekstra, A.Y., and P.Q. Hung, (September 2002). Virtual water trade: A quantification of virtual water flows between nations in relation to international crop trade
Rees, W.E., (October 1992). "Ecological footprints and appropriated carrying capacity: what urban economics leaves out", Environment and Urbanisation 4 (2): 121–130.

Drew, D., (October 2010). Water Resources and the Hydrological Cycle, Trinity College Dublin. [Internet] Available here
Saeger, R., Tzanova, A., and Nakamura, J., (April 2009). Drought in the Southeastern United States: Causes, Variability over the last millennium, and potential for future hydroclimate change. Columbia University, New York.
Righter, R.W., (2005). The Battle over Hetch Hetchy: America's Most Controversial Dam and the Birth of Modern Environmentalism. Oxford University Press
U.S. Census Bureau, (Various) [Internet] Available here
Yorke, V., (2009) Jordan Water Scarcity, Strategy, and Alternative Solutions, National Centre for Competence in Research – Trade Regulation
Aldaya, M.M., Garrido, A., Llamas, M.R., Varela-Ortega, C., Novo, P. and Rodríguez Casado, R. (2008) “The water footprint of Spain”, Journal on Sustainable Water Management, 2008-3
Smith, J., (2005) Chernobyl: Catastrophe and Consequences. Springer Books
Smith, J.T., Comans, R.N.J., Beresford, N.A., Wright, S.M., Howard, B.J., and Camplin, W.C., (2000) Pollution: Chernobyl's Legacy in Food and Water, Nature 405, 141
Hoekstra, A.Y., and Champaign, A.K., (2008) The Globalization of Water: Sharing the Planet's Freshwater Resources, Oxford: Wiley-Blackwell
Garrido, A., Llamas, M.R., Varela-Ortega, C., Novo, P., Rodriguez Casado, R., Aldaya, M.M., (2008), Water Footprint and Virtual Water Trade: Policy Implications, Madrid: Fundacion Marcelino Botin
Novo, P., Garrido, A., Llamas, M.R., Varela-Ortega, C., (2008) Are virtual water "flows" in Spanish grain trade consistent with relative water scarcity?, Papeles de Agua Virtual, 1, Madrid: Fundación Marcelino Botín
Junta de Andalucía (2008) Impacto de la ayuda a la producción sobre el olivar andaluz, Available Here

entry.title: Broken Beta
entry.content:
This piece is reposted verbatim from my Tumblr, Harden's Beard.
Welp. The Uncharted 3 beta is fucked. When I try to play it, it tells me it needs to update, then restarts my console. I’m not really excited about it though. I find it hard to really get any feelings going about the Uncharted series. Uncharted 2 was decent, but the game I played was far removed from the one described to me in reviews both professional and amateur. The action sequences were intense, yes (and the cold open (heh, pun) was a beautiful thing), but Nathan Drake himself was so… offputting. Part of this problem comes from the nature of the game itself (Drake’s “revelations” are triggered by your position on the map, rather than the position of your camera), but also the dialogue. Nathan Drake is a smug prick. He’s not as bad as his carbon copy, Inept Villain Sidekick (whoops spoilers although if you’re reading this you’ve either finished Uncharted 2 or are never going to play it) though. The only likeable character in the entire game is the love interest, who seems to have been taken from a better game with better writing. Everyone else is ctrl+v’d from Indiana Jones or one of the rip-offs of same.
Uncharted 2 was such a relatively unsatisfying experience because occasionally I’d catch glimpses of greatness. The rooftop helicopter battle, the entire temple puzzle section. Mostly though, 2 moments at the end, one in the cutscene before the final boss battle that crystallised one of the funniest things about video game morality (Drake is essentially taking this guy down because he kills people senselessly, and he’s doing this in a game that gives you trophies for kill milestones, like certain methods and weapons, and the villain ethers Drake), and the actual game ending, a genuinely hilarious exchange between Likeable Love Interest and Drake (who all my dudes seem to have man-crushes on for some reason, like WHY?), which is effortless and lived-in and so much better than all the forced one-liners Drake throws at you.
I had other problems with the game too, like argh taking Marco Polo seriously makes me so angry FUCK YOU NAUGHTY DOG even though look suspension of disbelief I know but this is one of my things, Marco Polo being a fraud. One of those fraudulent “facts” (like Eskimos have 100 words for snow how weird is that guys) that’s utterly bogus. While I was playing the game I just imagined that people were trolling Drake for being a tool and believing Polo's bullshit.
RATING: 7/10 THIS GAME IS CHILL IF YOU WANT TO KILL TIME I BORROWED IT OFF MY FRIEND ROB FOR FREE BUT I PROBABLY WOULDN’T PAY RRP FOR IT.
Amazon

entry.title: The Disconnect, or, Dude, I've Seen You Hit on Ladies, and It is The Saddest Thing
entry.content:
Butthurt has happened. Not since I got another Dundalk Internet Personality similarly lacking in self-awareness to display his maturity over twitter (Damn, I should have screencapped the whole exchange, the hypocrisy he displayed was a thing of beauty, a tour de force of self-ignorance normally only witnessed by GOP leadership over in the States), because he was pissed off that I was criticizing him for interfering in someone else's business, has there been a display of self-aggrandizing bullshit so beautiful. What unites these 2 individuals isn't their tragic lack of self-awareness, but rather the disconnect between how they view themselves, and how they actually are. The individual whose mature tweet has been screencapped included in his twitter bio the line "I don't follow, I lead". The individual whose rump is currently ravished recently made a blog post complaining that people weren't reacting to things the way he wanted.

My comment which sparked all this shit is available here. His blog post, "I Made a Mistake", is also worth reading, and it is rich in Essential Internet Arguments, like THAT'S JUST MY OPINION, and LOL DEFENDING MY SHIT IS TOO MUCH EFFORT.

Now Information Bro, a dude who I value most highly as a friend, has been keeping me abreast of the anal swelling currently befalling the blogger I wronged, and it is most entertaining. On his counsel however, the ethering of the blogger in question, and his resultant buttfrustration, will be saved for a later post, which will deal more with Internet Arguments and Logical Fallacies. This post, however, is inspired by that same blogger, (who won't be identified because, well, he doesn't deserve the publicity. To quote Mobute Sese Seko, he has "face for radio, voice for text, thoughts for semaphore), and concerns the disconnect between how these people portray themselves to browsers, and how they actually behave. Now to keep it fair I'll also be mentioning the blog of someone I actually like.

What unites The Danger Zone with The Rumpravished is their portrayal of their sex life. The former's is slightly inaccurate, but in a way that makes him more sympathetic (think Vriska in Homestuck), while the latter's description of it bears no resemblance to observed reality. Zone portrays himself as a kind of cold lothario, bedding the ladies haphazardly and without abandon. Now, he does get more play than Mario Chalmers, but at the same time, the coldness doesn't vibe with what is observed. However, this, as stated before, makes him more sympathetic, as the suppression of emotion for fear of showing vulnerability is a human action to which many can relate. The Rumpravished on the other hand, often makes casual references to his relationships (it is implied there have been numerous), and to talking to the ladies (he mentions his blog during his flirtations...), while by all accounts, he strikes out more than Mark Reynolds. As someone who has witnessed perhaps the 2 biggest strikeouts, and his subsequent reaction to them, I find his account of his love-life both unrealistic and goddamned hilarious. I'd describe them, but frankly the two girls in question would be embarrassed by association with him, and that would be mean, but more importantly, they wouldn't have acted in a way that provoked such an ethering.

In the latter case, the disconnect between his account of reality and reality itself is jarring.
