So yeah, my favourite hip-hop album for each year from 1991-2010, this should be fun.

1991) De La Soul - De La Soul is Dead
Wow, this list is off to an excellent start. I'm not sure what the De La Soul fanbase at large thinks of this, but personally I prefer it to 3 Feet High and Rising, which actually made a list of Best Indie Rock Albums a couple of years back. This one has so many killer jams, like Fanatics of the B Word and A Roller Skating Jam Named Saturdays, and it has limited verses from The Two Guys Who Aren't Posdnous (one of them still manages to shit up A Roller Skating Jam, "Mr. Sprinkler, Mr. Sprinkler" I mean come the fuck on), it's I think maybe their best album, and it's got Prince Paul's best production work ever.

1992) Pete Rock & CL Smooth - Mecca & The Soul Brother
Fuck yes Pete Rock. This also has T.R.O.Y., the saddest song to ever be written. It's a shame these dudes didn't make more albums, it was just fantastic to listen to.

1993) Wu-Tang Clan - Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)
Oh yes! Aside from The RZA's bizarre pronouncements and the general existence of Masta Killa, the Wu-Tang are one of the best oversized groups ever, up there with Arcade Fire and Plastic Ono Band. This one is also great because it only has one Masta Killa verse. There might be a relation between the quality of a Wu album and the abundance of Masta Killa. I must investigate.

1994) Nas - Illmatic
Nas is like Weezer. Nas is exactly like Weezer. But that's for another blog post, and there's been enough already written about how perfect Illmatic is.

1995) GZA/Genius - Liquid Swords
1995 actually looks to be pretty thin, and there was only non-Wu album this year that I really liked. But yeah, 1995 was the peak for the Wu-Tang Clan, this and Only Built 4 Cuban Linx..., they've fallen so far.

1996) Ghostface Killah - Ironman
This one has Daytona 500, which is maybe the catchiest song ever written. This is like 3 Wu albums in 4 years, I do love enforcing stereotypes, but this one is great. It's a shame Ghostface never got significant pop success, it'd be great. He also should have played Iron Man in the film, that would have been interesting.

1997) Company Flow - Funcrusher Plus
This is one of my top 5 albums ever. Fuck it is SO GUD. This was the album that put Rawkus on the map too, and I mean you decide whether that was a net gain for the world. The lyrics are mind-blowing, the flows are intricate and transcendant, and the beats have a harsh minimalism that evokes a rainy day in a grey city, long since resigned to its loss of influence as the manufacturing base moves ever eastward. If there was one album on this list I'd recommend above all others, it would be this one, it is simply fucking amazing. They never got around to releasing a second album, which sucks, since all the tracks they did after Funcrusher Plus, like Patriotism and Linda Tripp and D.P.A., all were even better than this album. As a result of all the label trouble that resulted in no second album though, we got Definitive Jux, so I mean everything worked out.

1998) Outkast - Aquemini
This isn't actually my favourite OutKast album, that honour goes to Stankonia, but this one is still fantastic. Apparently they're working on a new album, which is awesome, since I fucking loved Big Boi's solo effort. Incidentally, this was another year low on Rap Albums I Liked. Although Aquemini would be in the running any year, it was the only one this year I liked, since I was never huge on Miseducation of Lauryn Hill. Unplugged was way fucking better.

1999) Mos Def - Black on Both Sides
This one narrowly edges out The Slim Shady LP, mainly on the basis of Mathematics, one of the mind-blowing raps ever set to tape.

2000) Eminem - Marshall Mathers LP
Remember when Eminem was fresh and exciting and brilliant? Me too. What fun times they were. Supreme Clientele also came out this year, bringing the Wu back in a big way. Ghostface is always great. Always. 2000 was actually a great year. MMLP, Supreme Clientele, Deltron 3030, Stankonia. And Def Jux was founded. Holy shit.

2001) Cannibal Ox - The Cold Vein
And the reign of Def Jux begins. For the first half of the 00s everything they put out was fantastic. This one is maybe the best, and certainly the best this year, since everyone knows The Blueprint is the No Jacket Required of rap music. El-P's beats are radically different from the ones on Funcrusher, but they remind me of some particularly good ambient music from the late 70s, like Brian Eno pre-Music for Airports and all.

2002) El-P - Fantastic Damage
Again his beats are hugely different from the ones on The Cold Vein, and they're a lot funkier. This also has some of the best rapping I've ever heard, on Deep Space 9MM and Truancy. Unbelievably brilliant. He is one of the greats.

2003) Dizzee Rascal - Boy in da Corner
He's the representative of colossal british pop now, but this album has nothing in common with Bonkers or that song he did with yer one Florence. Brand New Day has to be one of the best hope-springs-eternal songs ever, like it's I Shall Be Released tier.

2004) Madvillain - Madvillainy
The first Stones Throw album on the list. If you watch any Adult Swim shows or The Boondocks you might already know them, since pretty much all the bumper music is from their releases. This one has MF Doom rapping over Madlib beats, and even though the songs are all like Guided by Voices-length, it kills, it kills a million times.

2005) Cage - Hell's Winter
It has beats from El-P and RJD2! It has that guy from Glassjaw! It has Jello Biafra impersonating George W. Bush! Probably the one truly great "emo rap" album ever released, I was never big on Kid Cudi or Charles Hamilton or them. I've heard good things about Donald Glover though, so I'll check him out.

2006) J Dilla - Donuts
Eh it's hard to describe this one, which was the last album released before J Dilla's death. It's kind of like a trippy Girl Talk album, which shorter tracks maybe. It's definitely an experience.

2007) El-P - I'll Sleep When You're Dead
Probably the most guest spots out of any album on this list, but usually the spots are only like 10 seconds long, and included solely because it's like Trent Reznor or Cat Power. Insanely fucking good, but again completely different from the 3 other El-P albums on this list. Recommended.

2008) Cadence Weapon - Afterparty Babies
The first canadian! This one had Bob Dylan references, and I actually first listened to it because of the combined recommendations of Carpo and John Meagher. It's really good, but also not like anything else on this list. But definitely worth a listen, especially for people (read: everyone who reads this) who don't really like rap music at all.

2009) P.O.S. - Never Better
The most "rock" of any entry here, and also the first appearance of a Rhymesayers album. It's got some great tracks, and apparently one of the videos is really fucked up (I haven't watched any of them, and in fact the last music video I saw was the one for Forever, which was HAR HAR forever ago). Yeah. Excellent. Apparently the P.O.S. stands for Pieces of Samantha or Promise of Skill or something, as well as what you think it stands for.

2010) Das Racist - Sit Down, Man
See my 2010 in Music post for this one, wrote about there at some length.

Well that raps (HO HO THE PUNS KEEP COMING) it up, the list didn't really throw any surprises at me, since there weren't any years when like UGK was the winner by default or something. Oh well.

[HIP-HOP EUPHEMISM],
Cathal

entry.title: A milestone is reached, and I compose odes in tribute to my close friends
entry.content:
100 posts! Who would have thought, back when I started this blog so I could show my friend a short story I wrote (I was unaware of these "google docs" or "filehosting" you speak of), that it would reach 100 posts in just under 2 years. And that it would have up to 5 readers! Originally, back when I was doing a post every 2 days, I planned for my 100th post (which, iirc, was scheduled to fall in late October/November) was to write a paean to my top bros! The make-up of this elite group has changed slightly since this post was first planned in early August, but the general theme, that of a virtual fist-bump for my dudes for being so cool, remains.

And so, in no particular order, the dudes in question, and the mad props they are to receive.

LARNEY
I live with this guy, he is SO GOOD (nullus, I mean so cool, but me saying It's so good is like a thing). I can't exactly remember when I met him, I assume it was one of those times back when Fitzy went out places, but he's always been the soundest of dudes. Plus an Adventure Time fan, I mean COME ON. Eh yeah generally he is pretty cool, you could even say THE COOLEST. I also think I owe him a pizza or something, I'm not sure.

FRANK
Eh out of all my friends Frank is the guy who wins the award for "Actually the worst person", but in spite of that, he's still a TOP BRO. We talk for hours about silly shit man, and he puts up with it even though I get the sense he has no interest in me talking about whatever. He blogs, and his blog is pretty much how I keep abreast (no hetero) of what is going in wrestling. Basically I plan to know enough so that I can follow the next Wrestlemania, which has The Rock, and me and Frank are gonna chill with Fitzy and enjoy this amazing comeback. Actually, speaking of

FITZY
The most antisocial of this loosely-defined bunch, seeing this guy out socializing in Dundalk is an event warranting several phonecalls to people informing them that "Fitzy is here man [What the fuck?]". He's also a master troll, I mean he takes them out at the knees, and makes the potty run out of the body, he amazes. I used to play TF2 with him, back before Valve shat it up with hats and trades and the "Mann-conomy", now we mostly just talk about whatever single-player games we've been playing. A++++. Like many peeps on this list, he blogs, so CHECK CHECK IT.

FORTENGARD
Again, not entirely sure how I met this guy, but he's pretty fucking cool. Also a huge animu fan, responsible for introducing me to all kinds of awesome shit, most recently Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt, Steven Stover, and Tony Jaa. He also blogs, about a variety of subjects, so you should check it out. He's pretty hysterical too, and our collective hating on Activision is a sight to behold, with so much concentrated haterwatts to boost 100s of flagging rap careers.

DARVER
Again not entirely sure how I first became friends with this guy. All I know is back when I met him he was a massive fan of Whedon and Battlestar. He still is, but I think he's outgrown his Battlestar t-shirt. Also the only Newcastle fan I know, which is bizarre since Newcastle were tearing up the joint when me and my friends were all kids. They had Ferdinand and Shearer up front, and a supporting cast consisting of insane biznasty like Faustino Asprilla and Pavel Srnicek. But yeah, he still keeps me up on TV shows I otherwise wouldn't hear of, and is good craic in a multitude of situations too. Again, he keeps a blog, so check that shit up.

RI
The closest thing to a shipper on board I know. Kind of a nerd. Also the only person I've talked to one the phone socially in the last 3 years, but that was mostly because she was bored, not because I'm an exceptional conversationalist. The second Whedon superfan on the list, she's a pretty big Nathan Fillion fan, and also a huge Star Wars fan, which is all cool. Also the person on the list I see least, which sucks, because as mentioned before, she's pretty cool. Also there's a girl on this list. My Ace Hen: a progressive blog.

MULLY
The guy who taught me how to download. Also the person from whom I obtained the seeds for my Dylan archive. 'nuff said.

KERRIE
Another chick, HOW CAN I HANDLE ALL THIS EQUALITY? Kerrie's the one on this list that I've known for the shortest time, but she is pretty cool, busta game or no busta game. She's already gotten her own post somehow, so I don't think more words are needed on the topic of her coolness. I've already extolled her coolness in a relatively long post. Read that instead. Or, better yet, watch some Firefly, damn that show is insane.

EIMEAR
I browsed my Facebook friendlist for people who warranted comment in this blog post, and she was the last name of note. She's pretty rad, like everyone else on this list (also she's female. You KNOFW i LOVE the BIG EQUALITY), but also the smallest, which I used to kind of take the piss about, but she was all haters gonna hate. She's also like MAD artistic. I was gonna do a blog about her art and shit way back last summer, but it never happened. It might at some point though, but I doubt it.

That's about it, I might edit this post more after it's publication to include even more dudes, but right now these dudes have certainly earned the mention.

BIG UP,
Cathal

entry.title: I'm surrounded by idiots, or, a "fisking" of sorts of recent comments made in favour of a "local" politician
entry.content:
I haven't really blogged about the general election at all yet. Actually, outside of voicing my disgust for The Carpetbagger's candidacy, I may not have mentioned it at all. It's happening this friday actually, and since I have fridays off I can exercise my democratic right nice and early and vote for anyone but Bailiff Adams. Feels futile though, man, since the latest poll is just a downright depressing sight. O'Dowd, or alternately, The Guy Who's Not Fucking Terrible and Actually From the County, has lost 3 points, while The Guy Who Actually Knows Nothing About the Economy or Even Basic Welfare Numbers and He Doesn't Even Feel Bad About This Christ How Ignorant Can You Be has somehow gained 5. Fitzpatrick is also likely to get elected, which saves Fine Gael some serious embarrassment.

But the reason for this blog is the upward trend in blind stupidity detected in the Louth area over since the start of the cycle. The Bailiff somehow represents a 'change' and a 'better way of doing things', which for people with working brains, is a somewhat bizarre assertion. The only positive represented by The Bailiff running in Louth, an area with which he has no tangible connection outside of some dead bodies (but who cares about those, right?), is that since The Bailiff has no connection to the area, hopefully he can represent a new trend in TDs who win based on being celebrities, rather than through use of (to borrow an American term, and apply it loosely) the pork barrel. Don Givens in 2016!

The stupidity itself though. At first I hoped that the campaign for The Bailiff in Louth would in many ways resemble the Alan Keyes 2004 Senatorial campaign. A famous idiot is drafted into a constituency to which he has no relation, and proceeds to shit himself silly with stupidity and ignorance. Although he did the latter, nobody seemed to really care, since we were apparently blinded by stupidity and simplistic appalling rhetoric (dear God, the "dead patriots" during the debate, yes I fucking raged).

Let us not get into the reprehensible actions of The Bailiff himself, and all the murders and intimidation and voter fraud, and also the actions of Sinn Féin lackeys lately, trashing a memorial for a hunger striker (it's Cooley, specifically, the Long Woman's Grave, which is out of the way even for here, so it's not a mystery as to the allegiance of the culprits) who had the gall to comment on the career of The Bailiff himself, but like what would he know, right?

But onto people my age, who have stirred within me feelings of disappointment on a scale not seen since Teddy Roosevelt watched the Taft presidency unfold. A sizable number of SF voters could abandon The Bailiff (like he abandoned his constituents in West Belfast) and thanks to these blithering idiots he'd still get in. Let us have a look at some things that are being said by the youth in favour of the The Baron's candidacy. Then there will be some reaction images, since only so much can be said about idiocy of this magnitude. Actually fisking these is pointless, there's not even enough incorrect substance to fisk. I didn't even have to go looking for them, they were basically thrown in my face, providing me with some rage fuel from a little closer to home (you should always buy Irish, kids).

"[The Bailiff] is what this country needs... he is a way better leader than [the other party leaders]"


"[I'm voting for The Bailiff] because he lives down the road, and round here we stick together." (This one might not be exactly verbatim, since I can't access my chat logs, but the basic point was Adams was getting the vote because he was "local")


And perhaps my favourite, a veritable shitstorm of "wat", a response given to the question of "Why [are you voting for The Bailiff]?":

"Because Fianna Failand (sic) Fianna (sic) Gay (sic) are Liars. Bastards. Fianna Fail have been in waay (sic) to (sic) long and its been the saame (sic) and saaame (sic) bullshit over and over again watching the same fat fuckers sitting there in the dail (sic) doing nothing but giving themselves holidays and paying drivers to cart them about. Dont (sic) start me on Fianna (sic) Gay (sic). Green Party? I couldnt (sic) give a shit bout (sic) the environment until the economy is fixed its (sic) a secondary issue. Sinn Fein have never been in and Its (sic) time for a fucking change. People dont (sic) like them generally ecause (sic) their Mammys and daddys have raised tem (sic) to hate the party since they were young. Open yer (sic) own fucking eyes and see that its (sic) time for change. Oh yeah, and ill (sic) give that crazy bastard who wants to go back to (sic) punt a vote..."


Yeah this one really takes the cake, and is also a good general summation of the anti-gubmint, pro-Sinn Féin (let us note the irony in Ireland's most authoritarian party representing anti-government sentiment) rhetoric that is gaining steam for reasons inexplicable. But he has a point: the Irish government is bad. Sinn Féin have the TDs to prove it.

From the thing about the drivers (there's actually a pretty good reason for that), and the intimation that politicians have too much time off (between the whole ferrying yourself back and forth from the legislature to your constituency, and all the actual legislating itself, which is, by all accounts, insanely intensive work, and then, in addition, there's all the pork you have to pass out, you have to make sure all those potholes get filled, politicians actually have to work pretty hard just to stay on top of things, they deserve all that time off), to the "Economy trumps environment", which when you're a country such as Ireland, where a large part of the economy is the environment (from tourism and agriculture, and then the industrial sector, which Ireland does so well because of the abundance of water resulting from its climate. It turns out industry is quite water intensive, and we have a lot, while Britain has none, hooray), the whole thing is a shitstorm of party-line ignorance.

However, perhaps the crowning moment in this horrible diatribe is the accusation levelled against those who are, for reasonable reasons indeed, opposed to, and completely horrified by, the presence of The Bailiff and Sinn Féin in government: That those of this persuasion (of which I am a particularly fervent member) are simply of this completely-stupid-Sinn-Féin-is-like-obviously-the-greatest-ever mindset because their no-good parents have brainwashed them.

Apparently our eyes are closed, and if only we open them we will be confronted with the infinite wisdom of Sinn Féin, a party with policies written by people who are like totally smarter than Elihu Root, John Maynard Keynes and Norman Borlaug put together (That is sarcasm: the Sinn Féin platform is actually written by people whose intelligence combined equals that of J. Danforth Quayle). But this argument is absolutely hilarious, absolutely every part of it; the blanket generalization of all anti-SF peoples (although he has a point, Helen McKendry's deep antipathy towards Sinn Féin is a result of her mother), and the accusation that they are sheep, coupled with his own regurgitation of nonsensical talking points straight off the party platform and some empty noise about 'change', which history buffs will know that Sinn Féin, a party driven by republican sentiment and history more than political ideology, is in fact business as usual round these parts (it's the whole point of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil).

Of course this is Ireland. While I expect people to be take an interest in politics as an abstract concept (government spending is wasteful! government should increase spending! SOVEREIGNTY!!!!!!!), it's also a given that they will, as a rule, bask in their ignorance about things like economic policy (it is very easy to make a reasonable argument for "the Fianna Fáil economic policies and austerity measures are breathtakingly stupid, and could well cripple the country for a long while" but I have not heard that argument made by the public at large) or the intricacies of the workings of government itself (the abolition of something as cheap as the Seanad has gained serious weight, because like €27,000,000 is like LOADS of money, we could get rid of it and like buy Leeds United to rouse the national spirit; let's not even touch on the hysterical "IMF IZ TAKEN UR SOVRENTEE" bullshit).

Oh well, I'm not even sure why I've undertaken this post, since it is completely pointless to talk about Sinn Féin, a party that, from anecdotal evidence, only has one rational, intelligent voter (Cass, in case you're wondering). I guess, as cliche as it sounds, I believe that you should never forget (in this case, SF are different from Fine Gael and Fianna Fail since the latter 2 parties are no longer headed up by the "armies" (read: terrorists and murderers) from whence they came. Sinn Féin are oh are they ever still headed up by these people, and between you and me, I don't take murder and terrorism lightly, nor do I believe it to be "cool" or "better than politics").

But yeah, it wouldn't hurt to just read or inform yourself a bit, you might actually learn something about government, like how it works, and how it can be stopped.

Also The Bailiff has a fucking terrible beard man, may as well be a moustache,
Cathal

entry.title: Touching on a number of things, all of which interest me
entry.content:
David Norris is being interviewed on television right now, talking about being president (apparently the pretext for the interview is his weight loss or something, but nah), and damn he's just so articulate. It remains to be seen whether or not he will get sufficient council backing to actually run, but if he does, it's safe to say that only Fergus Finlay could challenge him for my vote. Gerry Adams certainly won't be getting it, the carpetbagging fuck. That's what's going on right now on the political front, I mean there's the general election upcoming, but what is there to say about that other than laugh at the attempts at internet campaigning by the major parties. But a recent poll shows Norris with 27% support, double the second place candidate (admittedly there's quite a bit of party overlap in the candidates they selected, but with their candidates combined, he's still 5% ahead of the leading party, which huzzah, a Norris presidency, and all the embarrassments it presents for the Order of Hibernia and republicans everywhere).

But other things, yes. I have spent this evening reading Dresden Codak, a webcomic by Aaron Diaz that is, generally, about a young lady named Kimiko Ross. It's quite an excellent read, with some astonishing art, so check it out. The comics flashing back to Kimiko's childhood are my favourites so far, well-written precocious children are always a joy to read. It reminds me of me, before I turned into an obnoxious jerk when I went to secondary school. Damn dem some shitty times I had there.

Going from a school with less than 100 pupils, where you knew absolutely everyone since small times, to a secondary school, with over 700 pupils, where you don't really know the teachers, and there are enough people for there to be well-established cliques, rather than an amiable pyramid of cool, where the entire class of a dozen or so (my own class was a baker's dozen) are all on decent terms. I wasn't really able to deal with it, and I pretty much had no friends for my entire first year there, that sucked pretty hard. Eventually I became just flat out antisocial, whereas when I was like a small kid I was just really outgoing and talking to everyone. Eventually I ended up getting treatment for social anxiety, and it worked out quite well, and I was able to go to public places by myself again.

But away from that, which wow that was all a jump-off from a comic, and back to something that is also tangentially related to Dresden Codak, the singularity! I was in the library yesterday, on a rare incursion into Dundalk to get a new cellphone, and I ended up reading a Time article about Ray Kurzweil, where I learned he takes something like 200 pills a day in a bid to keep him around for the singularity, so he can transfer his consciousness to a machine.

I have to be honest, I'll jump at the chance to do such a thing, it would presents me with opportunities that I really can't even conceive of, like they're on a 11th-dimension level of inconceivable, and then when it finally happens we'll wonder how we couldn't conceive of something so obvious (I'm not up with the latest M-theory developments, so maybe they already have defined the 11th dimension, which would be really cool). There are implications in the singularity too though, like using sentient machines for the whole war thing, but the U.S. Navy got this yo, which is excellent. That kind of foresight is radical (in the teenager sense, rather than the actual sense), and it reminds me of the reasoning for the Zeroth Law and (spoiler alert) Galaxia in Foundation and Earth.

To get back to the present day however, it's All-Star Weekend in the NBA, which has already produced one amazing BLAKE GRIFFIN MOMENT™, which holy hell how awesome is Blake Griffin. The Clippers used to be a joke, but now they're as exciting as the Thunder. Just searching Blake Griffin on youtube yields megafonzies worth of awe-inspiring videos (note to NBA announcers, facial has another meaning that you should think about it before you use it), this guy is it. GQ actually has a bunch of short articles (and a long one by Bethlehem Shoals about the OKC Thunder) about why the NBA is so great right now, and it really is. The current young players are so exciting, and the veterans are staying on top of their game longer (can you believe Kobe has been around since the mid-'90s? He's 32!), and if they market it right internationally, you could have a level of interest not seen since the Jordan heyday, when almost everyone in my primary school class could name the Chicago Bulls starting line-up.

Also, to finish up, there's a new Homestuck album out, by Tensei, this one being tracks made for Strife! animations that never were, and it has some absolutely kick-ass art of Bro vs. Jack Noir, which Bro is the best guardian, Dad, Mom, and Seahorse Dad are high-tier when compared to him. I have managed to fulfil the promise contained within this post title, which touches on a number of things I find interesting, so this post is a success. I've done a survey about the lunch choices of TCD students too, so if I get anything interesting out of the collected data I'll blog about that soon, which maybe at least one person might be curious enough to slog through it.

I WILL DO SCIENCE TO THE DATA,
Cathal

entry.title: So long, soldier
entry.content:
It is a sad day, a tragic day. My phone is broken.

I cannot enjoy the song of birds, or the morning sun. My phone is broken.

I find no joy in the sound of music, or the laughter of children. My phone is broken.

In the sky I see only clouds, in my mind I see no smiles. My phone is broken.

Yeah, it finally happened. I've had my cellphone, a Nokia 3410, for 10 years now. It was my first and only phone. I got it the summer before I went to start secondary school, and it's been with me ever since. Other people abandoned it for flashier models with colour screens and cameras, but I stayed true. It was a perfect meeting of form and function, beautifully designed, and easily usable. It was simple and unbloated, it made calls, it sent texts, and it had the perfect alarm, which I have to date never slept through. I might try and fix it actually, just for the alarm. It's been a part of my identity for years, and I'm genuinely sad now it's gone. It may seem odd to be saddened by the loss of a phone, but 10 years is a long time. It's been there through everything. So many life-changing calls and texts were made and received on that phone, so many games of Snake II and Bumper played. The 3410 was always there, never faltering. Oh what a fool I was to put it on the charger that fateful day of February 15th 2011. It's survived longer drops, but now the display is blank. Thankfully I can still make calls, so I can still get home on Thursday, but it's still a sad day, a day of mourning.

Over the weekend I'll have to get a new one, and I'm so far out of the phone game I don't even know what to look for. Those HTC Android phones look nice and cool, but the price is a bit steep, and (don't laugh) I'm kind of worried that a phone that sleek and narrow will fall out of my pocket really easily. But I might look at those smartphones, they do look pretty cool. I was saving up to build a new computer over the summer or maybe get a HTC Desire, which I do have enough money to get one now, but that puts the computer plans down the crapper. Damn this choice. Ultimately I'm gonna pluck for a mad cheap phone though, because even a top of the line phone couldn't match the 3410's beauty.

I'll try and find a camera to post a touching photo up here. Oh it will be missed.

Nokia 3410, 2002-2011,
The best phone that ever was.

A sad day,
Cathal

entry.title: The Rock is cooking something, and I am able to smell it
entry.content:
Oh shit I did not see this one coming. Dudes who know me know that I think The Rock is the best fucking thing in the last 20 years, and that he was criminally misused by Hollywood. He was the perfect guy for a film like Midnight Run, but instead they stuck him in SRSAKSHN shit like Walking Tall and The Scorpion King (although the latter did lead to some awesome promos, in particular the one with The Hurricane. "The Rock knows who are you are... yeah, you're the Hamburglar... get The Rock a cheeseburger"), but he made it semi-big in the last couple of years with some enjoyable family comedies from Disney, based around sports. The Rock actually played for Da U back in the 90s, until he got injured and Warren Sapp took his place. But yes, the pro wrassle game ain't been the same since The Rock left for the lights and fame.

Then Raw, tonight, THE ROCK WAS BACK. This is monumental. This is a big fucking deal. Sean linked me to a youtube clip, and it was glorious. The Rock was back in top form, calling out Cena for being a bitch-ass punk (fuck that You can't see me bit had me in stitches), and getting me so so hyped for Wrestlemania, way more than last year, which I was mostly excited for the Montreal Screwjob rematch.

I mean, for those of you who don't know, The Rock was THE sports star back when WWF was blowing up over here. Fuck Austin and Kane and all those other guys, The Rock was the real star. He has infinite charisma man, and we all fucking thought he was awesome. He's responsible for the last good thing Wyclef did, and his catchphrases are all in the popular lexicon man, he had a huge influence. He was on Jonathan Ross promoting The Tooth Fairy last year, and he was just such a joy to watch. He can pull of any tone man (see his filmography, with the exception of the two films I've dissed), and he is just such a funny, talented dude.

But the clip, holy hell The Rock has not lost a step with his mic skills. At the end, like the whole bit where he gets the crowd to join in, fuck. He's all gettin' his haters to sit down, man, and getting everyone so excited. The People's Champ, back in all his glory, beating Cena's bitch-ass down at Wrestlemania. And I really hope it's a serious fucking beatdown, like Hart-McMahon at the last Wrestlemania, with The Rock being awesome left, right, and fucking centre. Aww shit, son, this is a big fucking deal. And dudes are seriously fucking hyped. Right now planning to get down to Frank's place with Fitzy and watch that shit LIVE FO REALZ, since The Rock coming back is pretty much the best shit to happen this year.

Oh God this is just amazing. This is just, I mean he's The Rock, he's just far too cool man, I mean nobody should be allowed to be that awesome. He's so awesome, he could make Walking Tall, and still be one of the best dudes on the planet. Like he separated from his wife, and they decided to remain besties. If you tried that you'd get fucking laughed at, but The Rock can pull that shit off. Hopefully The Rock and CM Punk team up to make promos (The Rock has ALL THE BEST PROMOS. ALL OF THEM!) so amazing they single-handedly wipe out all the bad stuff the WWE has done in the last 5 years. IT COULD BE JUST THAT GOOD. Wrestlemania, mark the fucking date man, THE ROCK IS MAKIN THIS HAPEN!

I CAN SMELL WHAT THE ROCK IS COOKING, AND IT SMELLS SO AWESOME,
Cathal

entry.title: A Monday post, which ties into an unofficial holiday
entry.content:
Not a whole lot to say/it was an average Monday. First thing I had was my mapwork lab, which at first looked like it was gonna take a while, but soon I sussed it and I was finished within an hour. I'm only really finished that early because the demonstrators are so awesome though, one of them looks like a cool Bill Gates! I really enjoy the mapwork/physics Geology module, it's hells of interesting, and it's got some plate tectonics up in. Alfred Wegener sure showed his bitch-ass haters. They were all laughing at him back in the day but now we laugh at them! Catastrophism is the most ridiculous school of scientific thought that has ever been, oh yeah.

I had a Geography term test too actually, which I got a 65 on, which hells of yes, I might get my first first. Also I worked a little bit on the survey project we have to do, but honestly it's not coming together great. We have good questions, but right now, there's no obvious correlation. Also need to find an online survey that lets you view individual submissions, since we need to make dem correlations, and you can't do that with rumps of data.

Also my chemistry lab went pretty well, a II.I seems to be the standard lab mark my demonstrator is giving me, even though secretly she thinks I'm bound to fail come summer. I managed to be out early (obviously my new lab coat has powers, damn it just feels so crisp. I actually feel like a million bucks wearing it), and I got time to do some last minute revision for the test. I also got to read the Homestuck update, which eh who knew Hussie could write sapphic pirate/mind-control erotica? That man constantly finds new ways to surprise me.

All in all, this term is going pretty well. I'm getting kick-ass chemistry grinds from an awesome dude who is mad helpful, and I'm even doing alright in the petrology module, which is a relief, since I suck at rocks, man, I'm just flat out terrible.

That was pretty much my day at college. Even though I'm in 10-6 without any real break, I really love Mondays now, I get to do so much awesome stuff. I'm learnding! And the demonstrators and lecturers are also just really top notch, although Dr. Raleigh is the only lecturer I have on Mondays, but damn man, who knew statistics outside of baseball could be so interesting? She actually uses baseball examples, which is quite cool, since baseball is mad awesome for the statistics, although I don't fully understand the way they calculate some (what up VORP? I've actually started using OPS+ to judge value in my OOTP game, since it doesn't favour players with more plate appearances. ERA+ is also pretty useful, since I have no idea what a good VORP is for each of the different positions in my rotation), it's really interesting, and really cool. You should read Moneyball, by Michael Lewis, and some stuff by Bill James too. Moneyball is a pretty neat summation of sabermetrics in general, and is quite an entertaining read to boot.

When I got home until now I haven't really done much. I played some Battlefront II with Larney before he went out, and then had some insanely tight NBA Live games with Domhnaill. It was pretty good craic, and I managed to break a chair in the excitement. It's no NBA 2k11, but NBA Live 2004 is pretty solid, and it's got nostalgia value to boot. Chris Webber! Reggie Miller! Mike Sweetney!

It's actually been a while since I've done a post like this, which is more in line with the posts of last summer, which were, as a rule, short and boring. This one isn't really short, but I'm not going to assume anyone will find it to be interesting reading. Whatevz! Time to kick back and roam around Summer Forest in Spyro 2. The Summer Forest theme is just perfect relaxation music. Yes please!

Also to tie it into Valentine's Day, here is a picture of a box of chocolates with a picture of Rainbow Dash that someone found in Walgreen's. How adorable. I remember the last time I was spoken for on Valentine's day I sent one of the cards The Onion put out. I can't remember what it said, or even if they liked it, but sending it made me feel all warm inside, as did the person in question. YAY!



Sex with... BOYS?,
Cathal

entry.title: 30 songs, all of which hold personal significance for me
entry.content:
The 30-day song challenge is a thing on Facebook, that I found out about from my mate Mully. It sounded pretty interesting, and a large caffeine intake in the last couple of hours meant I wasn't sleeping so I decided I would try and do this. 30 songs, with a short note explaining why each was chosen.

01 - Your Favourite Song - Michael Guy Bowman - How Do I Live?
This is a song from Homestuck, which I blogged about recently. A cover of the Diane Warren song from Con Air, this manages to be a Diane Warren cover that doesn't completely suck. This song on repeat is my Pump It Up mix, and I just fucking love it. Feels so good on my eardrums.

02 - Your Least Favourite Song - Black Eyed Peas - I Gotta Feeling
I caved in and went for an obvious choice. I am weak. Originally I was thinking Not Afraid by Eminem, but although I hate it, it's not my least favourite. I Gotta Feeling is. For months, it was impossible to escape. You couldn't socialize for months without hearing this song and some girls and that one disgraceful dude screaming along to it. Dear God, it was fucking horrible. Mazel tov, motherfucker? Motherfucking Mazel tov? This shit is horrible. I'm swearing so fucking much that's how bad this is.

03 - A Song That Makes You Happy - Boston Spaceships - Tattoo Mission
Not a whole lot to say about this one. It's a happy, wonderful song from Robert Pollard's new band. It, like the entire album it's from, The Planets are Blasted, is just a joy to listen to.

04 - A Song That Makes You Sad - Guided by Voices - I'm Cold
The first of what will no doubt be many Guided by Voices songs up in this thing. It's off Suitcase 1, that hodge-podge bootlegs collection Pollard put out a few years ago. The collection has a lot of good songs, including a piano-only version of Wondering Boy Poet, but this is my favourite. It's just really, really sad to listen to, and when I listen to it the sadness rubs off on me.

05 - A Song That Reminds You of Someone - Guided by Voices - Atom Eyes
Reminds me of Christine. Don't ask me why, I have absolutely no idea.

06 - A Song That Reminds You of Somewhere - Steward Copeland - Summer Forest
Damn, son. This instrumental from Spyro 2 just reminds me of a sunny day in the woods. It is blissful.

07 - A Song That Reminds You of a Certain Event - Chumbawamba - Tubthumping
World Cup '98 in it's entirety. I was actually in France when it went down, which was awesome.

08 - A Song That You Know All the Words To - Guided by Voices - Goldheart Mountaintop Queen Directory
This one is a cold hard classic off Bee Thousand, which is also completely awesome. It was when I heard this song that I fell in love with Guided by Voices, completely and utterly.

09 - A Song That You Can Dance To - Pen Ward and Olivia Olson - There Go Our Boys
I wouldn't really call what I do "dancing", but I can bug out to this one. It's from the first Marceline episode of Adventure time, and she's one of my favourite supporting characters. This song is just absolutely fantastic, so so catchy.

10 - A Song That Makes You Fall Asleep - Brian Eno - 1/1
The first side of Music for Airports, this is completely relaxing, soothing bliss. I can use it to clear my mind, actually that applies for pretty much the whole album, which is the most perfect, brilliant double album ever.

11 - A Song from Your Favourite Band - Guided by Voices - No Sky
It's hard to choose just one Guided by Voices song, but in the end I'll pluck for No Sky, off Under the Bushes Under the Stars. This is pretty straightforward and short, but like a lot of the UTBUTS songs, is completely effective. A+++++!

12 - A Song from a Band You Hate - Black Eyed Peas - Boom Boom Pow
See number 2, fuck they are awful. With the exception of Hey Mama, which is actually alright. There's always one...

13. A Song That is a Guilty Pleasure - I ain't some insecure dude who feels guilty 'bout digging awesome things. Get outta here!
Seriously, OH I LOVE THIS BAND BUT I AM WORRIED ABOUT PEOPLE JUDGING ME. I guess the closest any song comes is Winter Wrap-Up, I mean other people would feel guilty about that. But they shouldn't, it's fucking great.

14. A Song That No One Would Expect You to Love - Kazumi Evans - The Art of the Dress (Stitching It Together)
This is also a pretty awesome song. A rewrite of a Stephen Sondheim song (I forget which work it's taken from), this is catchy as hell. Suited for Success was such a good episode.

15. A Song That Describes You - Guided by Voices - I Am a Scientist
I racked my brain over this one, but in the end I went with the obvious choice, since I am pursuing a science degree, and I maintain a blog. I am a scientist, I am a journalist, I seek to understand me.

16. A Song That You Used to Love But Now You Hate - Nickelback - Hero
I was like 11, and Nickelback were hot shit. How foolish we all were. But back then, we didn't have any quick way of playing double music, so we didn't realise just how bad Nickelback were.

17. A Song That You Hear Often on the Radio - Eminem & Rihanna - Love the Way You Lie
I did not like Recovery at all, it was really bad. But I've heard this song on the radio like 3 times since it came out, which is more than I've heard any other song in the last year, so it wins by default.

18. A Song That You Wish You Heard on the Radio - The Protomen - Breaking Out
So. Fucking. Brilliant. I mean if I had to hear a song on the radio, it would be this one. People need to hear this 9 minute epic about individualism and rebellion.

19. A Song from Your Favourite Album - Bob Dylan - One Too Many Mornings
Off Live at "Royal Albert Hall", this one is brilliant. It's an electric version of one of the sadder songs off The Times They Are a-Changin' (which is saying something), and it's just so good, highlight from one of the best live albums ever.

20. A Song That You Listen to When You're Angry - Cursive - The Lament of Pretty Baby
Can't really explain this one, but I just gravitate towards Cursive's Domestica in general whenever I'm pissed off.

21. A Song That You Listen to When You're Happy - Brian Eno - The Big Ship
Perhaps the most beautiful piece of music ever recorded. Wow.

22. A Song That You Listen to When You're Sad - Guided by Voices - Dayton, Ohio, 19-something and 5
This one is from the fanclub album, Tonics and Twisted Chasers, Bob did with Tobin Sprout. It's also on the titular EP. It's live on the EP, but both renditions are heartbreaking, and it's Bob singing at his best. RECOMMENDED. Not so much the rest of Tonics though, except for "Is She Ever?"

23. A Song That You Want Played at Your Wedding - Robert J! Lake - Softly
Haven't really put much thought into it, but this piece is so beautiful, it wins.

24. A Song That You Want Played at Your Funeral - Clark Powell - Homestuck
This is a beautiful piece of music. In Homestuck, it's actually used to soundtrack a montage of Egbert's childhood, and it's just an incredibly sweet moment, but in general the music is perfect for any number of moods and situations, especially funerals!

25. A Song That Makes You Laugh - The Lonely Island - I Throw It on the Ground
Oh dear God, this one is hilarious. "I'M AN ADUUUUULT". It's about a hipster who shows that he is not part of the system by throwing various things on the ground. Vintage Lonely Island.

26. A Song That You Can Play on an Instrument - Billy Joel - Uptown Girl
I don't even like Billy Joel, yet I used to be able to play this like the Dickens on piano. I might pick it back up to use as a party piece.

27. A Song That You Wish You Could Play - Aphex Twin - avril 14th
I don't think it can actually be played with two hands, but getting an extra one fitted to your body would be totes worth it if you could play this.

28. A Song That Makes You Feel Guilty - Guided by Voices - Acorns and Orioles
Not really sure why I chose this one. HOW MYSTERIOUS.

29. A Song from Your Childhood - Shaggy and Rayvon - Angel
It Wasn't Me was actually the first piece of music I bought for myself. Such a classic. Fuck. Shaggy was the man.

30. Your Favourite Song at This Time Last Year - Emancipator - Old Devil
I detailed why Emancipator was awesome in my Best of 2010 Music post, you should check that out and then listen to Emancipator!

I honestly thought I'd write more for each song, but eh so it goes. COMMENCE ARMCHAIR PSYCHOANALYSIS or whatever, or better yet, do your own!

Footix was the best mascot ever man,
Cathal

entry.title: ACTIVISION!
entry.content:
Goddammit. I actually had a few conversations with Fortenbro, spanning a couple of months, about why Spyro Trilogy HD (not the recent one, let's pretend that whole thing never happened. I mean some of the character redesigns (especially Hunter), and the attempt at an epic mythos, were nice, but overall the games were weaksauce) would be the most baller shit this side of Hater Bot. Even though Activision owned the franchise, I held out hope. I mean, Kogrub would just jump on a money-spinning opportunity like a re-release. He'd get to make money off games Activision had nothing to do with! Alas, nothing happened. They're on the PSN store in North America, but I mean that's meaningless, because a) dammit bro HD! and b) a tenner per game?

But still, the fact that a new Spyro game is being released gives me hope. Even if the character design ain't all that impressive, maybe if this game is a success Activision to grace us with a HD
remaster of Spyro. Sigh. It's never going to happen. I am sadcheetah right now.

This new game, however. Even if it does manage to be enjoyable, it still has all those action figure peripheral things being peddled by the Activision marketing juggernaut. Hopefully it will have some Eye of Judgment style appeal at the very least, but I mean maybe Activision will actually pull through and put out a good game. It can happen, right?

(Aside: This news comes on the heels of Activision canning the Tony Hawk and Guitar Hero franchises, which it's about time. Hopefully the failure of these will show Kogrub that you can't just release endless shitty iterations of a franchise or charge insane prices for horrible peripherals. This means one of two things: 1) Kogrub is replacing these dead franchises with Spyro, which is slightly less dead, or 2) Kogrub will learn his lesson and lavish care and attention on the Spyro franchise, and give the developers freedom and space, and release the game at a reasonable price. lolololol as if number 2 will happen. The only really good thing to happen to Spyro recently was the cancellation of that animated film FROM THE DIRECTOR OF SPAWN, dear Jesus Christ no.)

On the plus side today, a new MLP episode, this time about Pinkie Pie! It should be, at the least, surreal!

Aw shit, gonna get fucked up on friendship tonight,
Cathal

entry.title: Orlanthi culture sure is weird
entry.content:
Another go at King of Dragon Pass. Once again, I made very little progress towards actually forming a kingdom. I was too busy pursuing an isolationist foreign policy, except when I was hating on the Greenwings. Fuck that clan man. And this was on easy difficulty. Fuck. But long story short, let us never speak again of the dark times that were Voskandora's chieftainship.

Ancient Lore
During the marriage of Orlanth and Ernalda, our men and women stood guard with Elmal, making Elmal our main deity.

Our clan’s earliest famous event was Jested’s Settlement, when Issaries the Talking God outwitted foreign deities in a difficult negotiation.

During the Storm Age, we adopted strangers into our clan. Our worst enemies in those days were the trolls.

We were originally a Balanced Clan.

At the Dawn, we first awakened Orlanth, the Father.

Our attitude toward dragons and their ilk was neutral; we did not go along with them nor actively make war on them.

1329
When we arrived in Dragon Pass, we claimed more land than we needed, to grow into. We built a clan hall, some steads, and a shrine to Elmal. But when we left Heortland, we lost much of our connection with the gods.

1330
The god-talkers predicted many piglets would be born this year.

Kentvent was bullied and insulted by a pair of Jenstali weaponthanes at their clan market. We sent for shamans to curse them. Shamans came and said they would curse the Jenstali for the low price of 15 cows. We accepted the arrangement. The shamans said that the spirits had entered the dreams of their targets, and rearranged the secret places of their souls. Soon we heard that the Jenstali had developed an unquenchable hunger for lichen, and an overweening passion for the company of their sheep.

Bandits blocked our emissary to the Badger clan. Garstal and his forces killed and scattered them.

We approached the Badger clan with an offer of peace. We offered them payment. They were pleased by our generosity, and we ended the feud.

Bandits blocked our emissary to the Greenwing clan. Urenstand attacked, but was wounded and had to return home.

Someone killed some of our horses. The weaponthanes were despondent, for by allowing this to happen we had shamed our patron god. We made the claim before their clan ring. They denied that they had slain our horses. Aransanda, who argued our case with them, thought they were lying.

Explorers encountered a bark-clad shaman who predicted an ice storm and warned against a mysterious crop of spears. We decided to find the shaman and offer to adopt him. They looked high and low for the shaman, but did not find him.

Humakti warriors said we should give them permission to enter our tula and fight the undead. We granted it, and gave them gifts. They praised us as an honorable clan. They tramped around our lands for many days, but did not find the creatures they were looking for. They were good guests, though, and did little to disturb us.

The harvest was poor.

The forces of cold and darkness attacked our land with snow and wind. Our herds were threatened. We called on Orlanth to help us against his ancient enemies. Soon after the sacrifices were made, the enemy storm lifted.

1331
It was an auspicious year for heroquesting.

Orendal spoke for the warriors when he said that they were stretched too thin, and that more fighters were needed. We sent Garstal on a mission to find the best warriors available.

Olende of the Greydog clan offered us gifts. We gave Olende a reciprocal gift. He said we were very generous, and that he would say so to others.

Robasart won a bet with the Narri chieftain, and won much grain. We gave them a gift in return. They praised our generosity.

Renatha, a member of the Rangdani ring, came seeking help against a gigantic wyrm. We offered to send warriors, but at a higher price. She named a price we liked better. They came back from the hunt carrying wyrm scales they had taken as trophies. They said that the Rangdani treated them fairly, paying what they said they would pay, and risking them no more than they did their own warriors.

Odayla cultists offered to perform a ritual to make the hunting better in our area. We accepted their offer, and gave them gifts. They thanked us for the gifts and departed, telling us that we would know when the ritual had been completed when the forest filled with elk.

Our scouts found a strange clan of beast folk who were like ducks. With justice and mercy, we offered peace to the duck people, who henceforth gave our clan a place of honor in their songs.

1332
The god-talkers feared for our explorers.

We found a cave full of dangerous, armored rodents on our tula. Robasart said he would lure them away with trickster magic. He pranced about the cave mouth, singing a song which he said was an irresistibly salacious tune in the language of the killer rodents. It seemed absurd, but the rodents formed a line and followed Robasart as he danced away from the borders of our tula and towards those of the Greenwing clan.

Someone killed some of our horses. The weaponthanes were despondent, for by allowing this to happen we had shamed our patron god. We sacrificed to Elmal Horse-Friend for protection from horse-killers. The god-talkers said that the signs were good; Elmal would protect us from such attacks in the future.

Dangmag wanted vengeance against the men who had killed his father many years before. We sent a delegation to demand wergild for the slaying of Dangmag’s father. The Rangdani lawspeaker said that their clan should not be liable for actions taken so long ago, when Rostakos and Vandarl belonged to another, faraway clan. Furthermore, the two men had changed since they burned Randalyar. “They have renounced their brutal ways, and are now as judicious and honorable as any Orlanthi thane.” “Yet,” said their chief, Farnan, “in the interests of harmony between our clans, we will pay the wergild you ask.”

Grivton led a delegation of weaponthanes to complain that the carls were being favored over them. We feasted in their honor.

We were raided by the horse nomads. We were driven from the battlefield and looted. And they took 22 of our footmen captive.

We were able to attract 56 new carls to the clan. They brought with them 44 children.

Robasart, the devotee of Eurmal on our clan ring, gave away a herd of our cows. We removed Robasart from the clan ring. The people said it was good to punish him, but that this was not enough punishment.

The harvest was poor.

Foul weather turned back our diplomatic mission to the Rangdani.

Aransanda took ill, because someone had woven Chaos runes into her skirt. We sacrificed to Chalana Arroy.

Salinarg began the Elmal Guards the Stead heroquest. Orlanth left on his great quest, and Salinarg stayed to guard the stead. A Chaos creature called the Eater of Skin came and attacked. Salinarg protected himself with Orlanth’s shield. The creature ate at Salinarg where the shield could not protect him. Salinarg sang a song of comforting valor. The song wounded the creature, which made strangled sounds, and was forced to end its own chaotic keening. It slashed through Salinarg’s back and tore his innards from him. Salinarg thrust his spear at it. The spear pierced the creature’s eye, and it screamed in anger. The creature ripped at Salinarg with one of its seven mouths, and tore open Salinarg’s chest. Before the creature could remove the spear, it groaned and died; the people rejoiced. Our worshippers, back in the ritual ground, had a chance to help Salinarg knit himself back together. We gave of our clan magic. Salinarg knitted himself back together and everyone, whether from the Orleving clan or the Storm Tribe, rejoiced. More Chaos enemies came, including the Author of Sores. Salinarg clubbed her about the head. Her head came off, but leapt forward and tore at Salinarg’s chest. Salinarg buffeted her with the wind of Orlanth’s sword. The Author of Sores groaned; her sores closed up, and she did not like this, for the sores were the source of her power. She caused the skin of Salinarg’s legs to pop open, so that he could hardly stand. Salinarg lanced her with a spear. The Author of Sores shook and howled. Green muck oozed from the creature’s body, and it fell upon Salinarg melting whatever flesh it touched. As the muck seeped out of her body, it deflated. The Author of Sores was slain, and the people rejoiced. Once again, our worshippers were given a chance to help Salinarg knit himself back together. We gave of our clan magic. Salinarg knitted himself back together and everyone, whether from the Orleving clan or the Storm Tribe, rejoiced. Then came the Maker of Bad Growth, another Chaos enemy. Salinarg left the realm of the gods. The god-talkers were sure that we would face an incursion of Chaos in the days to come, and the people were frightened.

1333
The god-talkers feared for our explorers.

Starvation hit our clan.

A gigantic chaos creature appeared on the boundaries of our tula. It ate some sheep, and scared away the shepherds. We sacrificed to Urox for aid against chaos. While we prepared the sacrifices, the chaos creature ate some of our cows. The god-talkers said the signs were good; Urox would aid us in our battle. We attacked the creature. We slew the creature. It decomposed over a matter of days, and we had to keep everyone inside their steads. Where it died, nothing would grow.

We saw a rainbow; the people were cheered by this good omen. Because we were lucky, we embarked on a raid.

We raided the Greenwings and eluded their patrols. Loricon ended up unseen among the enemy’s warriors. He fought recklessly but not well, and fell in combat with the enemy. We drove the Greenwings from the battlefield, and were able to plunder their tula.

After many weeks at death’s door, Aransanda recovered from the illness caused by the hexed skirt.

Starvation hit our clan.

Bandits blocked our emissary to the Greydog clan. Urenstand tried to bargain with them, but got nowhere. Urenstand and his forces killed and scattered them.

Acting as our emissary, Urenstand asked the Greydogs to make good on the obligation they owed us, and provide us with food. Urenstand asked for no more and no less than the usual amount. The Greydogs provided us with the food without complaint.

We wailed with woe as kinstrife struck us. Garrath was slain. We sacrificed to Urox, foe of Chaos.

Starvation hit our clan.

Uralda cultists sought aid in a great ceremony to prevent cattle sickness in a distant corner of Dragon Pass. We accepted their offer, and gave them gifts. They thanked us for the gifts.

Sarotar, a rebellious thrall belonging to the Greenwing clan, came to beg for our aid. He wanted us to protect escaped thralls from outraged Greenwing thanes. We sent a war party to fight the Greenwing thanes. We found them and did battle with them. They fought back fiercely, angered that we dared interfere in their clan affairs. Some of our people were killed, and others wounded. During our absence, Sarotar slipped his guards and rejoined his group. He and the other thralls escaped their pursuers. We later heard that they lived as outlaws and were eventually all killed by the people they preyed upon.

A delegation of the clan’s leading men raised serious complaints against the job Voskandora was doing as chief. We outlawed Voskandora for the mess she had made of the chieftaincy.

We were raided by the Trolls. We drove the Trolls off, and their survivors left without plundering our tula.

While plowing the fields, the carls found something strange. It was the enormous skull of some kind of dragon creature. We used it to decorate our clan hall.

The dangerous rodents came back and bit children and horses. We decided to seek outsiders to exterminate the creatures. We found weaponthanes of the Wolf clan willing to do it, for half a cow worth of silver each. Many of them were wounded, and they blamed us for not warning them how dangerous these rodents were. They said that all of the creatures were dead.

We were raided by the Greenwings. Orlkensor realized that the enemy were being attacked by Orlanth’s spirits of retribution, the impests, who must have meant to punish them for breaking Orlanth’s sacred vows. He killed Greenwing fools who were too hapless to defend themselves. We drove the Greenwings from the battlefield, striking them down as they fled.

1334
The god-talkers predicted many piglets would be born this year.

A milk-white calf was born into Orendal’s herd. Orendal kept the calf, and our herds increased. The carls were pleased by the ring’s decision.

Starvation hit our clan.

We were able to attract 26 new carls to the clan. They brought with them 35 children.

Starvation hit our clan.

A beautiful woman appeared in the woods. Some said that she ensnared our men. We ignored the rumors.

The dangerous rodents came back and bit children and horses. We decided to seek outsiders to exterminate the creatures. We found weaponthanes of the Turtle clan willing to do it, for half a cow worth of silver each. Many of them were wounded, and they blamed us for not warning them how dangerous these rodents were. They said that all of the creatures were dead.

Harsaltar died of a terrible curse when plants sprouted from his body. We cast a curse-lifting spell on all of the people of the clan. 3 carls died. One of them was married; so we knew that he had committed adultery with the mysterious woman of the woods.

We discovered a large cache of bones and ivory in one of our tula’s valleys.

Spirit-talkers showed up and asked if we needed anything from them. We asked them to sell us Spirit Fetches. We added the Spirit Fetch to our treasures.

We were raided by the Greenwings. We were losing the battle. Garstal stopped the warriors who were about to flee. Together they faced the Greenwings. We drove the Greenwings from the battlefield, striking them down as they fled.

We could no longer afford to maintain our shrine to Ernalda.

1335
The god-talkers predicted an unusual number of rats and vermin this year.

Priestesses of Chalana Arroy said they would heal our sick and wounded in exchange for a future favor. We declined their offer, and offered them gifts in return. They declined our gifts, saying that it was not yet the time. The priestesses said little else, but the people saw that they were displeased, and so were displeased in turn.

Many of our sheep became sick. We sacrificed to Nevala, the sheep mother. The sick sheep were healed by Nevala’s grace.

High-ranking members from the Orlmarth clan came to us to trade for our ivory. We offered them three wagonloads in exchange for 40 cattle. They weren’t completely pleased with this proposal, but they agreed to it.

Brangbane and his family came from distant Esrolia, to ask for membership in our clan. We accepted them, and on that day they became Orleving.

We were raided by the Horse-Spawn. Barngradus caused great damage in a group of Horse-Spawn who were attempting to circle behind us. We drove the Horse-Spawn from the battlefield, striking them down as they fled.

A representative of the carls protested to the clan ring, stating that they were tired of supporting a great number of priests and weaponthanes. We agreed that we had too many weaponthanes, and released some from our service.

Wilms, a thane of the Blackrock clan, asked us for the details of the “How Things Began” story. We told him what he wanted to know. He thanked us and departed.

A band of very strange musicians asked for permission to play at our clan market. We accepted the offer. Bundalini’s All-Skeleton Band played, and people came from all over. We decided to forge new trade arrangements. We made some good deals, which promised to pay off in the next few seasons.

1336
All of the omens were unlucky.

The dangerous rodents came back and bit children and horses. We ordered our weaponthanes to exterminate them. They said the carls should have been ordered to block the cave entrance. Many of them were wounded, but they said that they killed them all.

We reorganized as a Peace clan.

Verlain, a hunter of the Orlmarth clan asked permission to hunt a great white stag on our land. We said he could hunt it in cooperation with our own hunters. Together, they caught the stag. It was a magnificent beast indeed, and there was glory enough for both clans.

Starvation hit our clan.

The people complained Arene made bad trade deals on the clan’s behalf. The other ring members publicly scolded her. Arene was chastened, and agreed to mend her over-generous ways. This seemed to mollify the people somewhat.

Priests and thanes from the Wolf clan come to request the right to adopt a baby, one they said would grow up to become a great hero of the Knowing God. We granted their request, in exchange for a gift of knowledge. They said they would be happy to tell us the tale of “Orlanth and Aroka” in return for the baby.

The harvest was plentiful.

We were raided by the Trolls. Barngradus wrestled with a troll for a full minute before they both fell wounded. We drove the Trolls from the battlefield, striking them down as they fled.

Jotisan, a thane of the Rangdani clan, asked us for information about Bastakos, chief of the Hendart clan. He reminded us that we owed his people a favor. We endeavored to answer his questions. Jotisan asked us if Bastakos was a holy chief. We said, “Bastakos is as pious as the average Orlanthi chieftain.” Jotisan departed, and thanked us for the information. Not long afterwards, he returned to our tula to withdraw his thanks. “The information you gave us was mistaken at best and deceitful at worst. Our relations with the Hendarti have been sorely tested, and it is your careless words which are to blame.”

1337
It was an auspicious year for heroquesting.

The ghosts of our dead warriors returned and told us that our actions shamed the clan. We sacrificed to them. They pronounced themselves pleased with the respect we had shown them, and vanished.

A beautiful woman appeared in the woods. Some said that she ensnared our men. We sent searchers to capture her. Our best hunters searched long and hard, using their most powerful magics. They brought the woman back to us, tied with ropes. She would not speak to us. Our storytellers thought her some kind of kin to the aldryami, or elves. We gifted her, and asked her to convey our goodwill to her people. She warned us that our men had been dangerously infected, because we had offended the elves. She told us how to mix a potion to cure the infection before it showed itself. She also said that the trouble with the elves would get worse, if we weren’t careful.

The dangerous rodents came back and bit children and horses. We ordered our weaponthanes to exterminate them. They said the carls should have been ordered to block the cave entrance. Many of them were wounded, but they said that they killed them all.

Aslandar, of the Turtle clan, asked us to give him grain, because we owed him a favor. We gave him more than he wanted. Aslandar praised our generosity, and said that all of Dragon Pass would hear of it.

The warrior Garnath, outlawed from his clan, came to us for refuge. We gave him an honored place in the chief’s hall.

We were raided by the Trolls. We took 5 captives from the Trolls. Garnath distinguished himself in the fighting.

We were able to ransom the prisoners.

A squabble broke out between those who claimed descent from the founders of the tribe, and those whose ancestors were the remnant people adopted into the tribe during the Storm Age. We scolded the people for dividing into factions. Each side was offended that we had not reserved our hottest words for the other.

We were raided by the Greenwings. Although we held the field, we weren’t able to take any captives.

1338
The clan would see endless legal squabbles in the coming year, according to the god-talkers.

Brangbane was caught with trade goods that he did not buy through the clan ring. We stood him up before his fellows, and held him out as an example of disobedience towards chosen leaders.

Acting as our emissary, Urenstand sought an alliance with the Kardarvi. Urenstand said to them, “It would be generous of you to help us in a time of need.” Their chief, Jenesta, agreed that our two clans should be allies. “Generosity is the prerogative of chiefs and kings,” Jenesta said, “and I am glad to extend to you our bounty and protection.”

Outlaws blocked our emissary to the Greydog clan. Garstal and his forces killed and scattered them.

Acting as our emissary, Garstal sought a gift of magic from the Greydogs, who owed us a favor. He asked for less than the customary amount. They granted Garstal’s request and praised our generosity, because we could have asked for much more from them, in discharge of the obligation they owed to us.

The weaponthanes complained that they had not raided in years.

We raided the Greenwings. Jonrik, a Wind Lord of the Greenwings threatened to turn the battle against us single-handedly. Our own hero fired missiles at the Wind Lord until one struck home and got the Greenwing’s attention. Garstal challenged the enemy to single combat. The two warriors clashed. Jonrik was too much for Garstal, who took a horrible wound. We were driven off and had no opportunity to obtain booty.

Humakti warriors sought our help in a war party against walking corpses. We offered them hospitality. They refused us. “Do not attempt to weasel and cajole us!” their leader scoffed. “If you mean to refuse us, you can at least do so honestly.”

An outlaw woman brought us a baby she had raised in a shield. She told us that the babe, Kallyr, would one day be a mighty warrior. We asked her why she was an outlaw. “My own outlawry is a long and sad story,” she said. “Let us say that it was a matter of wrong passion, and that I accept my punishment. This girl’s mother was also outlawed, and the child is the result of her shame. She is innocent of any blame, and needs a clan to grow up in.” We did as the woman asked, and took the girl in.

The harvest was plentiful.

A two-headed calf was born; the people saw it as an ill omen. We sacrificed to Urox for protection from chaos. The god-talkers said that Urox had heard our pleas.

1339
The god-talkers said that Orlanth wanted us to make a pilgrimage to Mount Kero Fin.

Refugees come seeking aid. They said they had escaped from the Horse-Spawn. We adopted them as family.

The haughty horse nomads who called themselves Grazers, but we know as the Horse-Spawn, came to reclaim the refugees we had adopted. We told them we’d never seen their thralls. They swallowed our deception, and left our tula.

The Greenwings raided us for 34 cows.

We were raided by the Greenwings. The Greenwing clan burned 4 steads. We were losing the battle. Jorator charged the Greenwings and our warriors followed his example. We were driven from the battlefield and looted. They burned 5 more steads.

Dangmag led a delegation of carls to complain that we were too war-like, and that the crops were suffering as a result. To end the dispute, we compensated the aggrieved parties.

The harvest was plentiful.

Mordrim the Stout came to trade for the White Calf. We accepted, but demanded a favor in the future.

Gardrostan led a delegation of weaponthanes to complain that the carls were being favored over them. We thought their grievances exaggerated, and tried to make them see this, too. They agreed that they may have tried too hard to make their point, and that things weren’t as bad as they’d made them out.

Ragged outlaws demand hospitality, and threatened us with a rain of hail sent by Gagarth, the outlaw god. We granted them hospitality. They ate an astonishing amount of food, and drank more ale than we thought human bodies could contain. They insulted everyone, and made a mess. Even their children got drunk and made trouble. We thought they would fall into drunken slumber, but they stumbled away into the darkness of the night, telling us that they looked forward to visiting us again in the future. The people were most displeased by their actions.

We were raided by the Isoltings. Jorator was wounded while facing the Isolting charge. He rallied our warriors and attacked. Jorator’s wound slowed down his charge, and the Isoltings struck him down. Although we held the field, we weren’t able to take any captives.

1340
The god-talkers said we should explore distant parts of Dragon Pass this year.

The Issaries priestess Sora Goodseller came to our clan and asked if we had any white horses to trade. We had no white horses. Embarrassed that we had no white horse, we gave her a feast instead.

Explorers encountered a bark-clad shaman who predicted that hunters would trespass against us, and then warned against a swarm of insects. We decided to find the shaman and offer to adopt him. They looked high and low for the shaman, but did not find him.

Enastarra, daughter of Dorasor and Ferena, went missing. Her parents thought she was at Clan Rangdani, in the company of a former suitor, Loricon. We demanded compensation from the Rangdani. They agreed to our demand.

We found Greenwing hunters poaching deep within our territory. They paid for their effrontery with their lives. We later learned that the Greenwings, who already hate us, were planning bloody vengeance on us.

Swen of the Greydog clan offered us gifts. We threw a feast for thanes of Swen’s clan. They toasted our generosity, and said they would speak of it to others. Our people made merry, and also toasted the clan ring.

Our herds dwindled, and the people grew restive. The ring members told them that we would sacrifice to Uralda. The people accepted this pledge.

1341
Eurmal laughed during Sacred Time, and said that misfortune would plague us until we replaced at least half of our clan ring.

We raided the Greenwings. We drove the Greenwings from the battlefield, and were able to plunder their tula.

Drought struck our lands. The spectre of starvation hovered over us. We sacrificed to Heler, but our pleas for help went unanswered.

Drought struck our lands. The spectre of starvation hovered over us. We went with Orlanth to help him free Heler from the dragon’s maw.

Venharl attempted the heroquest of Orlanth and Aroka. He was unable to enter the place of the gods. Enemies aided Daga and Aroka, and Heler remained imprisoned. Rain did not come.

Drought struck our lands. The spectre of starvation hovered over us. We sacrificed to Daga, the enemy god of Drought and Famine, hoping that he would show us mercy.

Rastorlanth and Inganna got divorced. Inganna made unreasonable claims on him for a settlement. Our lawspeaker argued that she was misusing the law. Inganna was affronted, and left for clan Jenestni, promising that they would take vengeance against us.

Glendara, a carl of our clan, said that her prize stallion, Tempest, had been stolen by Rangarda Dark-Eyes of the Greydog clan. Members of the clan ring tried to persuade her to forget the matter. She would not hear of it. “No argument can sway me, while that mangy, dug-dragging she-dog has my Tempest.” The clan ring offered her compensation. Glendara said, “It is not the trade value of Tempest that concerns me. It is the principle of the thing. By stealing my prize stallion, she has stolen my honor.” We launched a legal claim against Rangarda Dark-Eyes. We took our claim to her clan ring. Rangarda denied that she had anything to do with the disappearance of Glendara’s horse. Her clan leaders seemed to make an honest effort to determine the truth, but ultimately ruled that there was no evidence of wrongdoing on Rangarda’s part. Glendara was most displeased by this result.

1342
It was an auspicious year for heroquesting.

The sons and daughter of Glendara recovered the stallion called Tempest, which they found secreted away on the tula of the Greydog clan. They slew one of Rangarda Dark-Eye’s sons, and wounded another. We sent gifts to the Greydogs, to smooth relations with them. They praised us for our generous gesture, and gave us a reciprocal gift equal in value to our own. They said that we should consider the fighting between the families of Glendara and Rangarda as a personal matter, and one which would not interfere with the strong relations between our two clans.

Uralda cultists offered to perform a ritual to benefit our herds. We accepted their offer, and said we owed them a favor. They thanked us in kind, and said that the Kardarvi, which many of them belonged to, would one day take us up on that favor. They gathered up our cows and then walked around them seven times, whisking them with the Holy Tail. After performing a lowing dance, they pronounced the ritual complete. They departed, to the cheers and good wishes of the carls.

Starvation hit our clan.

Emissaries of the Rangdani clan sought our support in the Orlanth and Aroka heroquest. We sent a few worshippers to the ritual. Our worshippers enjoyed their lengthy pilgrimage to Orlanth’s holy place. The Rangdani’s Wind Lord was unable to complete the difficult quest, and their elders lamented what would doubtless be a continuing drought.

We saw a rainbow; the people were cheered by this good omen. Because we were lucky, we embarked on a raid.

We raided the Greenwings and eluded their patrols. Orlkensor, our war leader, took a serious wound and fell near Arene. She dominated the Greenwing warriors, just as Uralda dominated the bulls, and was able to heal Orlkensor. We drove the Greenwings from the battlefield, and were able to plunder their tula.

The White Horses raided us for 9 cows while we were raiding.

A couple from another clan offered to sell us Esra’s Basket. We paid what they asked. We put Esra’s Basket in a safe place.

The Greenwings raided us for 41 cows.

It all started out so well,
Cathal

entry.title: [Deleted]
entry.content: Here lay a review of Homestuck. The review was incoherent, and poorly-written, so I've deleted it and left a placeholder here. I'll try and write another, better review over the summer.

entry.title: Is Vernon Wells the Way Out of This Recession?
entry.content:
This is a serious question. Some background: Vernon Well is a baseball player, not a fantastic one, middle-of-the-range, capable of being both pretty good and downright awful. This year, Vernon Wells will have a base salary of 23 million dollars. There is no football player I can think of who makes such a high salary (top 25 in professional baseball), yet is such a terrible player. If you can think of one, consider him like Vernon Wells, and this post might be a lot easier to follow. But yes, between 2007 and 2014, Vernon Wells will have accumulated over 125 million dollars. This for a player who has not led his team to the playoffs once, and has made one All-Star appearance in that time. His base salary will only increase as the contract drags on, since it is back-loaded, yet he is not getting any younger and is unlikely to turn into Ted Williams any time soon.
