Despite all this, some team (the Angels) was actually desperate enough for alright-I-guess hitters to trade for this horrible contract, which got me to thinking: can Vernon Wells be harnessed for other things.

Can Vernon Wells be used to convince world markets that humans and corporations are still capable of the idiotic desperate spending that drives economic booms? "Look, we're paying this guy more than it cost to run Brawn GP when they won the World Championship, WE'LL BUY ANYTHING!!!" If used correctly, the Vernon Wells contract could solve so many problems: Vernon Wells could hire a massive training staff (not that it would help or anything), and slash American unemployment! Vernon Wells could fund the NEA! Vernon Wells could set up a PAC and run Pro-Steroids candidates for congress, thus giving him a chance to justify his salary! Vernon Wells could buy enough season tickets to sell out every Angels home game, and free up money for fans to spend on overpriced refreshments! Vernon Wells could bail out the struggling maple syrup industry in Vermont! Vernon Wells could run for Governor of California, and lift bans on performance-enhancing drugs! Vernon Wells could start his own network news channel, with a pro-Wells bias! The possibilities are endless, and the future is bright. Vernon Wells is your new bicycle.

Over the next four years, Vernon Wells will cost 86 million dollars, yet, unlike Cristiano Ronaldo, whose cost was in that ballpark, there is absolutely zero hope that Vernon Wells will make any real money for his team. For that 86 million dollars, you could do all sorts of things. Buy Leeds United, fund several successful films, buy the distribution rights to Hercules in New York, and so on. All of these things, even owning Leeds United, are better business moves than trading for Vernon Wells and The Contract. You could even run an F1 team for a couple of seasons. I understand people think you need to spend money to make money, but there are levels of desperation, and this is somehow more desperate than casting Matthew Modine in your movie.

I don't even have anywhere to go with this. I am simply bewildered by this unbelievably stupid decision, that may even yet outdo Attilio Lombardo's reign at Crystal Palace for reckless, wasteful spending.

I mean, Christ,
Cathal

entry.title: Cashing In
entry.content:
Sadly no, I'm not selling this address to a squatter and taking the euro he would give me to buy a pack of noodles (I have like 6 in the cupboard, so I don't even need any soon), although I might move it onto Ryan's (cpttremendous.com) hosting so I can have my own fancy URL, sans blogspot. That would be so sweet. For now though, I'm gonna keep it here (there was a brief foray into the world of Posterous, but I just couldn't abandon all my pageviews).

But all this talk about cashing in is just a handy in for the post I promised Frank about his band: Tony Stark, but also it allows me to write about why cheap cash-in games are damn stupid in the long run. But yeah, Frank's band, Tony Stark, which is more of a duo really (do you call duos bands? The wikipedia page about Chromeo indicates that you do not), although apparently Kevin serves as a kind of auxiliary guitarist, which means he might take them in directions interesting and left-field! They didn't call it Stark Industries, but Paddy said it was a pretty good name for a (probably vanity) label.

But as Frank has no doubt mentioned on his blog (My Awesome Hair and Me, the number 1 blog for people who were actually looking for weird but at the same time tame porn), his plan is to sell out and make it big. I'm not sure if you can actually make it that way any more, I mean even if you completely submit yourself to the tastes of the market, and actually sell a decent amount, unless you're already established (Eminem, whose last album was inexplicably popular), you're unlikely to see much money from it. And in addition to that, if you were stupid enough to sign one of those 360 deals, you'll see even less still (unless they've given you a vanity label, like Jay-Z, in which case you can make some money off whoever you've got on there, Cole and Electronica I think?).

But yeah, this leads into another thing: shitty licensed crap, man it frustrates me. And I'm not talking about Krusty Brand Eyewash, but like the things with real potential to a) solidify your fanbase and b) make mad Hamiltons yo. I mean, putting real money and effort into a licensed video game pays for itself man.

Take Goldeneye. That's still paying out over a decade down the line, they were even able to re-release it on the Wii, because they put the effort in when they made it, and ended up with an awesome product that everybody has fond memories of.

To make an example of this, in 1997, another licensed game was released: (actually, aside, Civil War Generals II came out in 1997. Fuck that game was amazing, and after CivNet, the first strategy game I played hotseat with my bro, although we never did finish it) The Crow: City of Angels. This isn't an ideal example, the movie wasn't hugely successful, but The Crow has always had a cult following. But man was it ever panned. GameRankings gives it a user score of 23.5% (Official Sega Saturn Magazine gave it a 67, and said "Best avoided", which seriously, a near 7/10 is "best avoided"? Game review ratings be fucked the fuck up. Like the conomy.), and if it were released on XBLA or VC or wherever, like maybe 2 people would buy it because of some /v/ thread. Even if there were a new Crow movie or product coming out (iirc, it was Blood Stone that prompted the GoldenEye remaster), this cheap licensed cash-in wouldn't get that delicious upscalifyin' goodness.

This is relevant mainly because two shows of which I am a fan, Friendship is Magic and Adventure Time, have had these licensed games suggested. Pen Ward, the creator of AT, actually posted some sketch art detailing what he'd like a DS Adventure Time game to be like, and it seemed pretty sweet. It was really just Finn punching things, but who doesn't like that? And the other, FiM, is pretty much perfect for an RPG in the vein of those Sailor Moon ones from the 90s (or even a visual novel, which I've seen screens of one someone started on in RenPy, but they're a couple of months old and no progress seems to have been made since). Yet, right now we're limited to some cheap flash games on their respective websites, and if there were to be full games made for it (most likely the DLC games you do find on the Live Arcade and the Network), they'd be some cheap pitiful shit, especially FiM, which would most likely be some god-awful horrible off-model crap (nothing new there then, ho ho ho).

This is to be expected though. One has grown accustomed to the myopia of film studios and networks with regards to game licensing. Although recently there have been some excellent licensed games (Toy Story 3 in particular, and also Scott Pilgrim, and Arkham Asylum. A good Batman game WAT IS DIS?), the prevailing trend is still that of a cheap cash-in with little effort, and you can find countless examples crowding the pre-owned vidya section of any merchant. But really, putting effort into it can increase the lifespan and revenue of a franchise. Even the cash-ins of a game franchise itself, like the karting game, can yield excellent results (Crash Team Racing, obv). Like people are still talking about the Toy Story 3 game, and it helps the franchise in the long run, since now, assuming the movies are over, a whole new revenue stream can be cultivated with loving care, and people are insanely hyped for Arkham City, which looks just insane, how HIGH do you even have to BE to come up with that.

That wraps it up, there isn't really a closing statement to be made that I can think of right now, although if one appears to me, I might edit this post after the fact to include it. Also, apparently WorldStar was closed down, and nothing of value was lost.

THE RUDEST,
Cathal

entry.title: Mornin' Bloggin'
entry.content: I don't know why I never had pancakes for breakfast before now. This is legitimately FRESH. So so good, with some ham on the side, OH GOD.

entry.title: A search unsuccessful, an opportunity missed
entry.content:
The title of this blog refers to James Blunt's latest album, which came out last November, and has a title I've forgotten (I do know, however, that his second album is called "All the Lost Souls"). I told Graw I'd give it a listen if I could find a download link, so I opened up google and typed in "James Blunt [album name I've forgotten] mediafire" and nothing came up, so it didn't happen. That's probably for the best, since it's a 45 minute long album, and while Blunt isn't as bad as Limp Bizkit or some other horrible metal act that people inexplicably cream themselves over (listening to people talk about metal is kind of like watching dudes compare their dicks, except kind of painful physically and mentally) but he's still pretty bad. So yeah, that's not happening, so as a result I'm listening to Das Racist on headphones with the volume way up to try and drown out "Mrs. Brown's Boys".

If you're not familiar with it, it's basically the Irish equivalent of Madea's Awkward Moralizing Against a Backdrop of Bad Comedy. It's got the same cross-dressing old lady, bad jokes, and jarring tone shift towards the end where suddenly there is time for an Important Moral, or Character Filibuster or something else that completely does not gel at all and is made worse than it actually is by the fact that this serious, dry moralizing is coming during a horrible comedy.

I might also watch Sonatine, which is this movie Beat Takeshi made before his motorcycle accident, so he still has facial expressions in it, but it's a movie where a yakuza, facing death, heads out to a beach to chill with his crew and await death. It's a weird, beautiful movie, and it also has a fantastic score from Joe Hisaishi. I'll probably cop that ish if it gets a European blu-ray release (see also: FLCL, still not entirely sure if that's dropping over here, although it's not a massive blow if it doesn't thanks to Mully), but right now I'll have to make do with the fansubbed dvd rip.

Also I've played two games today which are worth comment. The first, Spare Parts, is part (hurr durr) of EA's new interest in putting out mad fresh IPs, which is certainly a welcome change (theory: Like the HIMYM episode about the Blitz, there is a Curse of Shovelware and Franchise-Whoring that follows around publishers for whatever reason. Activision is the current holder of this curse). It's a co-op platformer (although it has single player), where you play as two robots tasked by SIMON PEGG SUPER COMPUTER with collecting some ship parts. I only played the trial, but it was solid. The platforming reminded me of early PS2 games, back when platformers still got made on the regular, and it has some nice design. I might pick it up next week to play with my bro, since apparently it has like 10 hours of gameplay, which YEAH!

The second game is ModNation Racers, which I picked up on eBay for a tenner, cos I was looking for a current-gen karting game with some couch multiplayer, but I got way more than I expected. Like LittleBigPlanet, it sells itself on the Play.Create.Share thing, where, in addition to the levels and characters and stuff that come with the game, you can also download USER-CREATED CONTENT!

LittleBigPlanet dropped the sack massively on this one. A) Browsing levels was an actual pain and B) 90% of the levels fell into 3 or 4 categories, and didn't do anything interesting. For every interesting level I found, like the one where you played a ninja infilitrating a castle, or where you played through Where the Wild Things Are, there were 100s of shitty SHARK DODGING!!! levels. The second one seems to have remedied this with www.lbp.me, and maybe if it still has Stephen Fry it might be worth it when the price drops. Also there are already dozens of KILL OBAMA!1! or equivalent levels, which is hilarious. THEY HAVE COMPLETELY DISCREDITED THE PRESIDENCY, NOW EVERYBODY ACCEPTS THE BIRTHER TRUTH!!! I'm all for expressing your political views, but surely an internet forum or a phone call to one of those talk radio shows is a better way of doing it than creating a level that maybe 2 people will play tops. (Out of curiosity, I searched Biden, but got nothing. Oh well...)

But back to ModNation Racers. Fuck yes, worthwhile user-created content in spades! You could, if so disposed, basically turn the game into [Franchise] Racer, since there are enough player-characters for say Mario or Bomberman to do that. It's actually really impressive, as are the karts. But the greatest thing is the track creator, which holy fuck it is fantastic, and you can completely dictate the computer's level of involvement. You can get it to auto-complete and -populate a track, or do the entire thing by hand, and it is very, very in-depth. Although it only has a limited number of environments, you can still bend it so you get something different every time. And this is just me dicking around with it for 15 minutes, who knows what it's true potential might be! It could be like the M.U.G.E.N. of karting games, but actually balanced! I even got Iron Man and Rayman and Finn and Jake. STEAK SAUCE!

That's all there is to blog about now. I'm working on an interactive fiction story, which I'll post the intro up here when I've made more progress. Also apologies to Graw if she reads this, I just could not find that James Bunting album. But yeah, Sonatine takes precedence over googling.

I stay lit like the tip on some incense,
Cathal

entry.title: A post about rap music
entry.content:
So I just realised yesterday it's been nearly 3 weeks since I've updated this, which means it was a week short of the inactive time that qualifies a blogspot blog Officially Dead. Actually though coming across a really personal blog that gets no comments and just stops is actually one of the saddest things on the internet, for my money anyway (Aside, where has Lie Bot been in Achewood, I can't even remember the last time he was around).

But anyway, to get back into it, I was wondering what would be the best way to isolate all my readers: A post about rap music? A post about ponies? Perhaps some combination of the two (insert horrible MC-[character name] puns or some such here)? Anyway I can devote slightly more time to blogging now, since my geography paper and the accompanying writer's block are now finished, and we can return to the long posts about insignificant minutiae.

The only thing of note I can think of is I was listening to Patton Oswalt around college yesterday and he had a line that summed up perfectly why I'm so apathetic about the new rappers XXL and all those shitty rap blogs are getting all excited about. It's a bit where he talks about why he loved open mic nights in the 80s.

"...and you got to see.... 1: People who were clearly gonna be good comedians, they had a point of view, they were struggling, they had something to say. 2: People who were funny, but who gives a shit?"

I mean I still listen to quite a lot of rap music. And there are "veterans" (I use that term loosely, I basically mean they've been around long enough that the industry can't pass them off as a "new act" at the Grammy Awards) like Madvillain and El-P and OutKast, who I'll browse as quickly as possible to wherever their new albums are available. But, except for Das Racist and maybe Yelawolf, the "new" rappers that everyone is excited about fall, for me, into Oswalt's second category. They're good and all, but it's just like "why should I care? You are not making me care. Make me care!" and then they fail to make me care.

I mean they can rap, they aren't lulzily bad like, say, Asher Roth or Chet Haze, the Tom Hanks offspring who is rapping about college, or Charles Hamilton, who is basically a more ridiculous Tyrone Biggums at this point, but they don't remind me of those guys who were really good for a brief period, like Das EFX or whatever, but more like the countless guys in the early- and mid-90s who were competent, but completely faceless and anonymous, like their career peak was having a guest verse with someone who was tangentially related to Death Row. It's sad, but I guess there's nothing to do about it except acknowledge it briefly, as I have just done.

I guess I could probably get something longer out of it, but the apathy is so great I can't even manage that.

Blah blah blah,
Cathal

entry.title: Sales and Bomberman
entry.content:
I'm pretty much blogging instead of working on my geography paper due in 2.5 weeks because it's coming together so slowly, whereas with a blog I can roll off 1,000 words in less than an hour, it's unreal.

I'd actually started a thing about Rapidshare and isolating users, since my Rapidshare Pro expired today, but there was no central point emerging, and it wasn't going anywhere, so it's in the recycle bin. Wait, it's been emptied, it's gone forever. It's probably for the best, since it was turning into a long thing about the TF2 Mann-conomy, which I think nobody but Fitzy even knows about. So I suppose the thing to fill the void left by the deletion of that formless post is a LIFE UPDATE, the first of the year, and maybe a throwback to the horrible first season of this blog, where every post was 2 sentences long and pretty boring. This is gonna buck the trend tho', in that I'm gonna pick up on things I notice and write at nauseating length about them. ALL VERBOSE UP IN THIS, GIRL.

The first thing is probably what I'm doing right now, which is listening to this awesome song, which you've probably heard, by Symphony of Science. Oh fuck, it's just so catchy, and Carl Sagan's hand movements in the wormholes section are just incredibly gangster. He was so hardcore. Apart from disproving the stoner stereotype (Carl Sagan smoked cannabis regularly, and was one of the greatest minds of the 20th century, in my opinion anyway), he also could speak beautifully about space. I mean that's downright beautiful right there, it's goddamned poetry. It's one of those songs I've been listening to on repeat recently. There are a few others, but right now this one is monopolizing my time. I have Cosmos lying around somewhere actually, so I'm gonna fire that up at some point, since Carl Sagan Does a Documentary about the Stars sounds like the best thing ever.

So far this year has been uneventful. The aforementioned geography paper moves forward with the speed of separating plates (HURR DURR), and I haven't hung with any of my top bros yet, although that may be changing tomorrow, as both Fitzy and Frank, as well as perhaps Ri, will be in Dundalk. Since the sales this year were honestly pretty shit (Amazon and Steam excepted, but it's a given that they'll deliver with their sales) and the one thing I did pick up, Super Street Fighter IV, was returned post-haste since it was a steaming pile of crap. Gamestop had a pretty tempting for 3-for-2 thing on preowned games on, but I couldn't even find 3 games at decent prices. I mean Backbreaker at €25 is a bit ridiculous, although once it gets cheaper I am going to pounce on that, brother, and the prices combined with the GameStop returns policy meant my wallet did not throw up some money to it.

I did buy a couple of things in the Steam and PSN sales though. I got that recent Bomberman Ultra, for the multiplaya (up to 7-player local, fuck yes HudsonSoft!), and all the Half-Life stuff I did not yet own (Episode 2, Deathmatch, and Blue Shift/Opposing Force for the first one). Altogether it came to 7 euro for all of that, which you couldn't even find something that cheap in Gamestop, unless it was maybe Shaq Fu for the Jaguar or something. Overall though, I didn't get that much in this Steam sale. I bought the 2 Humble Bundles, and Super Meat Boy and Sam and Max season 3, which were both something like 70% off.

But Bomberman is holy good. I was gonna hold off and wait for Battlefest to come out, but a quick visit to the Metacritic showed its reviews were none too hot, while Bomberman Ultra, the current PS3 iteration, had a healthy 84. This is the first time I've played old school Bomberman since I was 6, but IT'S SO ADDICTIVE. Plus it's got 7p couch multiplayer, which FUCK YES THIS IS EXACTLY WHAT I WANTED. This has completely wiped from my memory Bomberman: Act Zero, probably the lulziest grimdark shit ever made (it manages to be worse than Loonatics: Unleashed, which a full episode needs to be watched to appreciate how bad it is). It also has a mad variety of nice novelty costumes, all of which gel perfectly with the classic Bomberman design.

(Aside about Act Zero: It's perfectly possible to make a really good story with well-rounded characters of what might seem like ridiculous and slight material (e.g.: Sonic SatAM, and Friendship is Magic, two shows that seem horrible on paper, but are both extremely good), and you could make a really enjoyable animated series out of Bomberman, but Act Zero just drops the ball horribly. I'll write about this more at a later point.)

That's pretty much all the major stuff. I've started cycling again, and I'm rewatching Planet Earth in 1080i, because who the fuck can get enough of all dat nature. UMMMMPPPPPH. I'm watching the Big Fat Quiz right now actually, goddamn this is hilarious, Richard Ayoade is so goddamned awesome.

Bomb up!,
Cathal

entry.title: The year in statistics: A review of My Ace Hen's first year through numbers
entry.content:
So 2010 is over, which means that my blog as a regularly updated web entity has had a year in existence (Well, not a full year, but like, most of 2010). I wasn't sure what I wanted the first post of 2011 to be, so I decided to cop-out and have a look at the last year statistically. In a word, it was:

Not particularly remarkable, I didn't break 1,000 page views, and probably the only remaining Yahoo! Browser user in the world visited a couple of times, but anyway, I'm just gonna put it out here for posterity, and also to show off my e-peen.

1) Pageviews by Country

This was pretty weird. As expected, Ireland was the main source of pageviews, but really confusing are the small countries, and also Denmark, which all of those views are from the last 2 days. I can explain within reason where the American, Latvian, and British views came from, but where did the rest come from? I be at a serious loss, but also maybe it means I'd fit in well in Denmark.

2) Pageviews by Operating System


This one isn't really surprising at all. Windows dominates, natch, and Mac's audience share here is within +/- 1% of the actual figure. Linux is a lot higher than expected though, and portable devices (mostly iOS, although apparently someone browsed here on a PSP) are lower, but do people read blogs on portable devices? It would've been sweet if it had a more detailed breakdown of Windows by version, just to see how many dudes are still on that Vista ish, but it's still cool.

3) Pageviews by Browser

This is the one where the audience share here has the greatest deviation from usage share in general. Internet Explorer is the biggest here, but its share is about 12% lower, while Firefox has a 2 point bump, and Chrome gets the biggest bump of all, with 29%, whereas the actual usage share is 12.4%. Safari and Opera are a lot smaller with share, Safari's is half its actual size, while Opera (actual figure 2%) didn't even get enough pageviews to warrant a single %.

4) Pageviews by month (July-December)

Nothing surprising here, when I completely stopped blogging in mid-August, until I resumed in November, traffic plummeted. Although still 50+ views when there's absolutely nothing to see is surprising.

5) Other things of interest

a) Most Read Posts

63 pageviews - 2010: The Musics
http://myacehen.blogspot.com/2010/12/2010-musics.html

26 pageviews - 2010: The Motion Pictures
http://myacehen.blogspot.com/2010/12/2010-motion-pictures.html

14 pageviews - Christine's Gaff
http://myacehen.blogspot.com/2010/07/christines-gaff.html

14 pageviews - On the changing nature of birthday celebrations
http://myacehen.blogspot.com/2010/11/on-changing-nature-of-birthday.html

13 pageviews - Takeaway
http://myacehen.blogspot.com/2010/08/takeaway.html

b) Top search terms

1. my ace hen
2. thesandthesea.blogspot
3. a couple days
4. "i fucked the moon"
5. a couple days back i was
6. "relaxation of the asshole" site: blogspot.com
7. acehen
8. blog thesandthesea blogspot
9. darver blessing of graves 2010
10. jar of jam ton of bricks

Again, nothing of interest. But to the Bob Pollard fans who were looking for download links and found my blog instead, I'm sorry man.

That's pretty much it in terms of stuff that won't bore you to death. Admittedly, a completely pointless post, but I thought it was interesting, plus I got to make shitty pie charts!

SCIENCE,
Cathal

entry.title: 2011: Things to Be Excited About
entry.content:
2010 posts done wrapped up here, so I'm gonna turn to 2011, and this post is just things scheduled to be released in 2011 about which I am pretty damn excited.

The Pale King - David Foster Wallace (Novel)
This is probably the thing I'm most pumped up for. DFW is certainly my favourite author, and he was just a flat-out phenomenal author. He wrote the best novel of the '90s, Infinite Jest, as well as some of the best essays I've ever read (Up, Simba is probably my favourite), and when he died he was working on a novel that is, if I recall correctly, about tax accountants who discover a deep secret to life. The excerpts that have been published so far (mostly in The New Yorker, I think) have been phenomenal, especially Good People. Supposedly only about 400 pages of it is finished, and the rest is gonna be notes, but I have faith it will be awesome, since Michael Pietsch is overseeing the whole thing, which should keep it great and close to the original vision.

Habibi - Craig Thompson (Graphic Novel)
I don't know a lot about this, other than it's a love story between a eunuch and a prostitute. But it's by Craig Thompson, whose previous graphic novel, Blankets, was really beautiful. I like old middle-eastern architecture a bit, so it should look nice at the least. Hopefully it can be as awesome as his last book was.

Avatar: Legend of Korra (TV Show)
This is a miniseries, which means at least there's no risk of it being cancelled before the ending is reached. This is a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender, which I've blogged about before, and this has the same creative team of "Byrke" behind it. Apart from the really intriguing steampunk setting of Republic City, and also some exploration of anti-bending (I'm really hoping it turns out the cabbage merchant started it all, but that might be a bit too cute, plus did he even know the Gaang was led by the Avatar), but also it makes long-lasting Kataang canon. The concept art also looks badass, and The Track Team is back doing the soundtrack, so everything is in line for one of the best shows of the year.

Game of Thrones (TV Show)
I ain't know a whole lot about this to be honest, but HBO getting into fantasy, especially getting into it with such a good series is excellent. It's also got a great cast, Lena Headey, Peter Dinklage, Sean Bean, plus David Benioff and Dan Weiss are writing, so it should be at the very least entertaining.

Source Code (Film)
Another thing I ain't know a whole lot about, but Duncan Jones + Jake Gyllenhaal = High Potential for Fucking Awesome.

Moneyball (Film)
I kind of want to see what Soderbergh would have done with this, especially the animated Bill James segments I heard so much. Anyway this is based on the book about Billy Beane using Sabermetrics to build a cost-effective baseball team. Aaron Sorkin is writing it now, and Bennett Miller is directing, and they've assembled a great cast, including Philip Seymour Hoffman and Brad Pitt, so this could be as good as The Social Network was.

Portal 2 (Video Game)
It's like the first Portal, but longer, and with Wheatley the charming English personality core! Plus the people behind Tag: The Power of Paint are working on it, which oh fuck. Plus it's Valve. ALL SIGNS POINT TO AMAZING.

The Last Guardian (Video Game)
I can't really write much about a lot of the things on this list. The Last Guardian is no exception. So I'll just say, TEAM ICO ON THE PS3, YOU KNOW YOU FUCKING WANT THIS.

A new Madvillain album (Music)
This is coming out in 2011, right? IT JUST HAS TO? It's been way too long since Madvillainy, and that remix album was just not enough. I really dug the song they did for the Adult Swim Singles Project, and I mean if it's even half as awesome as the first one, it'll be out of sight of any chain that it could be attached to.

A new El-P album (Music)
I think this is scheduled to come out in 2011. He even has a blog for it (www.cancer4cure.blogspot.com), although he doesn't really update it that much. I really liked the song he did for the last Def Jux compilation, and all the shit he's been doing lately in general (in particular, the Young Jeezy remix, the Das Racist guest verse, and How to Serve Man), so I mean again if it's up to the work he's done lately, it'll cruise to Best Album of 2011.

Things I'm excited about, but there's a good chance they might suck
SSX: Deadly Descents (Video Game)
FUCK YEAH A NEW SSX GAME, EA YOU ARE THE BEST PUBLISHER EVER. That was my first reaction when some new SSX urls were trademarked. All those glorious colours in HD, my brain was melting at the prospect, but then I saw the trailer. Which, eh...

It looked like Call of Duty. FUCK NO EA THIS ISN'T WHAT I WANTED. They've gotten rid of the beautifully designed, exaggerated circuits and replaced them with real mountains, which is a pretty sweet concept, but I mean if they go grimdark with this...

But hey, it's from the Skate 3 devs, and although I don't think the analog-stick trick system will work as well here, I have faith in their abilities. I just hope it's not misplaced.

The Looney Tunes Show (TV Show)
The small amount of dudes on DeviantArt losing their shit over the Lola redesign was hilarious. But aside from that, I mean this sounds interesting. The Looney Tunes would work well in a sitcom setting, and although John K. isn't working on it anymore, hopefully it will preserve some of his spirit. The redesigns look pretty good for the most part too, apart from the whole 3D Roadrunner and Coyote shorts, which FIRE THE PERSON WHO CAME UP WITH THAT.

That's pretty much it. 12 things to look forward to in 2011. I'm expecting at least 10 of them will be awesome, I'm still not sure about the direction the new SSX is taking. WHERE MY MOBY AND MAC AT? But still, it's a lot to look forward to.

See y'all next year,
Cathal

entry.title: Some New Years Resolutions, which hint at the possibility of drastic change.
entry.content:
So 2010 is pretty much over so it is time for the most broken of all resolutions, the New Years ones. These are being posted here for posterity anyway:

1. Lose some weight, get in shape
2. Get a decent average in my exams this year
3. Be a more awesome bro

I'm limiting it to three, but 1 and 3 are pretty broad and open to interpretation. But there it is anyway, FOR POSTERITY.

Bully!,
Cathal
