entry.title: 2010: The Motion Pictures
entry.content:
So we've come to the end of this exciting 3 day ride. This year was pretty good for films actually, Inception made a shit load of money, and Sorkin and Fincher had a glorious team-up. Other chill shit happened too, bro, but I didn't make it to the cinema as often as I did in previous years. But anyway, let's move right on to My Ace Hen's Best Motion Pictures of This Calendar Year, Being the Two Thousandth and Tenth Year of Our Lord. The post will probably be a bit shorter than the other four, and before the year is out I'll also be doing a RESOLUTIONS post, a MISCELLANEOUS AWARDS UNRELATED TO THE PREVIOUS FOUR CATEGORIES post, and an EXCITING THINGS IN 2011 POST

5. Scott Pilgrim vs. the World (dir. Edgar Wright)
Going into 2010, I hadn't really experienced any Sorkin at all, so I wasn't excited about The Social Network. The main film I was pumped for was this one, where Edgar Wright was adapting a Canadian comic I hadn't read or heard of before, but hey, it was Edgar F. Wright, it had to be good?

Oh fuck it was. I actually went out onto the internet and found the comics in .cbr format, and read them the day before I went to see it, and lord I wasn't disappointed on either count. Although the comics have pretty extreme SAMEFACE, they're pretty funny, but the film went above and beyond that (unlike a certain OTHER adaptation of an awesome thing, M. Night, what up?), and had some great acting, choreography, music, and cinematography. It's just a pretty awesome film all around, and y'know, I'm guessing if you read this blog you've already seen it, but if you haven't, go watch it anyway.

4. Toy Story 3 (dir. Lee Unkrich)
I don't really need to say much here. More of the same Toy Story you know and love, with added sad moments and Michael Keaton. Fuck yeah.

3. The Town (dir. Ben Affleck)
Ben Affleck? More like Ben Awesome! Although he was sort of a byword for shitty movies during a lot of the 2000s, I really think Affleck is one of the best directors going today. Sure he's only made 2 films, but they were both fucking great. Like the last one, Gone, Baby Gone, this is a thriller set in Boston, but it's got an even better cast. Jon Hamm! Chris Cooper! Blake Lively! Jeremy Renner! Affleck himself! It's a film I can't write about extensively without giving away too much, but if you liked those old thrillers from the 70s and late 60s, then peep this ish, brother.

2. Inception (dir. Christopher Nolan)
Or, the film where there wasn't really a twist, but everyone assumed and insisted there was one. This is, for my George Wash onna dosh, the best film Nolan's ever done, better even than Memento. Apart from the gully cast typical of a Nolan film (DiCaprio, Hardy, Murphy, Cotilliard, Watanabe, Caine, Page, Berenger, Postlethwaite, Gordon-Levitt), this also features his best set-pieces. The snow fortress!, The van!, The chase!, holy fuck they're all so good. This film, as you may already know, concerns dudes who go inside brains and perform theft, basically. Again, I can't give away too much, but that's mostly because I can't do this justice. It's got an incredible protagonist, and a great supporting cast (Eames is mai husbando), a really nice score from Hans Zimmer, and some kickass action, and beautiful cinematography from Wally Pfister. I copped the blu-ray of this one, and fuck it looks downright beautiful. I'm pretty sure all my regular readers have seen it, but y'all needs to rewatch it, it rewards that kind of behaviour.

1. The Social Network (dir. David Fincher)
Fuck. This is an embellished tale of the founding of Facebook. A lot of tech writers got themselves into a frenzy about this one, replicating the exact kind of behaviour they criticize old media writers of (one in particular attempted to give a complete analysis of the film's Mark Zuckerberg, while admitting to having not seen it. Way to go, idiot.), which I found infinitely entertaining, just like the film itself.

2010 was the year in which I discovered Aaron Sorkin, writer of A Few Good Men, Charlie Wilson's War, The West Wing, The American President, and Sports Night, to name his best, and The Social Network punches at their weight. It's got the same amazing dialogue typical of his work, and it meshes beautifully with the Fincher's faultless style. This is a film I could rewatch again and again and again, and although if one were to describe it, it might sound cliche (HE INVENTS A TOOL TO BRING PEOPLE TOGETHER, BUT HE HAS NO FRIENDS, et cetera) but typical of both Sorkin and Fincher at their best, this is truly transcendent. I mean this just blew me away 110%, FUCK. The acting is also incredibly impressive too, not least Armie Hammer (who I'd kind of written off as a dolt before this, because of the Justice League and Billy Graham films) and Justin Timberlake, who absolutely shines as a Sean Parker who is nothing like the real Sean Parker. I'm going to reserve a longer, more in-depth analysis of this film for when I cop the blu-ray in spring, but until then, I can only encourage that you watch this in the strongest possible terms. This is real fucking cinema.

HONOURABLE MENTIONS
How to Train Your Dragon
Kick-Ass
Easy A

HOW THE FUCK COULD YOU FUCK UP SUCH GREAT SOURCE MATERIAL, or, PROOF THAT UNBREAKABLE WAS JUST A FLUKE
The Last Airbender

OTHER FILMS THAT SUCKED REALLY HARD
Alice in Wonderland
The Edge of Darkness
For Colored Girls
Alpha and Omega

FILMS THAT WERE BALLS TO THE WALL AWESOME, BUT CAN'T BE INCLUDED BECAUSE OF STAGGERED INTERNATIONAL RELEASE DATES
A Prophet
The Secret of Kells
Summer Wars

FILMS I WANT TO SEE, BUT I HAVE YET TO EXPERIENCE THEM
Blue Valentine
Winter's Bone
Black Swan

That about wraps it up, again, if there's any films you dug that I missed, message or comment with them, and I'll check 'em out.

That's a wrap,
Cathal

entry.title: 2010: The Serialized Photoplays
entry.content:
This is the second last of my 2010 IN REVIEW series. The last one about music blew up, receiving over 50 hits from Denmark, but I'm not sure what to read into that. But anyway, this is the penultimate, and (it could be, we'll see how it pans out) the best of the four. Michelles and Obamas, My Ace Hen's 2010 Serialized Photoplays. I'm gonna limit my list to shows that debuted in 2010, and Boardwalk Empire and Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt aren't on here because I haven't watched it. This will be two separate posts anyway, one for TV (this one), and the next one for the movies. DON'T TOUCH THAT SET.

BEST TELEVISION SERIES
5. Hardy Bucks (RTE)
This one gets in mostly because I kind of skipped over the whole batch of new shows that came in this year. I mostly just caught up on new cartoons, and as a result 3 of the 5 shows on this list are animated. But hey, the actual review. There isn't a whole lot to say about this, since I can't really describe it. Irish Trailer Park Boys maybe? You can probably watch the whole thing on youtube anyway, since RTE really dropped the ball with this one, like they always do with a good show. It's not up there with The Modest Adventures of David O'Doherty, but it sure beats Katharine Lynch or the fucking Panel.

4. Regular Show (Cartoon Network)
Another show that it's hard to write about at length. Cartoon Network actually redeemed themselves a lot with their new batch of shows. Between this and Sym-Bionic Titan and my number one new show of the year, they've got a great line-up of new shows. There's a new Ben10 thing too, but I don't really care about that.

Anyway, Regular Show is a "sitcom" done by J.G. Quintel, who worked on The Marvelous Misadventures of Flapjack which is a pretty awesome show in itself, although it was screwed by the network pretty hard. It's also got Mark Hamill voicing a yeti, and is about two 23-year old slackers, a raccoon, and a blue jay, pretty much just fucking shit up. It doesn't sound great on paper, but heck is it funny. It's got a nice style to it too, as well as a kick-ass soundtrack. It's already in Season 2, but I mean there wasn't even a break between seasons 1 and 2, so it's questionable whether you should divide them. But hey, you should watch it. HMM-MMM-HMM

3. My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic (The Hub)
I feel weird putting this at number 3, and admittedly it might only be getting such a high placing because it exceeded my expectations, which they were higher for the new Weezer album than for this, but, to use my catchphrase with some self-awareness, IT'S SOOOOO GUD. I don't know a damn thing about My Little Pony other than the shows used to be the worst thing on TV outside of Mr. Blobby, but goddamn.

Anyway, in another extension of the mid-'00s Cartoon Network talent tree, this show is run by Lauren Faust, who worked on PowerPuff Girls and Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends. Although the show has a pretty nice art style, it really survives on the strength of its writing, and also an impressively well-rounded cast of characters. You can watch the entire thing at http://www.youtube.com/pensivepony although their account has been taken down once before, but I'll edit this post as it moves around. Also the first episode is a 2-parter, and although it's pretty good, and establishes a nice, epic mythology, along with hammering in the theme of the show (FRIENDSHIP IS TOTALLY GREAT, WOW. Yeah the show tends to drive it's Aesop home in the last minute of a show, and although it's way ahead of the curve for quality of such things, it still grates occasionally), but it's not really representative of the show as a whole, which is more a light comedy than a dark adventure story. But whatevz, check this sweet shit out.

2. The Walking Dead (AMC)
Frank Darabont runs a sweet show about some dudes going across the U.S. of A. after a zombie apocalypse. It's got awesome visuals and dodgy accents, so check this shit out.

1. Adventure Time with Finn & Jake (Cartoon Network)
Oh fuck this show is amazing. Some dude on tvtropes described it pretty well: it's just a pretty fantastical D&D campaign. Basically, the theme song describes the show pretty well:

Adventure Time,
come on grab your friends
we'll go to very distant lands,
with Jake the Dog,
and Finn the Human,
the fun will never end,
it's Adventure Time!

So it's about a shapeshifting dog who has a Bill Murray thing going on, a fervently LAWFUL GOOD 12-year old boy, with an awesome hat, adventuring across the post-apocalyptic continent of Ooo. There's also the most sympathetic kidnapper ever, the Ice King, who just oh man he is just so sad. The supporting cast is great too, there's Marceline the Vampire Queen, Princess Bubblegum, Lumpy Space Princess, everyone else. It's beautifully drawn, and has some kick-ass songs to boot (outside of the theme tune, my favourite is probably There Go Our Boys, which man it is catchy. OH MARCELIIIIIINE, WHY ARE YOU SO MEAN?) and is probably the only case in human history where Rule 63 was invoked without being creepy. This show is funny, moving, exciting, and, at times, kind of disturbing ("I'm your guardian angel, Finn": nightmares, man). I'm pretty sure it's on iTunes if you're into paying for things, if not you can probably find it on the internet somewhere, although that might take a while, and if that fails, just ask me for the episodes of this insanely baller piece of work.

HONOURABLE MENTION
Louie
Children's Hospital

BEST CONTINUING SERIES
The Venture Bros.
Mad Men
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia

BEST CLUSTERFUCK
Happy Town

MOST PRETENTIOUS PIECE OF SHIT
Gravity

THE SHOW I WILL MISS THE MOST
Party Down

But that's about it, again, if there are any new shows I missed or whatever, tell me about them.

And I am into it,
Cathal

entry.title: 2010: The Musics
entry.content:
Between watching My Little Pony, looking at palaeontology notes, and playing Democracy 2 (I swear I'm somehow getting worse at it), it's taken me until now to realise that I have 3 2010-in-review posts (music, films, tv) to get done in less than 2 days.

So fuck it, even though nobody read the last time I did several posts in a day (the result of a late caffeine-fuelled conversation with Darver, which I paid for heavily the next day), y'all gonna get more My Ace Hen than you will ever want. So, music, yeah. I listened to a fair few 2010 albums this year, and so far only one I'm looking forward to is still untouched (Panty Stocking OST), and I have a handful of 2010 albums on my laptop but none were quite good enough to make the list, so I'm just gonna skip them altogether.

So, without further delay, My Ace Hen's Top 5 Objectively Good Albums of 2010 and Also the Albums That Sucked Really Fucking Hard and You Should Feel Bad for Liking Them

5. Bob Dylan - The Bootleg Series Volume 9 (Columbia)
I actually deliberated for a while over what would take the fifth spot on this list, but then I remembered the Witmark Demos were officially released this year, remastered and all, and I couldn't put anything else here. I don't actually have the official version, rather I'm reviewing the old ass bootleg put out by Capricorn. Basically this release is Dylan's early demos for his first 2 publishing companies, Leeds and Witmark. There are a lot of familiar songs here, Hard Rain, Mr. Tambourine Man, et cetera. It's also got another version of Tomorrow is a Long Time, which is my favourite Dylan song of all. It's a beautiful collection indeed, and you can get with it a live concert he did at Brandeis university around the same time. But people kind of zone out when I start talking about Dylan, so just buy/download the thing or whatever it is you do when you want new music, this shit be worth it.

4. Broken Social Scene - Forgiveness Rock Record (Arts & Crafts)
This was the one that took me most by surprise. I'd only listened to a bit of Broken Social Scene before I heard this, and I thought it was pretty good yeah, but I never got around to listening to each album and E.P. through from start to finish. But regardless, I downloaded this and gave it a spin, to celebrate the start of my summer (I downloaded it the day my exams finished, if I recall correctly) and I was blown away. The first song. World Sick, was fucking phenomenal, and it only got better from there. Forced to Love, Art House Director, Sentimental Xs, Water in Hell, Texico Bitches, this album is packed with classics. I mean I can't really do them in justice in a short paragraph or two, so just cop this ish, as it is off the fucking chain.

3. Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross - The Social Network (The Null Corporation)
One of the best fucking films of the year, with one of the best soundtracks. Aaron Sorkin, David Fincher, and Trent Reznor teaming up for an trifecta of totally terrifyingly terrific. I can't write a whole lot about it, but this is a fucking beautiful piece of work. It's got kick-ass tracks like Hand Covers Bruise and In Motion, but it's also got the best rendition of In the Hall of the Mountain King I've ever heard (incidentally, it was one of the first classical pieces I ever heard). It's also further proof that Reznor needs to ditch the Nine Inch Nails shit and focus more on being one of the best composers and musicians of the last 30 years.

2. Das Racist - Sit Down, Man (МИШКА)
I was pretty skeptical about Das Racist at the start of this year. All I knew about them was that fucking song, Combination Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, which is just fucking awful. But then, positive news! They got some great producers on board and El-P was giving them praise, and then I played the video for Who's That, Brooown? and I was suddenly really excited. It then took me a while for a good quality link to come up, and so I gave it a listen.

HOLY FUCKING SHIT!!!!

Unlike some of the other rap albums I had listened to up to that point (I slept on the ones from Rhymefest and Clipse, who I really liked a few years ago) (I'm looking in your direction Eminem and Jay-Z), this one was fucking immense. I mean I thought Shut Up, Dude was good, it had You Oughta Know, and Rainbow in the Dark and a few other quality tracks, but this one just blew me away. Unlike with Jay Electronica, who when he started getting attention got me really hyped up, but then spent pretty much all of 2010 letting me down, Das Racist just exceeded my expectations, while at the same time continually raising the bar. The rapping is immense, and the beats are phenomenal, and I find something new every time I listen to it. It's also got that beautiful rarity, the El-P guest verse, and that alone would make it worth a cop, but seriously, fucking amazing, get this shit.

1. Emancipator - Safe in the Steep Cliffs (Emancipator Music)
Emancipator is this dude in his early 20s called Douglas Appling who plays most of the instruments on this entirely instrumental album. His first, Soon It Will Be Cold Enough to Build Fires, was really fucking good, and had a beautiful guest vocal from someone whose name I don't know on When I Go, but the only problem I had with it was I felt the drums were weak. Well it's like Emancipator was reading my mind, because this one fixed that, and is near perfect. Seriously,it's joined Music for Airports and Wozzeck, in Triumvirate of Perfect Music. There are not enough superlatives for this, it's absolutely amazing.

Other Really Great Albums I Listened to That Missed the Top Five
Neil Young - Le Noise
Kanye West - My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy
Janelle Monae - The ArchAndroid (Suites II and III)
Gorillaz - Plastic Beach
Hans Zimmer - Inception
Brian Eno - Small Craft on a Milk Sea
Gil Scott-Heron - I'm New Here
The National - High Violet
MGMT - Congratulations
LCD Soundsystem - This is Happening
Ghostface Killah - Apollo Kids
Robert Pollard - We All Got Out of the Army
Boston Spaceships - Our Cubehouse Still Rocks
The Gaslight Anthem - American Slang
El-P - weareallgoingtoburninhellmegamixx3
Camu Tao - King of Hearts
Arcade Fire - The Suburbs
Aloe Blacc - Good Things
Das Racist - Shut Up, Dude
Big Boi - Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty
The Magnetic Fields - Realism
Sufjan Stevens - The Age of Adz
Daft Punk - Tron: Legacy
John Legend and The Roots - Wake Up!
Baths - Cerulean
Flying Lotus - Cosmogramma
Titus Andronicus - The Monitor

WORST FUCKING ALBUMS OF THE YEAR FUCK HOW DOES AN ALBUM SUCK THIS HARD
Eminem - Recovery
M.I.A. - /\/\ /\ Y /\


MOSTLY PRETTY BAD, BUT A COUPLE OF GOOD SONGS TO EVEN THINGS OUT
Jay-Z - The Blueprint 3

ALBUMS THAT SUCKED REALLY HARD, BUT I HAD LOW EXPECTATIONS TO BEGIN WITH
Kings of Leon - Come Around Sundown
My Chemical Romance - Danger Days: The True Lives of the Fabulous Killjoys
Drake - Thank Me Later
Nicki Minaj - Pink Friday
Weezer - Hurley

FUNNIEST MOMENT OF THE YEAR BY A MUSIC BLOG
Hipster Runoff's long shit-fit about MGMT getting a 6.something from Pitchfork, and how this completely destroyed their credibility.

BEST INDIVIDUAL SONG OF THE YEAR
Aloe Blacc - I Need a Dollar

PROBABLY FOR THE BEST HE DELAYED THE ALBUM, or, WORST SONG OF THE YEAR AWARD
Dr. Dre and Jay-Z - Under Pressure

DIDN'T PUT OUT AN ALBUM THIS YEAR, EVEN THOUGH IT WAS THE PERFECT TIME TO
Jay Electronica

LONG OVERDUE REISSUES OF FUCKING AWESOME ALBUMS
Weezer - Pinkerton
Company Flow - Funcrusher Plus

MOST MISSED RECORD LABEL
Definitive Jux

BEST 4CHAN COMPILATION
SnowLevel

That's about it, if there's any albums I left out, tell me about them, but there's a chance that I might have listened to them and simply found them alright (e.g., Nas & Damien Marley, Reflection Eternal) but hey maybe I'll find something awesome thanks to YOU, THE READER.

Ding-a-ling,
Cathal

entry.title: 2010: The Vidya
entry.content:
With 2010 music, I listened to enough albums that even doing a short paragraph on each of them would be unfeasible. I mean I'll still ascribe arbitrary numerical values to their quality and all, but only my top ones will get any inches, plus I'll write about Pinkerton and Funcrusher Plus, two awesome albums that were reissued this year. But yeah, this one is all about the vidya, and all mentioned here are either on the ps3 or PC, since although I did briefly play a Dreamcast this year, I don't really want to talk about my failures as a roller coaster tycoon. Also I'll rag on Ubisoft a bit for a couple of reasons. In brackets be the console I experienced that particular vidya on.

TOP 5 GAMES OF 2010
5. Pac-Man Championship Edition DX (PS3)
I heard about this one somehow, and at first I was a bit skeptical. "Pac-Man?", I said, sure I can play that on Google. But hey, I thought, maybe I should give it a go, I mean once a classic, always a classic (Shakespeare in Love excepted, what did dudes see in that way back when?), right? So yeah I downloaded the demo and well HOLY FUCKBALLS THIS IS THE BEST GAME EVER I thought. Sure enough it went on sale around Christmas, and I bought the full version on PSN. IT IS SOMEHOW EVEN BETTER HOW IS THIS EVEN POSSIBLE I thought. I mean it wouldn't be really interesting to go into what the game actually has, it basically manages to be History of Pac-Man somehow, and has got mad modes and mazes and graphical mods and music. But I think Fortenbro said it better than I could on his twitter:

"OH GOD I'M TRIPPING BALLS FUCKING PAC MAN CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION DX"

4. Yakuza 3 (PS3)
This game/series wasn't on my radar at all going into 2010, but then slowly momentum started to build. Places like 1up were creaming topical like cortisone about it, and Fortengard was talking about how baller it was. I still wasn't planning on getting it any time soon, but then HMV had it on sale for an absolutely great €20. I picked that shit up and ended up playing this awesome beat-'em-up/RPG hybrid about a yakuza who now runs an orphanage! Some of his orphans bugged me at first, but damn this game develops its characters. Even that massive dick Mine was humanized by the end.

It also features mad side-quests, like taking creepy chicks out on dates (they ALL text you I LOVE YOU after like one fucking day, what the fuck man?), playing golf with a local politician, playing baseball to teach a prima donna former star a lesson, playing some old Sega games, and what was probably my favourite part, the blogging sidequest, where some complete weeaboo American dude shows you how to learn new moves through the awesome power of blogging. CAN YOU RELATE?


3. Sly Trilogy (PS3)
This is part of Sony's newfangled CLASSICS HD line, where PS2 games are given a spit-shine and reissued, lemony fresh, into the modern world. Although you could cynically dismiss it, given Sony's removal of PS2 backward compatibility from later editions of the PS3, it's still pretty sweet to have an awesome collection of games on one disc. That they don't retail for full price helps too. So far they've put out the God of War collection and the Sly Trilogy, and I think next year they're putting out a Team Ico collection, presumably to drum up excitement for The Last Guardian (which oh fuck how baller will that be?).

But yeah, Sly Cooper was this awesome crazy fun series of platformers back in the halcyon PS2 days, and it was kind of lumped in with the titans of PS2 platforming, Jak & Daxter, and Ratchet & Clank (they had the same devs as Crash and Spyro on the PS1 respectively. When the new devs showed up for those franchises, man did they start to stink quick. See: Enter the Dragonfly) but it didn't really have the same sales as they did, so it kind of faded from memory it seems.

It's back, though, and it's KICKING ASS. It has some Move support, but since I don't have Move I can't comment. The main feature is dem HD graphics. Although the cutscenes still take place in SD, the actual action looks damned beautiful. That's all there really is to it, the gameplay's still the same, and the dialogue is still kind of awkward (characters are pretty much always referred to by their full name, e.g. Agent Carmelita Fox, even though the characters should be familiar enough with her that Agent Fox or Fox or Carmelita would do), but hey, overall it's pretty gully.

2. Super Meat Boy (PC)
Of the four games on this list that have an ending, Super Meat Boy is the one where I'm furthest away (I've finished Yakuza 3 and the next game on the list I'm not naming yet, SUSPENSE) but holy fuck what I've played is great. It's a 2d platformer with 100s of levels, but each one has a unique aspect, and the game is fucking hard too. It's normally €13 on Steam, which I mean is a bit steep when you consider it was available for €3.50 during the Steam Christmas sale, and holy fuck it was a well spent three-and-a-half quid.

1. Civilization V (PC)
The motherfucking ownage game of the year. Fuck. This was the game I was really excited for going into this year, since like I'd been a Civ fan since I was 10 or something, and Civ IV was just such unbelievable ownage. A lot of people on CivFanatics were worried that it was going to be too much like Civ:Rev, that PS3 game which didn't have hotseat multiplayer even though it was ideal fuck. I mean there's not a whole lot to write about, it's classic Civ but better! Although I haven't figured out how to get geographically accurate starts yet, which kind of bugs me (Aztecs in Russia! Japan in Africa! China in China which was the only accurate one I saw in the course of my American game) but I mean it's still awesome.

I was at one point going to write a long thing about how my nation developed, which is one of the awesome things about Civ. To put it short, I have dicey relations with Germany, I conquered the southern and eastern coasts of Africa and then sold them off to the highest bidder to fund a public education system and an expanded navy, Persia be hating on me for reasons I can't quite comprehend, and I have a booming economy, which is only rivalled by Germany to my north (I actually conquered whatever Greek cities they hadn't taken, and sold them off to Germany, which paid for some improvements to my northern cities, also: I, America, am in South America, and Germany is in North America) and I'm currently planning to invade Australia and establish some colonies there. The combat system is also mad improved, and it's a lot harder to win by simple brute force now, and also cities now have their own defence strength, which I cannot stress enough how vital this is for me.

Also the game has this awesome art deco kind of style, and although it doesn't have Leonard Nimoy as the narrator and dude who reads out those excellent quotes you get when you build a wonder or research a new tech, it's Morgan Sheppard I think? And although his voice is good (and truly transcendent during the opening movie) I'm disappointed they didn't get Martin Sheen, because holy fuck that would have been amazing.

HONORABLE MENTION: COSTUME QUEST
I think I've actually ragged on Brutal Legend quite a bit in previous posts, but allow me to re-iterate: Shit sucked, dude. After it, I had little hope for Double Fine's future. The outlook was bleak. Spring was not to come.

BUT THEN, THQ stepped in and was all "Yo, we dig yo shit" and signed a deal with Double Fine to put out small, short games on XBLA and PSN, and I was all FUCK YES.

The first game to result from this partnership is Costume Quest, a hallowe'en themed RPG, where one can take on powers relating to their costume. This is a pretty sweet concept, and they don't skimp on the costumes either. There's a whole variety: from Space Ranger to Unicorn, and many of them have their own special abilities while you're exploring the overworld.

It's already got it's first expansion (the winter/christmas-themed Grubbins on Ice) and it's a pretty sweet RPG if you're into that sort of thing. The combat's simple, and you don't have any items to use (it can be a bit frustrating), and you fully heal after every battle, which is mad useful. It's also got some excellent style, and is just flat out nice to look at, plus hilarious to boot. It's €11.25 on the PSN (not sure how many MS Points it costs) and the expansion's an extra 3 or 4, so if you have some money lying around, you should pick up one of those Credit packs and buy it, cos it's some good vidya.

OTHER GAMES I PLAYED AND ENJOYED BUT THEY FAILED TO MAKE THE CUT
Red Dead Redemption
Skate 3
NBA 2K11
Joe Danger
Gran Turismo 5
FIFA 11
Tiger Woods PGA Tour 11
Minecraft
Super Mario Bros. X
The Sonic Fan Remix demo
Moonbase Alpha
Sam & Max Season 3
Back to the Future
Football Manager 11
OOTP 11
Professional Football Simulator
Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game
Castle Crashers

GAMES I WILL PLAY AT SOME POINT, BUT I DIDN'T THIS YEAR
R.U.S.E.
Mass Effect 2
3D Dot Game Heroes
Backbreaker
Rock Band 3

GAMES THAT SUCKED REALLY HARD
Super Street Fighter IV
Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode 1

GAMES THAT DIDN'T SUCK THAT HARD, BUT WEREN'T EXACTLY GOOD EITHER
Call of Duty: Black Ops
Fallout: New Vegas

FUKKEN UBISOFT
No updates on Rayman: Origins, or Beyond Good & Evil 2. When's the last time anyone saw Michel Ancel? I'm starting to worry.

That's about it, folks. I'll be covering the other realms of media (except books, because I didn't read enough books published in 2010 to make a top 5) over the next couple of days, so stay tuned.

So baller,
Cathal

entry.title: A christmas memory
entry.content:
The first christmas I explicitly remember is the one where I was sick. Apparently this was like a thing when I was a kid, that I would have some kind of minor illness during the holiday season, but anyway this christmas was particularly bad, because I got the fucking White Tigerzord! But I couldn't really play with it because I was really sick in bed, and although on the inside I was really excited, I couldn't do much with this incredibly bad ass zord.

Just something I wanted to blog,
Cathal

entry.title: A review of my first semester in my second year of my third level education
entry.content:
Hey that title actually works pretty well. I'm in the last 10 days of the year anyway, and although I haven't posted recently, that will all change since there will be a veritable rockalanche of posts about all kinds of shit, like a general social 2010 one, one about albums I really dug, one about films I saw and TV I watched, and so on. I might even get really annoying and post a My Year in Status thing up in, just to piss y'all off. Row row fight tha powah. But first off is a brief post about what I got up to in the 12 weeks of my first semester in blah blah blah. I'm kind of struggling writing long things thanks to the mindstate my geography essay has put me in (the first 100 words were a goddamned struggle that took far longer than 100 words ever should) but hopefully I can touch on all the major Mr. X happenings.

Well, first off, just to get it out of the way, the only reason I was even going into second year was because I had done alright on my supplemental exams, I'd even improved my Geography I mark by 250%, which I was mad chuffed with, and I did way better than I expected in my 2 chemistry exams, which I did pretty badly on in May, where I got 57% in both cases, which fuck yeah exceeding expectations (I honestly thought, after I came out from them, that I'd be lucky to get 40%, and would need compensation to pass the year (compensation is a practice in Trinity whereby you can fail 10 credits worth of exams and still pass the year, provided that a) you get 35% in the exam you failed and b) your average is 40% or higher)). But hey, it meant I had 2 weeks off until Semester 1 started (I used this time to start watching The West Wing, an amazing show I might blog about later) and also it turned out Larney was going into 2nd year too, which meant the glorious Bropad was go in Shanowen Square. It turned out we got a flat on the ground floor of a block right beside the gate, which too sweet. But on to the semester itself.

1) NEW DUDES
The main thing in any review post has to be NEW DUDES, basically dudes you met in the timeframe the post covered who are worthy of inclusion in this completely awesome blog, (which I can say definitively is the Best Blog in Cooley, and also the #1 Blog in Cooley.) so of course the obvious dudes are the two Connaught dudes currently living with me and Larney: Domhnaill and Simon (I ain't know their last names), who are both really sound dudes. I should mention I lost some money to Simon hustling hoops on NBA Live 2001 (once there was money at stake, Simon suddenly stopped shooting 40 3s a game, and was thus whupping my ass with his superior board play, but I also lost on a shitty shot for Nowitzki with 5 seconds to go, because this was back in 2000 before the Mavs were fucking awesome and Nash was a 2-time MVP) and Domhnaill generally being a legend. It was fun times gan dabht.

I met some cool dudes in my course too, but I mean what I can say is limited because I actually knew them beforehand, so yeah. Also my attendance record could have been better, although I only missed one lab, I did miss a handful of lectures, and something like a third of them in geography, which basically means that there is a small part of geography and a similar-sized chunk of chemistry I have no notes for (the lectures I missed happened to be given by the old-school No Notes Online types, shitsux) but thankfully I have excellent notes on the rest of the course in both cases, so it's all sound.

Last dudes to get a mention are the handful of dudes I met because Larney holds parties like every 2nd week almost (they're pretty good parties, and unlike last year, the noise is pretty reasonable, plus the lack of Massey the Buzz Killing Security Guard, Although He's Pretty Cool Generally, means that they're overall better) but shouts out to the dudes I saw the most, Kerrie (who actually got a post here earlier, mainly because she wrote a nice thing on my whiteboard, which I subsequently erased so I could plot galactic domination in Battlefront II, which more on that later) and Conor and Ruairi and Doireann and Andrew, who were all pretty cool, but also Aidan (Aiden?), who's kind of like Kevin's child is a good way of describing it, who even though he's a Maynooth student habitually spends a couple of days at a time up here. At one point he was there for pretty much the entire week, the blizzard week, where I walked home from college which wasn't fun, and Larney went outside in inches-deep snow in flip-flops and shorts, and was pretty much dead the next morning.

2) TRASH-TALKING
This is an art I've become pretty fucking good at thanks to the Playstation we have up in. I routinely beat dudes in games as varied as SSX 3, NBA Live, and Crash Team Racing, and also Battlefront II, and these easy victories over a bunch of jive turkeys allows me to trash talk liberally. At one point it got Simon very frustrated, but then he turned around and honed his own trash-talking game, so now it's pretty fun, and with SSX 3 and Domhnaill's dominance of Ruthless Ridge and Snow Jam, even he's gotten in on it. Trash talking is actually another fun part of couch multiplayer (see: Multitap, Obsolted in the archives) and it was actually fantastic.

Also since this is effectively a section about games that were done played now: Battlefront II, a recent addition to recreation in our flat. I got a lend of it off my friend Sean, who I've known since literally the day I was born, and brought it up, to play some mad Galactic Conquests up in with Larney. We're playing the Prequels Galactic Conquest, I'm the Seps, he's the Republic, and things are pretty exciting. Generally one of us will go on a 3- or 4-battle winning streak, and the map will change completely, then slowly things will return to the status quo, which is basically an 8:4 split of the galaxy, with Larney completely controlling the Northeastern quadrant, and me controlling everything else. A full recap of the events so far, retold in KDP style form will be related in a later post.

Also played was CTR, which thanks to the awesome multitap, was pretty popular. Kerrie's notorious game has been touched upon in her post, but she wasn't the worst, and she actually came 2nd a couple of times. Generally the whole thing had no established hierarchy, and the whole anyone-can-win-except-Kerrie thing really contributed to the crazy fun.

3) GENERAL ABSURDITY
So the final section of this blog is just gonna be brief descriptions of odd things that went down during the year.

Firstly I need to mention something I've heard mentioned in whispers on the Trinners section of boards.ie. Apparently in JF Science, some chick had an episode while campaigning for class rep, and her mom showed up and there were tears and vomiting. Emma wasn't able to yield any additional info, and since she's the only person I know in JF Science (well apart from Geenry, but I never see that dude) it's a dead end.

There were a number of things, some of them was shit I didn't witness, and thus it became cooler by way of mystery, such as the Heino keg which is now a table in our living room, and the threads connecting all three lights in the kitchen. Then there was outright bizarre shit, like someone throwing a snowman into our living room, and the sudden appearance of a miniature pool, which was re-purposed as a kind of open-air fridge.

There was also the discovery of ADVENTURE TIME, a fucking awesome cartoon about Jake the Dog and Finn the Human. The fun will never end, it's Adventure Time. Which we watched a lot of (along with Regular Show, about two 23-year-old slackers who are a blue jay and a raccoon) and it's alright become part of my everyday conversation with Larney. Finn's hat, and an appropriate piece of Jake clothing have been found on Hot Topic, so next time costuming up is called for, we are going to be Finn and Jake. It's a really fucking good show anyway (IT'S SO GOOD I would say, as apparently that is now my catchphrase) and you should watch it as soon as possible.

That's about it for the Semester 1 review, which I probably missed out on some sizable shit but I covered all the major bases, so enjoy, and learn more about me. I'll be doing some 2010 review and 2011 preview posts over the next week or so anyway, so stay tuned! And to all the dudes (Frank, Ri, Emma) who didn't get mentioned, it was 'cos I already knew you, but y'all alright by me anyway.

IT'S SO GOOD,
Cathal

entry.title: An RPG which attempts to create an epic story from various hip-hop related ingredients
entry.content:
So a couple days back I was talking on msn with my bro Fortengard (I've mentioned his blog before, which you can check out for sweet posts on various things that mostly originate in Japan (perhaps entirely, but I'm in Writer and I'm not going to check)) and he told me he had this baller idea, which I'm not going to recount, but it was pretty awesome. Impressed, and slightly jelly, I decided to come up with my own idea for a video game, and so after a really short brainstorm, I improvised an idea for an action-rpg that would be to hip-hop what Brutal Legend was to heavy metal.

Up front, I've never actually finished Brutal Legend, and it's a game that I just did not enjoy. One thing it did right however, was the mythology. Weaving icons of a genre that has always had acts fascinated with grand creatures, who are often massive dicks (there's Christian Metal too, but apart from UnderOath and this one song from a band Conservapedia was briefly really excited about, I don't know shit about it) and Brutal Legend fitted that in well. It also had stuff like the Headbanger armies, which poked gentle fun at stereotypes, and overall it was a really affectionate thing.

The main reason I thought this hip-hop RPG would be a good idea though, is the four elements. I'd been playing Barkley, Shut Up and Jam: Gaiden when I first came up with this idea actually (BSUAJ:G managed to make an epic story that was both hilarious and gripping, and featured some innovated hoops-based combat), but apart from the MCing element (which I cribbed the mechanism entirely from Deltron 3030, or at least my understanding of Deltron 3030) I couldn't figure out any possible mechanisms for the other 3 elements, although in theory they make a sweet, pyrokinetic magic combat system.

I have a bunch of ideas for the story anyway, and on MSN we spent most of the conversation talking about where various rappers would fit in, although really I don't plan on using actual rappers as characters, although pretty much I've slotted in Jay Electronica as the player character, KRS-One as the mentor, and Brother Ali as the healer. Other than that, I'm still working out what direction to go with it, even though like 5 years from now, when it's done, Interscope probably won't even be releasing rap music. But hey, maybe can I get in on some nostalgia market with that, and get Rhymefest to endorse it and everything.

This probably sounds corny as hell, but I think I could make something good with it, y'know? But the main thing is figuring out and ordering all my ideas into a neat, engaging story. This post would be longer if I posted every idea I had relating to this in this post, but then we'd be here all day, and even less people would understand it than usual.

But hey,
Cathal

entry.title: Kerrie Explains It All
entry.content:
Right so this is gonna diverge from what has been the defining genre of post for Season 2 of My Ace Hen (basically seasons is an idea I've discussed with Frank, basically the blog runs for 5 months, then has 3 months off, then another season of 4 months, in every annual cycle) which is long posts about obscure things the readers don't care about. Basically there's this person who basically lives here, Kerrie, who's in Kevin's engineering class (her breadboard is here and shit) along with the rest of the Engineering Cadre who are here often, to play CTR and set Kevin's homepage to porn. But yeah, Kerrie saw me blogging one time and asked to do a post for her, so basically I'm gonna post a short list of facts about Kerrie.

Her mom is a total wingman (wingwoman? or is it like Officer, with wingman not denoting gender?) but the most important thing is Kerrie's notoriously bad CTR game. I actually had a list of facts about Kerrie I typed up at Social Gunpoint, but posting them on a blog people I don't know read is not rad. But back to Kerrie's CTR game, a game so bad that a dog raises its hackles if it is approached by Kerrie's game. Her game stinks so bad families in cars roll up the windows. If her game touches some eggs the mother bird will kill said eggs. Should wear a leather mask and race Polar Pass in the travelling circus sideshow, everyone hey look at this terrible game. Apparently she came 2nd a few times or something recently, but I'll believe it when I see it.

However, this is not a complete representation of Kerrie. See, although her game is notoriously bad, one is rarely defined by one's game (unless you're Sam Bowie or something, in which case your life is defined by the inferiority of your game when compared to Michael Jordan, although I mean the Blazers had to pick Bowie. They'd drafted Drexler the previous year, and drafting Jordan would just have been a complete waste, whereas Bowie addressed a need, and it wasn't like he was on Olowakandi levels of suck), but Kerrie is, in fact, pretty awesome.

She's actually one of the two people who actually cleans our flat at all ever, which that someone actually cleans a place that isn't theirs says a lot for how bad things get around here, and although she sometimes does un-rad things, like getting a dude to shave his beard (NOT COOL) she is mostly up on the level, all writing nice things on my whiteboard, and ordering pizza, and generally being pretty cool. I suck at these people posts, but yeah, Kerrie is a bro, like a true bro.

I'm not sure what exactly I can write here, other than just re-assert my previous point, I mean it's pretty hard to quantify or articulate the bro quality, it's intangible and defies definition, nawmean? But she's got said B.Q., and although Larney is the only reader who knows who she is, she gets this post anyway, as small payment for all the cleaning out the sink times.

WORD,
Cathal

entry.title: A long, winding post on Avatar: The Last Airbender
entry.content:
So it's been a while since I've done a long, pointless post, since I've had less free time for various reasons; being awesome, working on my geography and chemistry projects, and also time I've set aside for polishing my lab books but never using said time efficiently, and lastly reading through the entirety of Hark! a Vagrant, which is an absolutely hilarious history-inspired comic for the most part, with absolutely great strips about Teddy Roosevelt and Napoleon and shit.

But like the thing that took up the most time last week was Avatar: The Last Airbender, this cartoon that ran for 3 seasons (or "books") from 2005 to 2008 on Nickelodeon, which I downloaded because of repeated recommendations from /co/ (next up from /co/: My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic... no, seriously) and I pretty much just sped through it, starting it late Sunday night and finishing it mid-afternoon on Thursday. It's still pretty fresh up in my noggin so I figured I'd write a long thing (inspired mostly by the series of recaps over at Fortengard Custom, link can be found in my blogroll) that won't be a straight-up recap, but more what I think of the show, and just things I noticed, along with an appraisal of everything.

So, in short, prepare your anuses for My Ace Hen's Impressions and Thoughts Regarding the Animated Serial, Avatar; concering the adventures and journey of the Last Airbender. I need to start somewhere, and considering the scope of the show, the opening narration does a pretty good job of explaining it, so I'll just post that as an introduction.


A map of the world in Avatar, with some pretty obvious colour-coding.

"Water... Earth... Fire... Air. Long ago, the 4 nations lived together in harmony. Then everything changed when the Fire Nation attacked. Only the Avatar, master of all 4 elements, could stop them, but when the world needed him most, he vanished. A hundred years passed and my brother and I discovered the new Avatar, an airbender named Aang. And although his airbending skills are great, he still has a lot to learn before he's ready to save anyone. But I believe Aang can save the world."

Basically, what it said. There are four elements, each representing a both a peoples and a martial art (or "bending", for obvious reasons, the show was subtitled The Legend of Aang over here) that can be linked to an Asian nation and martial art. Like, the Earth Kingdom is China, the Fire Nation is Japan, and the Water Tribe are the Inuits. You won't need 2 guesses for who the Air Nomads are inspired by. Also, each of the three seasons deals primarily with a form Aang has to learn (Book 1 = Water, Book 2 = Earth, Book 3 = Fire).

The opening narration is slightly different for the first episode, as Aang has not yet been discovered, and the show opens with the narrator (a Waterbender named Katara) and her brother (a sarcastic warrior dude named Sokka) are going fishing, and they come across an iceberg. They find Aang, but they also alert an exiled Fire Nation prince, Zuko (who believes that finding the long-lost Avatar will restore his HONOUR, a word you will hear him say a couple of hundred times over the course of the show), and his badass, tea-loving uncle, Iroh (Iroh drank coffee in the movie for some fucking absurd reason, but in terms of why the Last Airbender movie sucked, I mean it's just typical of why, minor pointless changes that destroy characters) are alerted to the Avatar's presence. Zuko shows up at Katara and Sokka's village at the South Pole, threats are made, action unfolds, and Aang, Katara, and Sokka take off to basically save the world. That's all you need to know in terms of the plot, I mean I really don't want to spoil anything, but now I'm gonna spend the rest of the post talking, in brief, about why I think this show is awesome, and is in my top ten shows of the 00s. (In no particular order, they are: The West Wing; Avatar: The Last Airbender; The Wire; Futurama; Arrested Development; FLCL; Mad Men; Firefly; How I Met Your Mother; Deadwood)

Obviously, talking about a cartoon, the first thing I need to touch on is the art style and animation, which I think are tout-sweet. The world is just beautiful to look at, and even the ridiculous things, like the X-Y zoo they got going on in Avatarworld, are awesome (fuck yeah Appa) and the characters are well designed, and distinctive



Actually this is a really good example, and it’s limited to characters from the first two episodes, and is thus spoiler free.

Suffice to say it's basically Western Anime, it looks extremely good, but some idiots continuously confuse it for an actual Japanese animation, which dear God son, you that dumb (Spoony did this, if I recall correctly). Another great thing is the show’s fight choreography, which is on par with some of the great wushu films of whenever. Each bending discipline is just an actual martial art with some effects basically (e.g., Water Bending = Tai Chi Chuan, Fire Bending = Kung fu) and the fights are just high on the Holy Shit Quotient. There’s also a Pro Wrestling thing with the Earthbenders in season 2, with a very affectionate parody of The Rock, voiced by Mick Foley, and it’s pretty hilarious. I mean I don't know that much about animation, so I can't write at length about it, and thankfully THE BOULDER allows me to segue into the next part of the post, about the characters and writing.

Honestly, the characters are the best thing about this great show. The main characters are all well-rounded, and have very good arcs, and develop nicely, although they retain their key characteristics (i.e., Aang is playful, Sokka is sarcastic, Zuko is obsessed with HONOUR!) and the minor characters, like Suki, and Jet, fit in seamlessly, and are generally awesome. I mean if I were to count the list of awesome, well-rounded characters, it would be in the high double digits. Most episodes of the first season, for example, introduce 1 or 2 great characters.

It even introduces a new character in season 2, and while many shows pretty much fall apart when they change the central dynamic, Avatar's characters are strong enough that the show continues its rise with a party of four instead of three, and when they bring all the cast back (for the most part) in season 3, it doesn't feel like horrible fanservice, like it often does. (Hey, it's characters who have no reason to be here, but they're here because they have a massive shipping community, etc.) although that's not to say Avatar doesn't have a massive and sometimes annoying shipping community (I'm looking at y'all, Zutarians, y'all why we can't have nice things) but even the romantic parts of the show have a feeling that the happy ending (lame pun, sorry) has been earned, which is always great.

The last thing to talk about, given that I've touched on the animation/fight choreography and the characters/writing, is the voice acting and music. It's got a kickass voice cast, including Mae Whitman (Arrested Development, Scott Pilgrim vs. the World), Mako (pretty much everything ever) and Mark Hamill (most iconic villains from 90s animations. He adds another leaf to that cap here with Fire Lord Ozai). The music is also fucking incredible, it's done by this duo called The Track Team, and you can get an unofficial version on Mediafire (I deleted my mp3 blog, Running Dog, for a reason, so hit me up on some kind of IM protocol if you want a link), and it fits with the world perfectly. It's also got some pretty nice folk standards up in also (Leaves from the Vine, damn that's some sad shit man, manly tears were shed for the dude singing it, and also for Mako, who died before the season was completed).

The deal-clincher for this show is it's universe though. Damn that's some immersive, brilliant world-building. I already discussed the Nations and how they were inspired by different Asian peoples up in the second paragraph, but beyond that, it's a seriously good universe, I mean there needs to be an Avatar version of King of Dragon Pass (for me, whether or not a fictional epic-fantasy universe could work with King of Dragon Pass gameplay is one way of determining how good it is, e.g., Lord of the Rings and Avatar pass, Harry Potter fails miserably).

I'm not sure what else I can write about this awesome show, so all I can do is encourage you to watch it, hit me up and I'll give you a link for the first episode so you can check it out, but it's definitely something you should do at some point.

I fucked the moon,

Cathal

entry.title: An unfinished parable
entry.content:
One day there was a man walking about a town, when he saw someone partaking in a forbidden drug. Incensed, he approached the drug user, and told him that he was going to destroy his life with addiction and listlessness, but the drug user was unfazed, and continued about his ways. This infuriated the man, and he grew increasingly angry. People nearby noticed the commotion and approached, and were amused by his interfering ways. He turned to them and said "Why are you sticking your noses into other people's affairs"

Eh I don't have an ending or moral for this, but it's a promising start, and I'm fooling around with writing briefer sentences, as a self-control thing.

Word out,
Cathal

entry.title: My badass desktop
Rock on the beach
entry.content:
So I have this idea for an historical action movie, which will basically be like Dirty Harry, but with Edwin McMasters Stanton (what a fucking name) kicking ass, rather than middle-aged Clint Eastwood. It's going to have all the elements of an awesome One Good Cop movie (with spy movie elements), and some interesting historical factoids. For example, the film will open with Stanton in the courtroom, invoking the insanity defence for Daniel E. Sickles, one of the first instances of the insanity defence ever! It'll also be embellished a bit, and the Confederates will be kind of like the Russians in spy movies of the day, and it will also include a rousing early speech (establishing Stanton as a man of the pen, as well as a man of the sword) where Stanton convinces Buchanan to declare secession unconstitutional.

Then the film will have scenes of Stanton helping out an inept cop in fighting a massive conspiracy. Then the dude he's helping gets fired for sucking so much, and Stanton's all "I'm only doing this to save my country", so then he sees the Confederates, and he's all ENOUGH O' THIS! And then he's all busting generals with Union sympathies and being badass (I repeat that this is entirely an idea of fiction, there is nothing rad about abusing your power to ensure a verdict in a court-martial, or any shit like that. Democracies don't play that, democracies never been 'bout dat.) But then Lincoln gets assassinated (before this happens, Lincoln gives him a "writing cheques your body can't cash" sort of speech) and Stanton has a character building moment at his funeral. Then Andrew Johnson shows up and is being all soft on the Confederates Stanton fought so hard, and it's all about Stanton clashing with Johnson, until Johnson tries to fire Stanton, but Stanton is so popular among the citizenry that they rise up and impeach Johnson before he can do that.
That is a pretty badass beard, one would have to admit.

I mean, again, work of fiction, but really Secretary of War is such a hardcore title, it's amazing there's never been a movie made with Harrison Ford or Kurt Russell with that title. I mean it's Air Force One and The West Wing-league "Awesome Titles for Movies and TV shows with Political Protagonists". Plus I could have all kinds of scenes, including scenes of strategic planning, which would be so gripping. I'll be developing this more, because there's just so much great material here, but yeah it'd just be damn good.

The tagline's going to be "I'll Tell You What I Know: He Can Save This Country".

Actually, scratch that. Tagline is "He's got a portfolio... OF PAIN"

For better security against conversation,
Cathal

entry.title: 3 Years of Clan History
entry.content:
Lately I've been playing a kind of simulation-type game called King of Dragon Pass, where the main objective is to take your lowly clan and through diplomacy and trade and war, build up your status and power and eventually have one of your clan members become head of a kingdom, a sort of Federated Clans of Dragon Pass deal. The game itself is really cool, and every screen has hand-drawn art (with the exception of the village overview thing), and it's really well-written. A nifty thing this game does is save all the events in your clan's history into a text file. In lieu of a meaty post about Superman, or the PS1 I've set up in my flat, I'm going to post the history of my clan from 1329-1331. Also included is the ancient lore, which is presented to the player as a series of choices that determine gameplay conditions, like specialisation and attitude toward dragons.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ancient Lore
During the marriage of Orlanth and Ernalda, our men whooped and drank with Orlanth, making Orlanth our main deity.

Our clan’s earliest famous event was when Roitina, lady of dance, first performed the Clan-Making Dance.

During the Storm Age, we adopted strangers into our clan. Our worst enemies in those days were the trolls.

We were originally a Balanced Clan.

At the Dawn, we first awakened Orlanth, the Father.

Our attitude toward dragons and their ilk was neutral; we did not go along with them nor actively make war on them.

1329


When we arrived in Dragon Pass, we claimed more land than we needed, to grow into. We built a clan hall, some steads, and a temple to Orlanth. But when we left Heortland, we lost much of our connection with the gods.

1330


The alynx spirits chased off the vermin spirits; there would be few rats this year.

The Issaries priestess Sora Goodseller came to our clan and asked if we had any white horses to trade. We had no white horses.

We approached the Boskovi clan with an offer of peace. We offered them payment. They were pleased by our generosity, and we ended the feud.

Eonislara, betrothed to Jorator of the Elkenval clan, was seduced by Korol, the notorious troublemaking poet of the Heran clan. We told Jorator what had happened, but urged him to continue with the wedding. Jorator said that Eonislara was a fine young woman, and that if the gods condoned this behavior, he could do no less.

We approached the Hendart clan with an offer of peace. We offered them payment. They were pleased by our generosity, and we ended the feud.

We were raided by the horse nomads. Korlmar drove off a group of Horse-Spawn who were attempting to circle behind us. We drove the horse nomads off, and their survivors left without plundering our tula.

We approached the Hendart clan with an offer of peace. We proposed a reciprocal marriage between clans to seal our peace. The marriages were agreed to. Bride prices were exchanged for dowries. Twin feasts were held, in our hall and theirs.

Inganna began the Storm Tribe heroquest. Inganna was told by Ernalda to make a tribe, so that she could challenge the Emperor. But the Doubting Wheel rolled up and told Inganna not to make a tribe. She said, “I will not be bad like the Emperor, for freedom is my essence.” “Freedom is your essence now,” the Wheel said, “but if you become like the Emperor in this way, soon you will be like him in every way.” She tried to roll the Doubting Wheel away. It rolled a long way away, until it arrived in the tula of the Fire Tribe, and there vexed the Emperor with its mockery and criticism. Inganna found Yinkin, who said he would join the tribe if Inganna could defeat the champions of the Plant Tribe. Inganna fought Sharp Green and let Yinkin fight Rustling Veins. Inganna blunted the many swords of Sharp Green, which gave it power. Yinkin defeated his foe, but said, “Your Storm Tribe will only be half useful. There is only half a chance that I will come to this confederation moot of yours.” Inganna found the Knowing God trapped inside a great cube. She told the Knowing God to launch a legal claim against the cube. “Why, in all my life, I have never heard anything so utterly moronic!” sputtered Lhankor Mhy. Then the cube crumbled, and the Knowing God was caught short for a moment. Then he Knew. “The creatures of the Stone Tribe think they understand everything. When they find something they cannot figure out, they fall apart.” Lhankor Mhy agreed to make the Marks On Bark Clan part of the Storm Tribe, so long as this new tribe had fierce warriors. Inganna found Vadrus, who had decided to fight Yinkin and his Cat Clan. Inganna said, “If we had a tribe, you could punish him without hurting him.” “This is a very strange thing you say,” Vadrus mused, “but perhaps it has a ring of truth to it. I will seek a new foe, and may even attend this confederation moot of yours — so long as my right to punish upstart Yinkin is made clear to all.” Inganna found more chieftains to bring their clans to the confederation moot, but when they got there, they fell to fighting, and blamed her for making contradictory promises. Inganna said, “With a tribe, we will be prosperous.” “How can we be prosperous if we can no longer raid our neighbors?” the chieftains asked. Inganna said, “With a tribe, our magic will be strong.” “What good is strong magic,” the chieftains scoffed, “if you must make friends with people you ought to be fighting?” Inganna said, “With a tribe, we can fight our common foes.” “Our foes are right here!” the chieftains cried. She offered to fight each and every one of them. They were quite ready to do this, and Inganna was preparing for the battle when Ernalda brought her implements of tribal regalia. She brought the Chest of Torcs, with which she could gift the clan leaders. She brought the Hall of Understanding, where people would settle their differences by talking them out. She brought the Crown of Authority, which made people respect her sacral powers and pledge allegiance to her. Most of the clans agreed to make the tribe, but there were still some who were stubborn. Then warriors of the Night Tribe came and attacked the quarrelling clans. Inganna led the fight against the Night People. Everyone banded together to fight these hungry enemies. After they defeated the night warriors, they acclaimed Inganna as their king. Inganna returned to the land of mortals, her quest successful. The god-talkers said that our next attempt to make a tribe would benefit from the favor of Orlanth.

Jorator came to complain that his bride Eonislara had broken a promise to stay faithful to him before they were married. He wanted her bride price back. We told Eonislara that she should divorce him. Eonislara agreed that Jorator was being unreasonable. She came back to us. Jorator stalked off, threatening reprisals.

Leikan began the Storm Tribe heroquest. Leikan was unable to enter the realm of the gods.

Temertain, a thane of the Heran clan, complained that Bastakos insulted him, and said there would be a feud if we did not punish our trickster. We told Temertain he should not take Bastakos’s insults so seriously. After much discussion, he agreed that no one would think his honor besmirched by a mere trickster’s mockery, especially if he paid no mind to it himself.

Kestald complained that his wife Arkilla dishonored him by interrupting a duel with Saronil of the Boskovi. He was told that this was not a matter for the clan ring. The people were happy that the ring was wise enough not to involve itself in a petty dispute. As for Kestald and Saronil, they met again, and took to sipping ale together, lamenting the meddling ways of wives.

1331


The alynx spirits chased off the vermin spirits; there would be few rats this year.

Our scouts found a strange clan of beast folk who were like ducks. With justice and mercy, we offered peace to the duck people, who henceforth gave our clan a place of honor in their songs.

We learned that the Herani had declared a feud against us.

Women from the Gorind clan came to urge us to help them prosecute a feud against the Boskovi. We offered to make peace between the feuding clans. The women seemed offended. “Make peace with those detestable rodents? Don’t suggest such a thing, even in jest!” We sent messengers to warn the Boskovi that the Gorinds meant them harm. The Boskovi thanked us for the warning; they said they would be our friends in the future.

A trickster came to laugh at us, and to offer us a blessing that would help us on our next heroquest. We demanded an apology. He apologized in such a way as to magnify the insult. We attacked him. We wounded the trickster and one of his guardians, and they ran off. Our honor was satisfied.

Bastakos, the devotee of Eurmal on our clan ring, gave away a herd of our cows. We asked the Blue Spruces to give the cows back. They said that tricksters could never be trusted, and returned the cattle to us.

Intagarn spoke for the warriors when he said that they were stretched too thin, and that more fighters were needed. We sent Kulbrast on a mission to find the best warriors available.

Yorsar approached us, seeking our support for his heroquest. We refused him, because our magic was weak. Yorsar flew into a rage, claiming we were liars. He picked up Vininna and threw her through the clan hall wall. Swearing gore-spattered vengeance on the cowards of Dragon Pass who did not understand the need for unity between Orlanthi, he departed.

A couple from another clan offered to sell us the Torc of Honor. We paid what they asked. We put the Torc of Honor in a safe place.

1332
The god-talkers said we would be blessed with many children this year.

Enastakos of the Blackrock clan offered us gifts. We threw a feast for thanes of Enastakos’s clan. They toasted our generosity, and said they would speak of it to others. Our people made merry, and also toasted the clan ring.

Robasart of the Blue Jays wooed and married Eonislara. He proclaimed himself lucky to find such a beautiful and fertile wife.

A bold young warrior named Gardrostan sought a duel with a champion of our clan. Orlaront accepted his challenge. The two fought a ferocious battle that seemed to go on for hours. Finally, our champion fell to his knees and spoke the traditional words of surrender.

Spirit-talkers showed up and asked if we needed anything from them. We did not want anything from them, but gave them hospitality. The old one told us we would be rewarded for our generosity.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

As you can probably see, I'm not great at this.

For Orlanth!,
Cathal
