entry.title: Edmund refused Lynx
entry.content:
The title sounds good, but it doesn't really mean anything, other than Edmund doesn't wear Lynx and thus does not get fresh with the fine women, because he lacks the Lynx effect. Someone sued over a lack of action after using Lynx recently, but whether he actually felt aggrieved or was just another project of lawsuitmania, well it's not a mystery. Maybe if you joined a cult to get fresh with the fine women then it would be less mercenary to sue.

Doug E. Fresh needs to make a comeback by the way, hopefully he'll make an appearance with Slick Rick on Rock the Bells. Rock the Bells has an excellent line-up this year, Wu-Tang, Rakim, and KRS One are all playing some of their best albums in full, although I would have rathered Rakim to do Follow the Leader than Paid in Full. I Know You Got Soul and My Melody and I Ain't No Joke are good and all, but Microphone Fiend is untouchable, listening to the RATM cover is very painful, Zach de la Rocha just cannot rap, it needs to be said over and over, he's definitely on my list of Terrible Rappers Who Need to Stop Already, along with Flavor Flav (who ideally would be replaced by a younger, less annoying equivalent; Public Enemy live would get so much better, I mean they toured with the Roots, but Flavor Flav was there bringing it down by existing in the vicinity of Chuck D and also the Roots), along with Insane Clown Posse, and Drake (my god I do not get Drake's popularity, he can't sing or rap well), and most of G-Unit, and there's probably a few others, but the ones I can think of have either basically retired from it (Master P) or don't really appear on my radar at all and thus don't get a spot (Lil' Boosie). But basically there are a shit load of awesome acts at Rock the Bells, Clipse, MURS & 9th Wonder, Ill Bill, and Brother Ali. There are a couple I never really got into (Immortal Technique) and then there's the Make Boots Riley Look Bad Band (Street Sweeper Social Club). Lauryn Hill's on the bill too, which is going to be awesome for all the wrong reasons. I'd love to hear Miseducation re-done as a polka album, that seems like something she might do. Lauryn Hill is crazy, seriously.

Also the Lost finale is a post in itself, but basically how did they manage to not answer ANYTHING in a 100-minute episode? Fucking hell.

Telephone,
Cathal

Their party was at Sas's house anyway, (apparently I curse too much in front of people's parents too so I need to watch that) and at first I was worried I wouldn't know anyone, but like there were a few people with whom I was casual acquaintances, plus everyone there was completely chill. We listened to a lot of music, I got my iPod back after like a year, and I met some pretty cool people, then Carpo got the guitar and jammed some Brand New and we all sang along.

That was pretty much it for the weekend, and I've been in hiding to avoid learning anything at all about the Lost finale, so a big post will be coming on Tuesday when I re-enter the world.

Let the rhythm hit 'em,
Cathal

entry.title: Strictly Business
entry.content:
So today was my first day of the summer spent at home. I really should have made more of it. Woke up at like 11, went for a walk along the beach, and then had some delicious tortillas, played some Ratchet and Clank, and read Brief Interviews for Hideous Men. I've actually played all the games Frank gave me last week now, so I can give some Prindle-style run-downs of 'em.

Brutal Legend: The idea was a lot better than the actual execution, combat is clumsy and annoying and Jack Black interjects during gameplay in a way that grates after the 3rd repeat of an unfunny quip. But it's Tim Schafer, it's still funny and well presented, but I'd much rather watch someone else play it for me.

Ratchet and Clank Future: Fuck Yeah.

LittleBigPlanet: Actually got round to playing it online, the user-created levels had neat ideas, especially the survival ones; The Shark one was fun as hell. But the gameplay is still uninspiring. But Stephen Fry and fantastic music compensate. Still not sure why Edge gave it a 10/10, speaking of which I need to pick that up tomorrow.

Tomorrow is also a couple of other things. I'm hanging out with my bro Frank for the last time before his leaving, and then I'm heading out to Tallanstown, for the Carpo/Sas farewell party. Saturday I'll probably go into Dundalk and get my haircut, although I Wrestled a Bear Once are playing in Eden Quay, I'm not sure I'll be able to make it, which sucks, cos it's gonna be the last awesome gig before the Leaving's over, at which point Hot-Stuff play Macs and the Whales are re-united. Elsewhere in music I've been listening to Deftones and some early Def Jam records. I can't believe it's taken me this long to get LL Cool J's first album! My library passed 27000 songs a couple of days ago too, and if I get round to labelling my marching band mp3s, it'll be at 28000, which right now is maybe half of Mully's.

Jar of Jam,
Cathal Murphy

entry.title: Things just ain't the same
entry.content:
Eh I've finished basically a full week of Summer so far, and it went pretty well, it was pretty chill and laid back and it was like a nod rather than a OHMIGODIHAVENTSEENYOUIN3WEEKSIWASCRYING thing. The first bum note of the summer yeah I see the pun is someone clogging my toilet the fuck up. Completely disgusting. Things ain't the same once you've seen a dude's stew. So tomorrow I have to get up at 9 and head up to the Omni and get all the products I need for some D.I.Y. plumbing.

But what actually happened over the weekend. Niamh and Orla showed up and we had a good time at the time but now it's been tempered with developments. My first weekend back home sleeping in a comfy as fuck bed was pretty good too. I set up a wireless network so my bro can check his moodle from the comfort of his own desk or conservatory desk, and started using PSN, although now I have to update every game I want to play and the files are 200MB at least (I'm on Digiweb, it'd be like downloading CS5 for those of you on decent connections) and I played LittleBigPlanet, which only has 2 things going for it: Stephen Fry's narration, and the soundtrack. I have Stephen Fry narrated audiobooks and the soundtrack on my iPod, so LBP isn't being played again.

I went into Dundalk too, and hung out with Frank and Ri (let it be known that Ri's mom totally wants me) and although the usual suspects were absent because of exam preparation, that was probably a good thing. I went to Frank's house to pick up some PS3 games and we talked and I learned some stuff that I didn't need to know, but it's better that I do know. My room is empty apart from my clothes and some stuff for cleaning that fucking toilet now too, and I'm sorting out next year with Larney either tomorrow or on Tuesday. Still need to know who the fourth roommate is, I hope it's Fitzy.

Hopefully during the week I'll also be able to hang out with people I haven't seen in a bit, and go to DKIT to at long last empty my flux. Although I haven't been able to abuse it yet, it was definitely worth the 29 quid. I checked Man Without a Country by Kurt Vonnegut out of the library too, it's short comical op-eds sort of, pretty entertaining.

I stayed pretty on point with this one actually, took less than 10 minutes to write. But gonna continue the regular feature here.

Have you ever been getting with a girl, and she starts crying because she won't be able to see you for 3 weeks? CAN YOU RELATE?

Aus Berlin,
Cathal

So my exams are over, and my Summer is go. The exams themselves went alright, I completely fucked up Geography so thank God for automatic resits. I sat my last exam on a basketball court and I wish it had been one of those exams that took all 3 hours because I was sitting right next to the hoop, and me and Rory were all Man if we're here at the end, scrunch up the paper and drop a two. Shit would have been THE best way to end the fucking year. But when Summer actually started I was out at the same time as Grahame, so we went over to Spar and he got a roll and a 4 euro bottle of wine and met some of his mates and we just chilled in the Pav. They're doing another one right now actually, fan-submitted flavours like American Cheeseburger and Roast Beef and Yorkshire Pudding, which my flatmate commented "Tasted like it, but wasn't right" and then it became a kids would only know Roast Beef and Yorkshire Pud through Walkers and when given the physical real thing would say it didn't seem right.

So now basically I have four and a half months of nothing but chilling and brostuff and basically I'm really hyped about it. There is good stuff up to my ears right now, and it started off awesome and so far it's been awesome. Orla and Niamh are coming up tomorrow too so it's gonna be like HAPPY 18th basically Orla buying alcohol legally for the first time in her life and making white russians, and I'll rock my Lebowski specs and talk about how I was one of the Seattle Seven.

entry.title: Homegrown
entry.content:
Fiacre always has homegrown weed, it's his thing, although I haven't actually seen the dude in a few months, next time I see him he'll probably have some more. Neil Young had a song about it, and an album too with the same title although it was more about his wife, and it's never been released. The Band plays on a few of the tracks too. The Band are great, I'm not a huge fan of Music from Big Pink, but their self-titled album is one of my favourites, even if it's mostly just straight-forward songs about unions and women who help you when you're drunk and in Louisiana. They were a great backing band too, Live at the "Royal Albert Hall" is fucking hardcore, but I'm gonna get away from the whole looking for Tru Punx from a time before Punk was even used to describe a style of music, that's one thing that grinds my spark plugs man.

There was an absolutely terrible "punk" band in Dundalk a couple of years back, they only played a couple of gigs but they rocked Swastikas and that kind of thing without any kind of motivation other than "fuck the hippies and journalists" which sounds like something a guy ripping off Bret Easton Ellis would say to excuse a shitty novel. You don't even see hippies anymore, they've all migrated to Rastafarianism. That's not to say all non-Jamaican Rastas were hippies in a past life, I mean H.R. from Bad Brains is one and he's really just the world's biggest douchebag, although Bad Brains are a good band, and it's not enough to stop me listening to them, like I dunno Skrewdriver. The punk band had this one song, Beethoven Was a Punk, which no.
Punk's a pretty loosely-defined term anyway, but I like the D.I.Y. aspects, and the kinda stuff Fugazi do, like having low admission prices and discouraging slam-dancing and not being self-righteous about doing those basic decent things that any band should do, except maybe the Stooges, who made antagonizing the audience part of their thing. There's a lot of good home-recorded music though, like the stuff the Guided by Voices So-Called Classic Lineup did, Bee Thousand and Vampire on Titus and what have you, and Cody ChesnuTT, Daniel Johnston, and Dylan's Basement Tapes, and so on. I guess the Library of Congress Field Recordings would count too, some of that stuff is amazing, even if the recording equipment was a bit shoddy.

My favourite song from the first half of the 20th century is definitely I Wish I Was a Mole in the Ground, it's pretty simple and the lyrics are really cryptic, and the effect it has is otherworldly, like a lot of the stuff from back then actually, particularly Robert Johnson, although if you slow him down it's another beast entirely. In Japan that's the prevailing opinion, that all his 78s were played at the wrong RPM, and that you need to slow it down to hear what it actually was, and if you do his voice sounds better, but his guitar is completely different and doesn't match with first-hand accounts at all, but I suppose naturally things would get exaggerated, e.g. the things said about Cool Papa Bell (Best nickname ever) and Jon Gibson and a lot of athletes from the day, but back when nobody paid attention to those kind of dudes when they were making their name it was bound to happen. Like the Four Horsemen from Notre Dame, the guy who made them famous and made an entire second income championing them and talking about how close he was to Notre Dame and Rockne in later years even though the week after he wrote the Four Horsemen article he didn't even bother to check them out when they came to New York. They weren't great players either, just really good, and completely undersized, not that that's a big thing. A team in Brooklyn signed a couple of them and tried to turn it into a marketing gimmick, but it didn't really fly because Red Grange was the big thing in 1925.

It's pretty cool to see that happen, when one guy comes in and saves a league or sport and raises it to another level, like Tiger Woods or Michael Jordan did. Red Grange did that for Pro American Football in the '20s anyway, back when it was basically considered to be as good as the Airtricity League is nowadays, and he turned it into something else and a desirable place for All-Americans to go when they graduated with their physical education degrees. I can't see any sport needing it right now, except maybe Baseball, which desperately needs someone to capture the public imagination in a good way, rather than by having paintings of themselves as centaurs and doing steroids, or just doing steroids and being an asshole. Every other major sport kind of has a lightning rod right now, except maybe Gaelic Football, I can't really think of any, although I kinda lost interest and switched to hurling after the Ulster style became popular. It was just ugly as hell to watch the Armagh team with no skills beat up Donegal who were trying to play solid graceful football, and then the back-door system giving them a second chance after they fucked up against Fermanagh or some other good team. Hurling's awesome, although I couldn't play it for love or money, but that applies to so many things it's not worth saying.

Over,
Cathal

entry.title: Collapsing the wavefunction
entry.content:
I had an article about David Wallace near-done but the draft didn't save so I'm gonna have to start from scratch here and try and get a similar kind of feel to this one. But basically a book of a 5-day road trip with David Wallace by a guy working for Rolling Stone is out, probably as a promotional thing for his unfinished thing which comes out next year. Wallace is probably my favourite writer, and his stuff was a big part of me turning from a pretentious brat into who I am now, y'know less of the look at how edgy and troubled I am to being or at least trying to be aware of things and trying to see every side of something. His death was pretty surprising for me, because it really seemed like he had it figured out, he was just completely brilliant, and he didn't rub it in your face either it was more like a conversation between friends, and it was really a pick-me-up.

But this is my last week before my college exams anyway, and by extension Saturday was my last night out before summer, although I don't really go out that much to begin with, so that I was out at all was a big deal. But it was a really good night, it reminded me why I used to go out every weekend, rather than when I wanted to get an overpriced drink and see people fall over themselves. Everything just went good. Everybody got buzzed but didn't reach a level of intoxication where they were at risk of vomiting, and it was just like a Brian Eno piece, that would be the best way of describing it. I sorted out shit man and it felt good to know where I was in things, although I'm not sure what the velocity is now, but I'm sure of the location pretty much. Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle is SO relevant to my life. It's not a big deal though, more of just a nice thing that I have going on right now, which is always cool. Overall it was pretty cool, I talked to some people I haven't seen in a while, and everybody found it necessary to say Nice beard, dude. Feltgoodman, because I'd trimmed my beard for the first time since RAG week, although I'm gonna try rock a full beard over the summer, rather than the 3/4 one I got now, I gotta the moustache and the beard connected, otherwise it's just facial hair. It's the first time I was at The Spot in a long time too (The Spot is this miniature woods off from the Spirit Store, and is ideal for sessions and shmoke and all) and talked to Shane Byrne and Jack for an ass-long time, and witnessed Ri's incredible subtlety at work. It's a fun place, one time me and a knucklehead from back in the day rang people asking for soapy titwanks, and busted a whiskey bottle with bare hands. I took the french people there back when they were around too, and managed to fall off the path.

Summer's a fortnight away right now, and oh boy am I excited. I gotta do the exams first, which won't be too bad (THANKS CONTINUOUS ASSESSMENT!) but once they're done I got more time to put in this blog, and cycle, and write and read and listen and chill and grow.

Word 'em up,
Cathal

entry.title: My dad, and other less important things.
entry.content:
I've abandoned trying to indent new paragraphs now since it turns tabbing doesn't really do anything in blogger except maybe move it into 2 spaces and I'm all ENOUGH OF THIS.


I was thinking about what kind of sitcom dad I would want to be like. Like Huxtable or Niles or whoever. I'm not sure who would be the coolest, since in those sitcoms the coolest characters didn't have kids and it was like the more relatable guys like Ross who had kids. My dad isn't really like any of those sitcom dads though, my dad is more like the dude from those school dramas who turns out to be have been a really hip cat during the heyday or whatever. He went to the Who when he was 16, he told me, but nowadays he's all disappointed in modern music and doesn't really have time for it. For his 60th we went to Athlone for a day, since he was back at work on Monday so we couldn't really stay the Sunday.

It was actually a completely boss hotel, it was really modern and well-designed, although the pillows were all soft and insubstantial so I watched Glory Road instead of sleeping and then regretted it heavy when I woke up. Glory Road was a pretty good film, it was bout the UTEP basketball team in the '60s and how they bet Kentucky and won the Final Four with a team of all black players which was back in the day when the SEC did not allow coloured folks in their vicinity. It kinda condensed the timeline a bit but without it the events would have not seemed quite so momentous. I was reading up about them afterwards and it turns out the press of the time was pissed as hell that Adolph Rupp had been shamed and basically accused Texas Western (as UTEP was called at time. They changed their name one year after winning a national championship, that is just bad brand management) of being a pro franchise. It was kind of like in the 1920s when Notre Dame started playing on the east coast regularly and everyone had all kinds of rumours about them, but they pulled it out when it really mattered, like when Al Smith got completely humiliated in the 1928 election by the other party pretty much making Catholics out to be worse than whoever was the Hitler proxy at the time before they had Hitler. It must have been difficult to forfeit political debates back then, you actually had to dig yourself a hole rather than just compare somebody to Hitler.

There was mad vitriol against the Texas Western team, and in fairness in the '60s it was probably most strange for a small school that was not built exclusively for an occasionally-fanatical minority to get recruits from places like New York NY or Gary IN, and they were probably pissed that people were dunking and beating the old-school Kentucky team which played Solid Fundamental Basketball.

Eventually like a year or 2 later when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar came around (Lew Alcindor, whatever, he's always gonna be Kareem) and basically showed up everyone else in the entire league as suckers they banned dunking for about ten years. They didn't even call it the slam dunk back then it seems, that term was used for a special type of dunk that Julius Erving did. I used to be really into basketball, but now it's kind of boring. I don't wanna be the guy ragging on about high salaries, but the NBA needs a salary cap badly. Like you have guys riding the bench playing sparse minutes a game getting paid more than most NFL starting quarterbacks, and the money's guaranteed too, so they can do whatever they want and they still get paid. It's insane, and all it leads to is dudes like Vince Carter, who I used to admire but now think is a massive jerk-off. There were backups in the NBA in 2008 who were making more than RYAN HOWARD! Think about that. There's gonna be a strike next year or something so maybe David Stern will finally introduce a salary cap and bring some sense back and leave the insane guaranteed money for Chris Bosh and the like. Y'know, dudes who actually earn it.


But my dad's probably retiring within the next 14 months. He's earned it, he's worked 39 years basically as what is the most-reviled profession in Ireland for some reason (teacher, but not like loan shark or heroin pusher or any number of worse things that people do not get upset about) and I know because my mom had me go over the figures for what his pension would be based on retiring in July vs. retiring at the end of next year. There's not much point in him working beyond 40 years from the financial side of things, but also I think both him and my mom want him retiring a bit before he's 65 because basically the correlation between Length of Enjoyed Retirement and Proximity to 65 at Time of Retirement for teachers is kind of a scary sight, like on average a teacher that retires at 65 will live for 2 years of pension-collecting and hobby-pursuing, tops.
That blog post was meant to be a short, kind of sentimental thing about my dad but it ended up being a lot longer, and I'm pursuing a policy of Raw and Unfiltered, and I'm not gonna tag it either, since that would involve having a spreadsheet to keep track of my tags to stop one-off tags or tags with subtle variations that defeat the purpose of tags and Excel is not my game, and plus the National's new album is now online and I must give it a listen.

Slán,
Cathal

entry.title: The 4th one usually sucks. I'm bucking the trend.
entry.content:
I was reading Carpo's blog and decided I should write a full-sized update for mine, which I really only started so I could link people to that short story I was really proud of but never came up with a title for.

A lot of stuff has been going on this year, Trinity has been working out awesome, although I could probably have made more classes last semester, but my ego was telling me I didn't need any of that. My exams start in 2 weeks, and they should go alright, with the exception of Chemistry 2 I'm pretty well prepared for them. I met a few cool people this year too, generally the science course is filled with sound dudes. The same applies to Shanowen. Ian moved out in February to a new place, but Liam and Cian are still here and they are 2 solid people. Cian's girlfriend is around sometimes too, and as a 3rd year Trinity science student, she has been giving the helpful advice about it. Dan's also here pretty much every day, and his love of life is infectious. He'll be making me and my brother a sandwich before he dies, it's on his bucket list.

In Dundalk things are improving too. I have a few good friends who are generally there for me and being cool. Shouts out to Fitzy and Frank. Frank is a really good listener, even though recently I have mostly been rambling about my own insecurities. He has the leaving cert coming up, and I am occupying his time. But if you're reading this Frank, thanks bro. Niamh and a few other people are also really cool too, even though I totally flaked on Niamh and invited to her to what is contender for World's Worst Party 2010. She brought Sarah with her, who I have not seen in over a year, and I got my brother's CD back. It's good to see people after a long furlough, even if circumstances of parting weren't exactly good. Thinking about how close we used to be, it's actually slightly surreal, and a few things that happened are nestled in the back of my mind and are basically steroids for the neurotic parts of me that are so raw that the IOC does not even know about them, and it's the last thing I need right now.

I also got talking to Noonan, and him and the Whales are getting back together and recording over the summer. It's going to be one of the best records I hear this year, they're one of the few bands on the Dundalk scene right now that I'm feeling. Noonan's a fantastic guitarist too, and he writes some funny lyrics. That'd probably change if he listened to Brand New's later stuff, but right now he's all about the fun pop-punk about girls and skateboards. It suits him, he's great with melodies, although he doesn't take me seriously when I compliment his abilities. But I'm definitely picking up the vinyl when it drops, harsh tunes and hopefully a kick-ass live show for accompaniment.

I also have a crush on someone; the last time I did I think people were still wondering if Eminem was going to release a comeback album. I don't know if she feels similarly, although she seems to. I'm a novice at this kind of stuff. Previous relationships and all that make me a wreck with this kind of stuff, even though it really has no bearing on it. I don't know if I have any reason to be nervous, I'm just worried I'll lose her interest by being dull or coming on too strong or too weak or something. She's actually pretty cool and all too, she's got amazing taste in music and I could talk to her for ages. I dunno if anything more's going to happen though, but it would be cool as hell if it did.

My MSN got hacked too it seems, and that's probably related to her, given that she's the only person who got sent messages from it. I think I know who did it, but I can't really act upon it because a) I'm not 100% sure and b) It would have bad consequences all around really. I've changed my password and I'm probably going to get a new MSN, so it shouldn't happen again.

I went into Dundalk on Friday and Saturday for what was probably the first time in ages, since everyone seemed shocked by my new facial hair. It was pretty good seeing everyone again, and I hung out with the girl from the previous paragraph for a bit on Saturday, which was good craic, and then went out to a double-18th in Ravensdale. I wasn't expecting much, but it turned out to be good buzz. Steve brought a frisbee and I discussed situations with Frank. He's planning to leave the Bush by changing all their keyboards to Dvorak, which will be hilarious. I'd forgotten how much I liked everyone in that group. They're, for the most part, really chill people. Leno and Devenney were there too. Me and Devenney used to straight up hate each other, but now he's a legend, and nobody got really pissed, so it wasn't like I felt out of place for being pretty much the only sober person around.

That's pretty much it in terms of new events. 4/20 tomorrow so I'm hitting up DKIT with Mully, and we're going to get nicely toasted. I was hoping to have the pokeball bong by that point, but it's not happening. Still something to look forward to in the summer though.

Summer '10 is going to be the shit.


Peace out,
Cathal

entry.title: Gran Blog 3 Prologue: Concept
entry.content: I love 4chan. I love Achewood's fan community. I love trolling. I love lucozade. I love my family. I love mah bros. I love college. I love my flat, and the people that live in it, whether that be officially or unofficially. I love all the DCU dudes that hang out here. I love David Foster Wallace. I love Guided by Voices. I love Bob Dylan. I love pizza. I love chillin'. I love the Venture Brothers. I love holding hands. I love life.

entry.title: A new post cos I haven't used this in 6 months.
entry.content:
So I'm going to college in just over a week, and I'm shitting it cos there are all these social events at night that I really won't fit in at cos I don't drink or anything. But still, I'm living with Sas, and she's pretty legendary, plus Carpo will be over a bit, so at least I'm hanging with dudes I know. I'm living in a really nice place too. It's about the size of Carlingford, and the Spar and Off-Licence are about 200 metres from my flat. And the gym is too, they cancel each other out.

My last month in Dundalk's been pretty good though. I went to 2 shindigs in Christine's house and I had a pretty good time, and I went to the cinema by myself. But other bad shit has happened too. Everyone's going down with some gland infection and it's a bit weird as I was told it wasn't contagious. And one of my best mates got fucked over too, and I'm kinda pissed at the people who did it. But tomorrow I'm going to Kevin's house and me and Mark are gonna make some fuckin' memories then go out to the pub and make some more with everyone else. It's gonna be a great weekend.
